lang="en">United Kingdom</h1> <div class="mw-body-content" id="bodyContent">\n<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div> <div id="contentSub"></div>\n<div id="jump-to-nav"></div> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>\n<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#p-search">Jump to search</a>\n<div class="mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">This article is about the country. It is not to be confused with <a href="/wiki/Great_Britain" title="Great Britain">Great Britain</a>, its largest island whose name is also loosely applied to the whole country.</div>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"UK" redirects here. For other uses of "UK", see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/UK_(disambiguation)" title="UK (disambiguation)">UK (disambiguation)</a>. For other uses of "United Kingdom", see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_(disambiguation)" title="United Kingdom (disambiguation)">United Kingdom (disambiguation)</a>.</div>\n<p class="mw-empty-elt">\n</p>\n<div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Country in Europe</div>\n<p class="mw-empty-elt">\n</p>\n<table class="infobox geography vcard" style="width:22em;font-size:88%;"><tbody><tr><th class="adr" colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold;padding:0.25em 0.33em 0.33em;line-height:1.2em;font-size:1.25em;"><div style="padding-top:0.25em; font-weight:normal;"><div class="fn org country-name" style="display:inline"><div class="NavFrame collapsed" style="border: none; padding: 0;">\n<div class="NavHead" style="font-size: 105%; background:transparent;line-height:normal;font-size:84%;font-weight:normal;"><b><span style="font-size:1.25em;">United Kingdom of Great<br/> Britain and Northern Ireland</span></b></div>\n<ul class="NavContent" style="list-style: none none; margin-left: 0; text-align: left; font-size: 105%; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0; line-height: inherit;"><li style="line-height: inherit; margin: 0"> <table style="padding:0;border:none;margin:-3px;width:auto;min-width:100%;font-size:100%;clear:none;float:none;background-color:transparent;font-size:76%;font-weight:normal;"><tbody><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Scots_language" title="Scots language">Scots</a>:</th><td><i lang="sco" title="Scots language text">Unitit Kinrick o Great Breetain an Northren Ireland</i></td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Ulster_Scots_dialects" title="Ulster Scots dialects">Ulster Scots</a>:</th><td><i lang="sco" title="Scots language text">Claught K&#228;ngrick o Docht Br&#228;tain an Norlin Airlann</i></td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Welsh_language" title="Welsh language">Welsh</a>:</th><td><i lang="cy" title="Welsh language text">Teyrnas Unedig Prydain Fawr a Gogledd Iwerddon</i></td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Cornish_language" title="Cornish language">Cornish</a>:</th><td><i lang="kw" title="Cornish language text">Rywvaneth Unys Breten Veur ha Kledhbarth Iwerdhon</i></td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Scottish_Gaelic" title="Scottish Gaelic">Scottish&#160;Gaelic</a>:</th><td><i lang="gd" title="Scottish Gaelic language text">R&#236;oghachd Aonaichte Bhreatainn is &#200;ireann a Tuath</i></td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Irish_language" title="Irish language">Irish</a>:</th><td><i lang="ga" title="Irish language text">R&#237;ocht Aontaithe na Breataine M&#243;ire agus Thuaisceart &#201;ireann</i></td></tr></tbody></table>\n</li></ul>\n</div></div></div></th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" style="text-align:center;text-align:center;padding:0.5em 0;"><div style="display:table; href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Telephone numbers in the United Kingdom">+44</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21"><a href="#cite_note-21">[note 8]</a></sup></td></tr><tr><th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/ISO_3166" title="ISO 3166">ISO 3166 code</a></th><td><a href="/wiki/ISO_3166-2:GB" title="ISO 3166-2:GB">GB</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Country_code_top-level_domain" title="Country code top-level domain">Internet TLD</a></th><td><a href="/wiki/.uk" title=".uk">.uk</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22"><a href="#cite_note-22">[note 9]</a></sup></td></tr></tbody></table>\n<p>The <b>United Kingdom</b>, officially the <b>United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland</b> but more commonly known as the <b>UK</b><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[14]</a></sup> or <b>Britain</b>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[note 10]</a></sup> is a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sovereign_country" title="Sovereign country">sovereign country</a> lying off the north-western coast of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_mainland" title="European mainland">European mainland</a>. The United Kingdom includes the island of <a href="/wiki/Great_Britain" title="Great Britain">Great Britain</a>, the north-eastern part of the island of <a href="/wiki/Ireland" title="Ireland">Ireland</a> and many smaller islands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25"><a href="#cite_note-25">[15]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland" title="Northern Ireland">Northern Ireland</a> is the only part of the United Kingdom that shares <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland%E2%80%93United_Kingdom_border" title="Republic of Ireland&#8211;United Kingdom border">a land border</a> with another sovereign state&#8205;&#8212;&#8204;the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland" title="Republic of Ireland">Republic of Ireland</a>. Apart from this land border, the United Kingdom is surrounded by the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a>, with the <a href="/wiki/North_Sea" title="North Sea">North Sea</a> to the east, the <a href="/wiki/English_Channel" title="English Channel">English Channel</a> to the south and the <a href="/wiki/Celtic_Sea" title="Celtic Sea">Celtic Sea</a> to the south-west, giving it the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_length_of_coastline" title="List of countries by length of coastline">12th-longest coastline in the world</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Irish_Sea" title="Irish Sea">Irish Sea</a> lies between Great Britain and Ireland. With an area of 242,500 square kilometres (93,600&#160;sq&#160;mi), the United Kingdom is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_area" title="List of countries by area">78th-largest sovereign state in the world</a>. It is also the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population" title="List of countries and dependencies by population">22nd-most populous country</a>, with an estimated 66.0 million inhabitants in 2017.\n</p><p>The UK is a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parliamentary_democracy" title="Parliamentary democracy">parliamentary democracy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26"><a href="#cite_note-26">[16]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27"><a href="#cite_note-27">[17]</a></sup> The current <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Monarchy of the United Kingdom">monarch</a> is Queen <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_II" title="Elizabeth II">Elizabeth II</a>, who has reigned since 1952, making her the <a href="/wiki/List_of_current_state_leaders_by_date_of_assumption_of_office" title="List of current state leaders by date of assumption of office">longest-serving current head of state</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[18]</a></sup> The United Kingdom\'s capital and largest city is <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Global_city" title="Global city">global city</a> and <a href="/wiki/Financial_centre" title="Financial centre">financial centre</a> with an urban area population of 10.3 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29">[19]</a></sup> Other major <a href="/wiki/List_of_urban_areas_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="List of urban areas in the United Kingdom">urban areas in the UK</a> include <a href="/wiki/Greater_Manchester_Built-up_Area" title="Greater Manchester Built-up Area">Manchester</a>, <a href="/wiki/West_Midlands_conurbation" title="West Midlands conurbation">Birmingham</a>, <a href="/wiki/West_Yorkshire_Urban_Area" title="West Yorkshire Urban Area">Leeds</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greater_Glasgow" title="Greater Glasgow">Glasgow</a>, <a href="/wiki/Liverpool_Urban_Area" title="Liverpool Urban Area">Liverpool</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/City_of_Newcastle_upon_Tyne" title="City of Newcastle upon Tyne">Newcastle</a>.\n</p><p>The United Kingdom consists of <a href="/wiki/Countries_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Countries of the United Kingdom">four constituent countries</a>: <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">England</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wales" title="Wales">Wales</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland" title="Northern Ireland">Northern Ireland</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-page823_30-0"><a href="#cite_note-page823-30">[20]</a></sup> Their capitals are <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a>, <a href="/wiki/Edinburgh" title="Edinburgh">Edinburgh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cardiff" title="Cardiff">Cardiff</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Belfast" title="Belfast">Belfast</a> respectively. Apart from England, the countries have their own <a href="/wiki/Devolution_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Devolution in the United Kingdom">devolved</a> governments,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-devoladmins_31-0"><a href="#cite_note-devoladmins-31">[21]</a></sup> each with varying powers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[22]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33">[23]</a></sup> The nearby <a href="/wiki/Isle_of_Man" title="Isle of Man">Isle of Man</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bailiwick_of_Guernsey" title="Bailiwick of Guernsey">Bailiwick of Guernsey</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bailiwick_of_Jersey" title="Bailiwick of Jersey">Bailiwick of Jersey</a> are not part of the UK, being <a href="/wiki/Crown_dependencies" title="Crown dependencies">Crown dependencies</a> with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Government" title="British Government">British Government</a> responsible for defence and international representation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[24]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Conquest_of_Wales_by_Edward_I_of_England" title="Conquest of Wales by Edward I of England">medieval conquest</a> and <a href="/wiki/Laws_in_Wales_Acts_1535_and_1542" title="Laws in Wales Acts 1535 and 1542">subsequent annexation</a> of Wales by the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_England" title="Kingdom of England">Kingdom of England</a>, followed by the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Union" title="Treaty of Union">union</a> between England and Scotland in 1707 to form the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain" title="Kingdom of Great Britain">Kingdom of Great Britain</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_Union_1800" title="Acts of Union 1800">union</a> in 1801 of Great Britain with the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Ireland" title="Kingdom of Ireland">Kingdom of Ireland</a> created the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland" title="United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland">United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland</a>. Five-sixths of Ireland seceded from the UK in 1922, leaving the present formulation of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[note 11]</a></sup> There are <a href="/wiki/British_Overseas_Territories" title="British Overseas Territories">fourteen British Overseas Territories</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-overseasterrirories_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-overseasterrirories-36">[25]</a></sup> the remnants of the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a> which, at its height in the 1920s, encompassed almost a quarter of the world\'s land mass and was the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_empires#Empires_at_their_greatest_extent" title="List of largest empires">largest empire in history</a>. British influence can be observed in the language, culture and political systems of many of its <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_that_have_gained_independence_from_the_United_Kingdom" title="List of countries that have gained independence from the United Kingdom">former colonies</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[26]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[27]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39">[28]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40"><a href="#cite_note-40">[29]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerguson2004b307_41-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerguson2004b307-41">[30]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The United Kingdom is a <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">developed country</a> and has the world\'s <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">fifth-largest economy</a> by nominal GDP and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">ninth-largest economy</a> by <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a>. It has a <a href="/wiki/World_Bank_high-income_economy" title="World Bank high-income economy">high-income economy</a> and has a very high <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index rating</a>, ranking <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">14th in the world</a>. It was the world\'s first industrialised country and the world\'s foremost <a href="/wiki/Power_(international_relations)" title="Power (international relations)">power</a> during the 19th and early 20th centuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[31]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ferguson_43-0"><a href="#cite_note-ferguson-43">[32]</a></sup> The UK remains a <a href="/wiki/Great_power" title="Great power">great power</a>, with considerable economic, cultural, military, scientific and political <a href="/wiki/Sphere_of_influence" title="Sphere of influence">influence</a> internationally.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[33]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-David_M._McCourt_45-0"><a href="#cite_note-David_M._McCourt-45">[34]</a></sup> It is a recognised <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_with_nuclear_weapons" title="List of states with nuclear weapons">nuclear weapons state</a> and is <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures" title="List of countries by military expenditures">sixth in military expenditure</a> in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46"><a href="#cite_note-46">[35]</a></sup> It has been a <a href="/wiki/Permanent_members_of_the_United_Nations_Security_Council" title="Permanent members of the United Nations Security Council">permanent member</a> of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a> since its first session in 1946. It has been a <a href="/wiki/Big_Four_(Western_Europe)" title="Big Four (Western Europe)">leading member state</a> of the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> (EU) and its predecessor, the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">European Economic Community</a> (EEC), since 1973; however, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_European_Union_membership_referendum,_2016" title="United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016">a referendum in 2016</a> resulted in 51.9% of UK voters favouring leaving the European Union, and the country\'s <a href="/wiki/Brexit_negotiations" title="Brexit negotiations">exit is being negotiated</a>. The United Kingdom is also a member of the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">Commonwealth of Nations</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G7" title="G7">G7</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G-20_major_economies" title="G-20 major economies">G20</a>, <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a> (OECD), <a href="/wiki/Interpol" title="Interpol">Interpol</a> and the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> (WTO).\n</p>\n<div class="toc" id="toc"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2>Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>\n<ul>\n<li Ireland</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-6"><a href="#Irish_independence"><span class="tocnumber">2.4</span> <span class="toctext">Irish independence</span></a></li>\n<li href="#Law_and_criminal_justice"><span class="tocnumber">5.3</span> <span class="toctext">Law and criminal justice</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-16"><a href="#Foreign_relations"><span class="tocnumber">5.4</span> <span class="toctext">Foreign relations</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-17"><a href="#Military"><span class="tocnumber">5.5</span> <span class="toctext">Military</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-18"><a href="#Economy"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">Economy</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-19"><a href="#Overview"><span class="tocnumber">6.1</span> <span class="toctext">Overview</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-20"><a href="#Science_and_technology"><span class="tocnumber">6.2</span> <span class="toctext">Science and technology</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-21"><a href="#Transport"><span class="tocnumber">6.3</span> <span class="toctext">Transport</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-22"><a href="#Energy"><span class="tocnumber">6.4</span> <span class="toctext">Energy</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-23"><a href="#Water_supply_and_sanitation"><span class="tocnumber">6.5</span> <span class="toctext">Water supply and sanitation</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-24"><a href="#Demographics"><span class="tocnumber">7</span> <span class="toctext">Demographics</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-25"><a href="#Ethnic_groups"><span class="tocnumber">7.1</span> <span class="toctext">Ethnic groups</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-26"><a href="#Languages"><span class="tocnumber">7.2</span> <span class="toctext">Languages</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-27"><a href="#Religion"><span class="tocnumber">7.3</span> <span class="toctext">Religion</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-28"><a href="#Migration"><span class="tocnumber">7.4</span> <span class="toctext">Migration</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-29"><a href="#Education"><span class="tocnumber">7.5</span> <span class="toctext">Education</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-30"><a href="#Healthcare"><span class="tocnumber">7.6</span> <span class="toctext">Healthcare</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-31"><a href="#Culture"><span class="tocnumber">8</span> <span class="toctext">Culture</span></a>\n<ul>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-32"><a href="#Literature"><span class="tocnumber">8.1</span> <span class="toctext">Literature</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-33"><a href="#Music"><span class="tocnumber">8.2</span> <span class="toctext">Music</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-34"><a href="#Visual_art"><span class="tocnumber">8.3</span> <span class="toctext">Visual art</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-35"><a href="#Cinema"><span class="tocnumber">8.4</span> <span class="toctext">Cinema</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-36"><a href="#Cuisine"><span class="tocnumber">8.5</span> <span class="toctext">Cuisine</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-37"><a href="#Media"><span class="tocnumber">8.6</span> <span class="toctext">Media</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-38"><a href="#Philosophy"><span class="tocnumber">8.7</span> <span class="toctext">Philosophy</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-39"><a href="#Sport"><span class="tocnumber">8.8</span> <span class="toctext">Sport</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-40"><a href="#Symbols"><span class="tocnumber">8.9</span> <span class="toctext">Symbols</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-41"><a href="#Historiography"><span class="tocnumber">9</span> <span class="toctext">Historiography</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-42"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">10</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-43"><a href="#Notes"><span class="tocnumber">11</span> <span class="toctext">Notes</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-44"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">12</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-45"><a href="#Further_reading"><span class="tocnumber">13</span> <span class="toctext">Further reading</span></a></li>\n<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-46"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">14</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>\n</ul>\n</div>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology_and_terminology">Etymology and terminology</span></h2>\n<p><span id="Etymology"></span>\n</p>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Britain_(place_name)" title="Britain (place name)">Britain (place name)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Terminology_of_the_British_Isles" title="Terminology of the British Isles">Terminology of the British Isles</a></div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_Union_1707" title="Acts of Union 1707">1707 Acts of Union</a> declared that the kingdoms of <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_England" title="Kingdom of England">England</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Scotland" title="Kingdom of Scotland">Scotland</a> were "United into One Kingdom by the Name of <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain" title="Kingdom of Great Britain">Great Britain</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[36]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"><a href="#cite_note-48">[37]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[note 12]</a></sup> The term "United Kingdom" has occasionally been used as a description for the former kingdom of Great Britain, although its official name from 1707 to 1800 was simply "Great Britain".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[38]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-name_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-name-51">[39]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-name2_52-0"><a href="#cite_note-name2-52">[40]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-name3_53-0"><a href="#cite_note-name3-53">[41]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[42]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_Union_1800" title="Acts of Union 1800">Acts of Union 1800</a> united the kingdom of Great Britain and the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Ireland" title="Kingdom of Ireland">kingdom of Ireland</a> in 1801, forming the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland" title="United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland">United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland</a>. Following the <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_Ireland" title="Partition of Ireland">partition of Ireland</a> and the independence of the <a href="/wiki/Irish_Free_State" title="Irish Free State">Irish Free State</a> in 1922, which left <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland" title="Northern Ireland">Northern Ireland</a> as the only part of the island of Ireland within the United Kingdom, the name was changed to the "United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[43]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Although the United Kingdom is a sovereign country, England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland are also widely referred to as countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-alphabeticalNI1_56-0"><a href="#cite_note-alphabeticalNI1-56">[44]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[45]</a></sup> The UK Prime Minister\'s website has used the phrase "countries within a country" to describe the United Kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-page823_30-1"><a href="#cite_note-page823-30">[20]</a></sup> Some statistical summaries, such as those for the twelve <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NUTS_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="NUTS of the United Kingdom">NUTS 1 regions of the United Kingdom</a> refer to Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland as "regions".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[46]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[47]</a></sup> Northern Ireland is also referred to as a "province".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-alphabeticalNI2_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-alphabeticalNI2-60">[48]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-placeApart_61-0"><a href="#cite_note-placeApart-61">[49]</a></sup> With regard to Northern Ireland, the descriptive name used "can be controversial, with the choice often revealing one\'s political preferences".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[50]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The term "Great Britain" conventionally refers to the island of Great Britain, or politically to England, Scotland and Wales in combination.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[51]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[52]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[53]</a></sup> However, it is sometimes used as a loose synonym for the United Kingdom as a whole.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[54]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Britain_(place_name)" title="Britain (place name)">term "Britain"</a> is used both as a synonym for Great Britain,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britain-CED_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-Britain-CED-67">[55]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britain-OLD_68-0"><a href="#cite_note-Britain-OLD-68">[56]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britain-Col_69-0"><a href="#cite_note-Britain-Col-69">[57]</a></sup> and as a synonym for the United Kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britain-MW_70-0"><a href="#cite_note-Britain-MW-70">[58]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britain-Col_69-1"><a href="#cite_note-Britain-Col-69">[57]</a></sup>\nUsage is mixed, with the <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a> preferring to use Britain as shorthand only for Great Britain<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-checklist-bbc_71-0"><a href="#cite_note-checklist-bbc-71">[59]</a></sup> and the UK Government, while accepting that both terms refer to the United Kingdom, preferring to use the term UK rather than Britain.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-style-guide-govuk_72-0"><a href="#cite_note-style-guide-govuk-72">[60]</a></sup> The UK <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Permanent_Committee_on_Geographical_Names" title="Permanent Committee on Geographical Names">Permanent Committee on Geographical Names</a> lists "United Kingdom" and "UK or U.K." as shortened and abbreviated geopolitical terms for the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, it does not list "Britain",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PCGN-uk-guide_73-0"><a href="#cite_note-PCGN-uk-guide-73">[61]</a></sup> stating that it has been used "informally" by government websites.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-num10-countries_74-0"><a href="#cite_note-num10-countries-74">[62]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The adjective "British" is commonly used to refer to matters relating to the United Kingdom. The term has no definite legal connotation, but is used in law to refer to United Kingdom citizenship and <a href="/wiki/British_nationality_law" title="British nationality law">matters to do with nationality</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bradley_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bradley-75">[63]</a></sup> People of the United Kingdom use a number of different terms to describe their national identity and may identify themselves as being <a href="/wiki/British_people" title="British people">British</a>, <a href="/wiki/English_people" title="English people">English</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scottish_people" title="Scottish people">Scottish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Welsh_people" title="Welsh people">Welsh</a>, <a href="/wiki/People_of_Northern_Ireland" title="People of Northern Ireland">Northern Irish</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Irish_people" title="Irish people">Irish</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76"><a href="#cite_note-76">[64]</a></sup> or as belonging to a combination of different national identities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[65]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_British_Isles" title="History of the British Isles">History of the British Isles</a></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Background">Background</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_England" title="History of England">History of England</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_Wales" title="History of Wales">History of Wales</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_Scotland" title="History of Scotland">History of Scotland</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_Ireland" title="History of Ireland">History of Ireland</a>, and <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_formation_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="History of the formation of the United Kingdom">History of the formation of the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Stonehenge,_Condado_de_Wiltshire,_Inglaterra,_2014-08-12,_DD_18.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2786" data-file-width="5265" decoding="async" height="116" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Stonehenge%2C_Condado_de_Wiltshire%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-12%2C_DD_18.JPG/220px-Stonehenge%2C_Condado_de_Wiltshire%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-12%2C_DD_18.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Stonehenge%2C_Condado_de_Wiltshire%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-12%2C_DD_18.JPG/330px-Stonehenge%2C_Condado_de_Wiltshire%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-12%2C_DD_18.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Stonehenge%2C_Condado_de_Wiltshire%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-12%2C_DD_18.JPG/440px-Stonehenge%2C_Condado_de_Wiltshire%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-12%2C_DD_18.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Stonehenge,_Condado_de_Wiltshire,_Inglaterra,_2014-08-12,_DD_18.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The stones of <a href="/wiki/Stonehenge" title="Stonehenge">Stonehenge</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Wiltshire" title="Wiltshire">Wiltshire</a>, were erected between 2400 and 2200 BC</div></div></div>\n<p>Settlement by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cro-Magnons" title="Cro-Magnons">anatomically modern humans</a> of what was to become the United Kingdom occurred in waves beginning by about 30,000 years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[66]</a></sup> By the end of the <a href="/wiki/Prehistoric_Britain" title="Prehistoric Britain">region\'s prehistoric period</a>, the population is thought to have belonged, in the main, to a culture termed <a href="/wiki/Insular_Celts" title="Insular Celts">Insular Celtic</a>, comprising <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Britons_(historical)" title="Britons (historical)">Brittonic Britain</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gaelic_Ireland" title="Gaelic Ireland">Gaelic Ireland</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[67]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Roman_conquest_of_Britain" title="Roman conquest of Britain">Roman conquest</a>, beginning in 43 AD, and the 400-year <a href="/wiki/Roman_Britain" title="Roman Britain">rule of southern Britain</a>, was followed by an invasion by <a href="/wiki/Germanic_peoples" title="Germanic peoples">Germanic</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anglo-Saxon" title="Anglo-Saxon">Anglo-Saxon</a> settlers, reducing the Brittonic area mainly <a href="/wiki/Wales#Medieval_Wales" title="Wales">to what was to become Wales</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cornwall" title="Cornwall">Cornwall</a> and, until the latter stages of the Anglo-Saxon settlement, the <a href="/wiki/Hen_Ogledd" title="Hen Ogledd">Hen Ogledd</a> (northern England and parts of southern Scotland).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[68]</a></sup> Most of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_England" title="Anglo-Saxon England">region settled by the Anglo-Saxons</a> became unified as the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_England" title="Kingdom of England">Kingdom of England</a> in the 10th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Short_Athelstan_biography_on_the_BBC_History_website_81-0"><a href="#cite_note-Short_Athelstan_biography_on_the_BBC_History_website-81">[69]</a></sup> Meanwhile, <a href="/wiki/D%C3%A1l_Riata" title="D&#225;l Riata">Gaelic-speakers in north-west Britain</a> (with connections to the north-east of Ireland and traditionally supposed to have migrated from there in the 5th century)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82">[70]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[71]</a></sup> united with the <a href="/wiki/Picts" title="Picts">Picts</a> to create the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Scotland" title="Kingdom of Scotland">Kingdom of Scotland</a> in the 9th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84">[72]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bayeux_Tapestry_WillelmDux.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="291" data-file-width="401" decoding="async" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Bayeux_Tapestry_WillelmDux.jpg/220px-Bayeux_Tapestry_WillelmDux.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Bayeux_Tapestry_WillelmDux.jpg/330px-Bayeux_Tapestry_WillelmDux.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/96/Bayeux_Tapestry_WillelmDux.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bayeux_Tapestry_WillelmDux.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Bayeux_Tapestry" title="Bayeux Tapestry">Bayeux Tapestry</a> depicts the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Hastings" title="Battle of Hastings">Battle of Hastings</a>, 1066, and the events leading to it</div></div></div>\n<p>In 1066, the <a href="/wiki/Normans" title="Normans">Normans</a> and their <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Breton_people" title="Breton people">Breton</a> allies invaded England from northern <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a> and after <a href="/wiki/Norman_conquest_of_England" title="Norman conquest of England">its conquest</a>, seized <a href="/wiki/Norman_invasion_of_Wales" title="Norman invasion of Wales">large parts of Wales</a>, <a href="/wiki/Norman_invasion_of_Ireland" title="Norman invasion of Ireland">conquered much of Ireland</a> and were invited to <a href="/wiki/Davidian_Revolution" title="Davidian Revolution">settle in Scotland</a>, bringing to each country <a href="/wiki/Feudalism" title="Feudalism">feudalism</a> on the Northern French model and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norman-French" title="Norman-French">Norman-French</a> culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85">[73]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Normans" title="Anglo-Normans">Anglo-Norman</a> <a href="/wiki/Ruling_class" title="Ruling class">ruling class</a> greatly influenced, but eventually assimilated with, each of the local cultures.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[74]</a></sup> Subsequent <a href="/wiki/House_of_Plantagenet" title="House of Plantagenet">medieval English kings</a> completed the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Conquest_of_Wales" title="Conquest of Wales">conquest of Wales</a> and made an unsuccessful <a href="/wiki/Wars_of_Scottish_Independence" title="Wars of Scottish Independence">attempt to annex Scotland</a>. Following the <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_Arbroath" title="Declaration of Arbroath">Declaration of Arbroath</a>, Scotland maintained its independence, albeit in <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Scottish_Wars" title="Anglo-Scottish Wars">near-constant conflict with England</a>. The English monarchs, through inheritance of <a href="/wiki/Angevin_Empire" title="Angevin Empire">substantial territories in France</a> and claims to the French crown, were also heavily involved in conflicts in France, most notably the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hundred_Years_War" title="Hundred Years War">Hundred Years War</a>, while the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Scottish_monarchs" title="List of Scottish monarchs">Kings of Scots</a> were in <a href="/wiki/Auld_Alliance" title="Auld Alliance">an alliance with the French</a> during this period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[75]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Early_Modern_Britain" title="Early Modern Britain">early modern period</a> saw religious conflict resulting from the <a href="/wiki/Reformation" title="Reformation">Reformation</a> and the introduction of <a href="/wiki/Protestantism_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Protestantism in the United Kingdom">Protestant</a> state churches in each country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[76]</a></sup> Wales was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Laws_in_Wales_Acts_1535%E2%80%931542" title="Laws in Wales Acts 1535&#8211;1542">fully incorporated into the Kingdom of England</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_Tudors_89-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Tudors-89">[77]</a></sup> and Ireland was constituted as a kingdom in personal union with the English crown.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[78]</a></sup> In what was to become Northern Ireland, the lands of the independent Catholic Gaelic nobility were confiscated and <a href="/wiki/Plantation_of_Ulster" title="Plantation of Ulster">given to Protestant settlers</a> from England and Scotland.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[79]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 1603, the kingdoms of England, Scotland and Ireland were united in a <a href="/wiki/Personal_union" title="Personal union">personal union</a> when <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/James_I_of_England" title="James I of England">James VI, King of Scots</a>, inherited the crowns of England and Ireland and moved his court from Edinburgh to London; each country nevertheless remained a separate political entity and retained its separate political, legal, and religious institutions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-D._Ross,_2002_p._56_92-0"><a href="#cite_note-D._Ross,_2002_p._56-92">[80]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-J._Hearn,_2002_p._104_93-0"><a href="#cite_note-J._Hearn,_2002_p._104-93">[81]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In the mid-17th century, all three kingdoms <a href="/wiki/Wars_of_the_Three_Kingdoms" title="Wars of the Three Kingdoms">were involved in a series of connected wars</a> (including the <a href="/wiki/English_Civil_War" title="English Civil War">English Civil War</a>) which led to the temporary overthrow of the monarchy and the establishment of the short-lived <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unitary_republic" title="Unitary republic">unitary republic</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_England" title="Commonwealth of England">Commonwealth of England, Scotland and Ireland</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[82]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[83]</a></sup> During the 17th and 18th centuries, British sailors were involved in acts of <a href="/wiki/Piracy" title="Piracy">piracy</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Privateering" title="Privateering">privateering</a>), attacking and stealing from ships off the coast of Europe and the Caribbean.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[84]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:State_House-_1620_-_St_Geo_-_Bermuda.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="648" data-file-width="864" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/State_House-_1620_-_St_Geo_-_Bermuda.jpg/220px-State_House-_1620_-_St_Geo_-_Bermuda.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/State_House-_1620_-_St_Geo_-_Bermuda.jpg/330px-State_House-_1620_-_St_Geo_-_Bermuda.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/State_House-_1620_-_St_Geo_-_Bermuda.jpg/440px-State_House-_1620_-_St_Geo_-_Bermuda.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:State_House-_1620_-_St_Geo_-_Bermuda.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/State_House,_Bermuda" title="State House, Bermuda">State House</a> in <a href="/wiki/St._George%27s,_Bermuda" title="St. George\'s, Bermuda">St. George\'s</a>, Bermuda. Settled in 1612, the town is the oldest continuously-inhabited English town in the New World.</div></div></div>\n<p>Although the <a href="/wiki/Restoration_(1660)" title="Restoration (1660)">monarchy was restored</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Interregnum_(1649%E2%80%931660)" title="Interregnum (1649&#8211;1660)">Interregnum</a> ensured (along with the <a href="/wiki/Glorious_Revolution" title="Glorious Revolution">Glorious Revolution</a> of 1688 and the subsequent <a href="/wiki/Bill_of_Rights_1689" title="Bill of Rights 1689">Bill of Rights 1689</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Claim_of_Right_Act_1689" title="Claim of Right Act 1689">Claim of Right Act 1689</a>) that, unlike much of the rest of Europe, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Royal_absolutism" title="Royal absolutism">royal absolutism</a> would not prevail, and a professed Catholic could never accede to the throne. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_constitution" title="British constitution">British constitution</a> would develop on the basis of <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">parliamentary system</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[85]</a></sup> With the founding of the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Society" title="Royal Society">Royal Society</a> in 1660, science was greatly encouraged. During this period, particularly in England, the development of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/English_navy" title="English navy">naval power</a> (and the interest in <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Discovery" title="Age of Discovery">voyages of discovery</a>) led to the acquisition and settlement of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_British_Empire" title="First British Empire">overseas colonies</a>, particularly in North America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[86]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[87]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Though previous attempts at uniting the two kingdoms within Great Britain in 1606, 1667, and 1689 had proved unsuccessful, the attempt initiated in 1705 led to the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Union" title="Treaty of Union">Treaty of Union</a> of 1706 being agreed and ratified by both parliaments\n</p>\n<div style="clear:left;"></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Treaty_of_Union">Treaty of Union</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="History of the United Kingdom">History of the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Treaty_of_Union.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1225" data-file-width="1562" decoding="async" height="173" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Treaty_of_Union.jpg/220px-Treaty_of_Union.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Treaty_of_Union.jpg/330px-Treaty_of_Union.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Treaty_of_Union.jpg/440px-Treaty_of_Union.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Treaty_of_Union.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Union" title="Treaty of Union">Treaty of Union</a> led to a single united kingdom encompassing all Great Britain</div></div></div>\n<p>On 1 May 1707, the united <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain" title="Kingdom of Great Britain">Kingdom of Great Britain</a> came into being, the result of <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_Union_1707" title="Acts of Union 1707">Acts of Union</a> being passed by the parliaments of England and Scotland to ratify the 1706 <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Union" title="Treaty of Union">Treaty of Union</a> and so unite the two kingdoms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[88]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[89]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[90]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In the 18th century, cabinet government developed under <a href="/wiki/Robert_Walpole" title="Robert Walpole">Robert Walpole</a>, in practice the first prime minister (1721&#8211;1742). A series of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jacobite_Uprisings" title="Jacobite Uprisings">Jacobite Uprisings</a> sought to remove the Protestant <a href="/wiki/House_of_Hanover" title="House of Hanover">House of Hanover</a> from the British throne and restore the Catholic <a href="/wiki/House_of_Stuart" title="House of Stuart">House of Stuart</a>. The Jacobites were finally defeated at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Culloden" title="Battle of Culloden">Battle of Culloden</a> in 1746, after which the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scottish_Highlanders" title="Scottish Highlanders">Scottish Highlanders</a> were brutally suppressed. The British colonies in North America that broke away from Britain in the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War" title="American Revolutionary War">American War of Independence</a> became the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_of_America" title="United States of America">United States of America</a>, recognised by Britain in 1783. British imperial ambition turned towards Asia, particularly to <a href="/wiki/Company_rule_in_India" title="Company rule in India">India</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103"><a href="#cite_note-103">[91]</a></sup>\n</p><p>During the 18th century, Britain was involved in the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_slave_trade" title="Atlantic slave trade">Atlantic slave trade</a>. British <a href="/wiki/Slave_ship" title="Slave ship">ships</a> transported an estimated two million slaves from Africa to the West Indies. Parliament banned the trade in 1807, banned slavery in the British Empire in 1833, and Britain took a leading role in the movement to abolish slavery worldwide through the <a href="/wiki/Blockade_of_Africa" title="Blockade of Africa">blockade of Africa</a> and pressing other nations to end their trade with a series of treaties. The world\'s oldest international human rights organisation, <a href="/wiki/Anti-Slavery_International" title="Anti-Slavery International">Anti-Slavery International</a>, was formed in London in 1839.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[92]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[93]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[94]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Union_with_Ireland">Union with Ireland</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_Union_1800" title="Acts of Union 1800">Acts of Union 1800</a></div>\n<p>The term "United Kingdom" became official in 1801 when the parliaments of Britain and Ireland each passed an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Acts_of_Union_(1800)" title="Acts of Union (1800)">Act of Union</a>, uniting the two kingdoms and creating the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland" title="United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland">United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[95]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Battle_of_Waterloo_1815.PNG"><img alt="Painting of a bloody battle. Horses and infantry fight or lie on grass." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="846" data-file-width="1854" decoding="async" height="100" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Battle_of_Waterloo_1815.PNG/220px-Battle_of_Waterloo_1815.PNG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Battle_of_Waterloo_1815.PNG/330px-Battle_of_Waterloo_1815.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Battle_of_Waterloo_1815.PNG/440px-Battle_of_Waterloo_1815.PNG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Battle_of_Waterloo_1815.PNG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Waterloo" title="Battle of Waterloo">Battle of Waterloo</a>, 1815, marked the end of the <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a> and the start of <i><a href="/wiki/Pax_Britannica" title="Pax Britannica">Pax Britannica</a></i></div></div></div>\n<p>In the early 19th century, the British-led <a href="/wiki/Industrial_Revolution" title="Industrial Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a> began to transform the country. Gradually political power shifted away from the old <a href="/wiki/Tory" title="Tory">Tory</a> and <a href="/wiki/Whiggism" title="Whiggism">Whig</a> landowning classes towards the new industrialists. An alliance of merchants and industrialists with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Whig_(British_political_party)" title="Whig (British political party)">Whigs</a> would lead to a new party, the <a href="/wiki/Liberal_Party_(UK)" title="Liberal Party (UK)">Liberals</a>, with an ideology of <a href="/wiki/Free_trade" title="Free trade">free trade</a> and <i><a href="/wiki/Laissez-faire" title="Laissez-faire">laissez-faire</a></i>. In 1832 Parliament passed the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Great_Reform_Act" title="Great Reform Act">Great Reform Act</a>, which began the transfer of political power from the aristocracy to the middle classes. In the countryside, <a href="/wiki/Enclosure" title="Enclosure">enclosure</a> of the land was driving small farmers out. Towns and cities began to swell with a new urban working class. Few ordinary workers had the vote, and they created their own organisations in the form of trade unions.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (April 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>\n</p><p>After the defeat of France at the end of the <a href="/wiki/French_Revolutionary_Wars" title="French Revolutionary Wars">Revolutionary</a> and <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a> (1792&#8211;1815), Great Britain emerged as the principal naval and imperial power of the 19th century (with London the largest city in the world from about 1830).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[96]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy#1815&#8211;1914" title="Royal Navy">Unchallenged at sea</a>, British dominance was later described as <i><a href="/wiki/Pax_Britannica" title="Pax Britannica">Pax Britannica</a></i> ("British Peace"), a period of <a href="/wiki/International_relations_of_the_Great_Powers_(1814%E2%80%931919)" title="International relations of the Great Powers (1814&#8211;1919)">relative peace among the Great Powers</a> (1815&#8211;1914) during which the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a> became the global <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hegemon" title="Hegemon">hegemon</a> and adopted the role of global policeman.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[97]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[98]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[99]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[100]</a></sup> By the time of <a href="/wiki/The_Great_Exhibition" title="The Great Exhibition">the Great Exhibition</a> of 1851, Britain was described as the "workshop of the world".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[101]</a></sup> The British Empire was expanded to include <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">India</a>, large <a href="/wiki/British_Empire#Cape_to_Cairo" title="British Empire">parts of Africa</a> and many other territories throughout the world. Alongside the formal control it exerted over its own colonies, British dominance of much of world trade meant that it effectively <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Informal_Empire" title="Informal Empire">controlled the economies of many regions</a>, such as Asia and Latin America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[102]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115">[103]</a></sup> Domestically, political attitudes favoured free trade and laissez-faire policies and a gradual widening of the voting franchise. During the century, the population increased at a dramatic rate, accompanied by rapid urbanisation, causing significant social and economic stresses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[104]</a></sup> To seek new markets and sources of raw materials, the <a href="/wiki/Conservative_Party_(UK)" title="Conservative Party (UK)">Conservative Party</a> under <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Disraeli" title="Disraeli">Disraeli</a> launched a period of imperialist expansion in Egypt, South Africa, and elsewhere. <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">Canada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">Australia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand" title="New Zealand">New Zealand</a> became self-governing dominions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[105]</a></sup> After the turn of the century, Britain\'s industrial dominance was challenged by Germany and the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[106]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Social reform and home rule for Ireland were important domestic issues after 1900. The <a href="/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK)" title="Labour Party (UK)">Labour Party</a> emerged from an alliance of trade unions and small socialist groups in 1900, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Suffragettes" title="Suffragettes">suffragettes</a> campaigned for women\'s right to vote before 1914.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[107]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Royal_Irish_Rifles_ration_party_Somme_July_1916.jpg"><img alt="Black-and-white photo of two dozen men in military uniforms and metal helmets sitting or standing in a muddy trench." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="671" data-file-width="949" decoding="async" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Royal_Irish_Rifles_ration_party_Somme_July_1916.jpg/220px-Royal_Irish_Rifles_ration_party_Somme_July_1916.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Royal_Irish_Rifles_ration_party_Somme_July_1916.jpg/330px-Royal_Irish_Rifles_ration_party_Somme_July_1916.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Royal_Irish_Rifles_ration_party_Somme_July_1916.jpg/440px-Royal_Irish_Rifles_ration_party_Somme_July_1916.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Royal_Irish_Rifles_ration_party_Somme_July_1916.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Infantry of the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Ulster_Rifles" title="Royal Ulster Rifles">Royal Irish Rifles</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Somme" title="Battle of the Somme">Battle of the Somme</a> (more than 885,000 British soldiers died on the battlefields of the First World War)</div></div></div>\n<p>Britain fought alongside France, Russia and (after 1917) the United States, against Germany and its allies in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_World_War" title="First World War">First World War</a> (1914&#8211;1918).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[108]</a></sup> British armed forces were engaged across much of the British Empire and in several regions of Europe, particularly on the <a href="/wiki/Western_Front_(World_War_I)" title="Western Front (World War I)">Western front</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Westwell&amp;Cove_121-0"><a href="#cite_note-Westwell&amp;Cove-121">[109]</a></sup> The high fatalities of trench warfare caused the loss of much of a generation of men, with lasting social effects in the nation and a great disruption in the social order.\n</p><p>After the war, Britain received the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a> mandate over a number of former German and <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman</a> colonies. The British Empire reached its greatest extent, covering a fifth of the world\'s land surface and a quarter of its population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[110]</a></sup> However, Britain had suffered 2.5 million casualties and finished the war with a huge national debt.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Westwell&amp;Cove_121-1"><a href="#cite_note-Westwell&amp;Cove-121">[109]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Irish_independence">Irish independence</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Irish_Treaty" title="Anglo-Irish Treaty">Anglo-Irish Treaty</a></div>\n<p>The rise of <a href="/wiki/Irish_nationalism" title="Irish nationalism">Irish nationalism</a>, and disputes within Ireland over the terms of <a href="/wiki/Irish_Home_Rule_movement" title="Irish Home Rule movement">Irish Home Rule</a>, led eventually to the <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_Ireland" title="Partition of Ireland">partition of the island</a> in 1921.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[111]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Irish_Free_State" title="Irish Free State">Irish Free State</a> became independent, initially with <a href="/wiki/Dominion" title="Dominion">Dominion status</a> in 1922, and <a href="/wiki/Statute_of_Westminster_1931#Irish_Free_State" title="Statute of Westminster 1931">unambiguously independent in 1931</a>. Northern Ireland remained part of the United Kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CAIN_124-0"><a href="#cite_note-CAIN-124">[112]</a></sup> A wave of strikes in the mid-1920s culminated in the <a href="/wiki/1926_United_Kingdom_general_strike" title="1926 United Kingdom general strike">General Strike of 1926</a>. Britain had still not recovered from the effects of the war when the <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Great Depression in the United Kingdom">Great Depression</a> (1929&#8211;1932) occurred. This led to considerable unemployment and hardship in the old industrial areas, as well as political and social unrest in the 1930s, with rising membership in communist and socialist parties. A coalition government was formed in 1931.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[113]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Britain entered the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Second_World_War" title="Second World War">Second World War</a> by declaring war on <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a> in 1939 after Germany had invaded Poland. <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Winston Churchill</a> became prime minister and head of a coalition government in 1940. Despite the defeat of its European allies in the first year of the war, Britain and its Empire continued the fight alone against Germany. In 1940, the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Air_Force" title="Royal Air Force">Royal Air Force</a> defeated the German <a href="/wiki/Luftwaffe" title="Luftwaffe">Luftwaffe</a> in a struggle for control of the skies in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Britain" title="Battle of Britain">Battle of Britain</a>. Urban areas suffered heavy bombing during <a href="/wiki/The_Blitz" title="The Blitz">the Blitz</a>. There were also eventual hard-fought victories in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Atlantic" title="Battle of the Atlantic">Battle of the Atlantic</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/North_Africa_campaign" title="North Africa campaign">North Africa campaign</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Burma_campaign" title="Burma campaign">Burma campaign</a>. British forces played an important role in the <a href="/wiki/Normandy_landings" title="Normandy landings">Normandy landings</a> of 1944, achieved with its United States ally.\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Since_the_Second_World_War">Since the Second World War</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Political_history_of_the_United_Kingdom_(1945%E2%80%93present)" title="Political history of the United Kingdom (1945&#8211;present)">Political history of the United Kingdom (1945&#8211;present)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Social_history_of_the_United_Kingdom_(1945%E2%80%93present)" title="Social history of the United Kingdom (1945&#8211;present)">Social history of the United Kingdom (1945&#8211;present)</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:362px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_British_Empire.png"><img alt="Map of the world. Canada, the eastern United States, countries in East Africa, India, most of Australasia and some other countries are highlighted in pink." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1400" data-file-width="2753" decoding="async" height="183" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/The_British_Empire.png/360px-The_British_Empire.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/The_British_Empire.png/540px-The_British_Empire.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/The_British_Empire.png/720px-The_British_Empire.png 2x" width="360"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_British_Empire.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map showing territories that were at one time part of the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a>, with the United Kingdom and its current <a href="/wiki/British_Overseas_Territories" title="British Overseas Territories">British Overseas Territories</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Crown_Dependencies" title="Crown Dependencies">Crown Dependencies</a> underlined in red</div></div></div>\n<p>After the end of the <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">Second World War</a> in 1945, the UK was one of the <a href="/wiki/Four_Policemen" title="Four Policemen">Big Four</a> powers (along with the U.S., the Soviet Union, and China) who met to plan the post-war world;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[114]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[115]</a></sup> it was an original signatory to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Declaration_of_the_United_Nations" title="Declaration of the United Nations">Declaration of the United Nations</a>. The UK became one of the five permanent members of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a> and worked closely with the United States to establish the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/IMF" title="IMF">IMF</a>, <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a> and <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[116]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[117]</a></sup> However, the war left the UK severely weakened and depending financially on the <a href="/wiki/Marshall_Plan" title="Marshall Plan">Marshall Plan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[118]</a></sup> In the immediate post-war years, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Labour_Government_1945%E2%80%931951" title="Labour Government 1945&#8211;1951">Labour government</a> initiated a radical programme of reforms, which had a significant effect on British society in the following decades.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[119]</a></sup> Major industries and public utilities were <a href="/wiki/Nationalization" title="Nationalization">nationalised</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Welfare_state" title="Welfare state">welfare state</a> was established, and a comprehensive, publicly funded healthcare system, the <a href="/wiki/National_Health_Service" title="National Health Service">National Health Service</a>, was created.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[120]</a></sup> The rise of nationalism in the colonies coincided with Britain\'s now much-diminished economic position, so that a policy of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Decolonisation" title="Decolonisation">decolonisation</a> was unavoidable. Independence was granted to <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> in 1947.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[121]</a></sup> Over the next three decades, most colonies of the British Empire gained their independence. Many became members of the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">Commonwealth of Nations</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[122]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The UK was the third country to develop <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapons_and_the_United_Kingdom" title="Nuclear weapons and the United Kingdom">a nuclear weapons arsenal</a> (with its <a href="/wiki/Operation_Hurricane" title="Operation Hurricane">first atomic bomb test</a> in 1952), but the new post-war limits of Britain\'s international role were illustrated by the <a href="/wiki/Suez_Crisis" title="Suez Crisis">Suez Crisis</a> of 1956. The international spread of the English language ensured the continuing international influence of its <a href="/wiki/British_literature" title="British literature">literature</a> and <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Culture of the United Kingdom">culture</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-culture_135-0"><a href="#cite_note-culture-135">[123]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sheridan_136-0"><a href="#cite_note-sheridan-136">[124]</a></sup> As a result of a shortage of workers in the 1950s, the government encouraged immigration from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Commonwealth_countries" title="Commonwealth countries">Commonwealth countries</a>. In the following decades, the UK became a more multi-ethnic society than before.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[125]</a></sup> Despite rising living standards in the late 1950s and 1960s, the UK\'s economic performance was less successful than many of its main competitors such as France, <a href="/wiki/West_Germany" title="West Germany">West Germany</a> and Japan.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_(081).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="310" data-file-width="521" decoding="async" height="131" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg/220px-Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg/330px-Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg/440px-Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_(081).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Leaders of member states of the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> in 2007. The UK entered the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">European Economic Community</a> in 1973. In a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_European_Communities_membership_referendum,_1975" title="United Kingdom European Communities membership referendum, 1975">referendum held in 1975</a>, 67% of voters voted to remain in the EEC,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[126]</a></sup> but 52% voted to leave the EU in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[127]</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>In the decade-long process of <a href="/wiki/European_integration" title="European integration">European integration</a>, the UK was a founding member of the alliance called the <a href="/wiki/Western_European_Union" title="Western European Union">Western European Union</a>, established with the <a href="/wiki/London_and_Paris_Conferences" title="London and Paris Conferences">London and Paris Conferences</a> in 1954. In 1960 the UK was one of the seven founding members of the <a href="/wiki/European_Free_Trade_Association" title="European Free Trade Association">European Free Trade Association</a> (EFTA), but in 1973 it left to join the <a href="/wiki/European_Communities" title="European Communities">European Communities</a> (EC). When the EC became the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> (EU) in 1992, the UK was one of the 12 founding members. The <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lisbon" title="Treaty of Lisbon">Treaty of Lisbon</a> was signed in 2007, which forms the constitutional basis of the European Union since then.\n</p><p>From the late 1960s, Northern Ireland suffered communal and paramilitary violence (sometimes affecting other parts of the UK) conventionally known as <a href="/wiki/The_Troubles" title="The Troubles">the Troubles</a>. It is usually considered to have ended with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Belfast_Agreement" title="Belfast Agreement">Belfast "Good Friday" Agreement</a> of 1998.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[128]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hope_141-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hope-141">[129]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[130]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Following a period of widespread economic slowdown and industrial strife in the 1970s, the <a href="/wiki/Premiership_of_Margaret_Thatcher" title="Premiership of Margaret Thatcher">Conservative government of the 1980s</a> under <a href="/wiki/Margaret_Thatcher" title="Margaret Thatcher">Margaret Thatcher</a> initiated a radical policy of <a href="/wiki/Monetarism" title="Monetarism">monetarism</a>, deregulation, particularly of the financial sector (for example, <a href="/wiki/Big_Bang_(financial_markets)" title="Big Bang (financial markets)">Big Bang</a> in 1986) and labour markets, the sale of state-owned companies (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Privatisation" title="Privatisation">privatisation</a>), and the withdrawal of subsidies to others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[131]</a></sup> This resulted in high unemployment and social unrest, but ultimately also economic growth, particularly in the services sector. From 1984, the economy was helped by the inflow of substantial <a href="/wiki/North_Sea_oil" title="North Sea oil">North Sea oil</a> revenues.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[132]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Around the end of the 20th century there were major changes to the governance of the UK with the establishment of <a href="/wiki/Devolution" title="Devolution">devolved</a> administrations for Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[133]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Human_Rights_Act_1998" title="Human Rights Act 1998">statutory incorporation</a> followed acceptance of the <a href="/wiki/European_Convention_on_Human_Rights" title="European Convention on Human Rights">European Convention on Human Rights</a>. The UK is still a key global player diplomatically and militarily. It plays leading roles in the EU, UN and <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>. However, controversy surrounds some of Britain\'s overseas <a href="/wiki/Military_deployment" title="Military deployment">military deployments</a>, particularly in <a href="/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%93present)" title="War in Afghanistan (2001&#8211;present)">Afghanistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Iraq_War" title="Iraq War">Iraq</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[134]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2008_global_financial_crisis" title="2008 global financial crisis">2008 global financial crisis</a> severely affected the UK economy. The <a href="/wiki/Cameron%E2%80%93Clegg_coalition" title="Cameron&#8211;Clegg coalition">coalition government</a> of 2010 introduced austerity measures intended to tackle the substantial public deficits which resulted.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[135]</a></sup> In 2014 the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Government" title="Scottish Government">Scottish Government</a> held a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scottish_independence_referendum,_2014" title="Scottish independence referendum, 2014">referendum on Scottish independence</a>, with 55.3% of voters rejecting the independence proposal and opting to remain within the United Kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_148-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC-148">[136]</a></sup> In 2016, 51.9% of voters in the United Kingdom <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_European_Union_membership_referendum,_2016" title="United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016">voted to leave the European Union</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Washington_Post_149-0"><a href="#cite_note-Washington_Post-149">[137]</a></sup> The legal process of leaving the EU began on 29 March 2017, with the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_invocation_of_Article_50_of_the_Treaty_on_European_Union" title="United Kingdom invocation of Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union">UK\'s invocation of Article 50</a> of the Treaty of Lisbon, formally notifying the EU of the UK\'s intention to leave. The article stipulates that the negotiations to leave will last at least two years. The UK remains a full member of the EU during this time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[138]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Adler_151-0"><a href="#cite_note-Adler-151">[139]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Geography of the United Kingdom">Geography of the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Uk_topo_en.jpg"><img alt="Map of United Kingdom showing hilly regions to north and west, and flattest region in the south-east." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3089" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="263" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Uk_topo_en.jpg/170px-Uk_topo_en.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Uk_topo_en.jpg/255px-Uk_topo_en.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Uk_topo_en.jpg/340px-Uk_topo_en.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Uk_topo_en.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The topography of the UK</div></div></div>\n<p>The total area of the United Kingdom is approximately 243,610 square kilometres (94,060&#160;sq&#160;mi). The country occupies the major part of the <a href="/wiki/British_Isles" title="British Isles">British Isles</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[140]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Archipelago" title="Archipelago">archipelago</a> and includes the island of Great Britain, the north-eastern one-sixth of the island of Ireland and some smaller surrounding islands.
