It lies between the North Atlantic Ocean and the North Sea with the south-east coast coming within 22 miles (35&#160;km) of the coast of northern France, from which it is separated by the <a href="/wiki/English_Channel" title="English Channel">English Channel</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-factbook_153-0"><a href="#cite_note-factbook-153">[141]</a></sup> In 1993 10% of the UK was forested, 46% used for pastures and 25% cultivated for agriculture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Atlapedia_154-0"><a href="#cite_note-Atlapedia-154">[142]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Royal_Observatory,_Greenwich" title="Royal Observatory, Greenwich">Royal Greenwich Observatory</a> in London was chosen as the defining point of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prime_Meridian" title="Prime Meridian">Prime Meridian</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[143]</a></sup> in <a href="/wiki/International_Meridian_Conference" title="International Meridian Conference">Washington in 1884</a>, though it no longer is.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156"><a href="#cite_note-156">[144]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The United Kingdom lies between latitudes <a href="/wiki/49th_parallel_north" title="49th parallel north">49&#176;</a> and <a href="/wiki/61st_parallel_north" title="61st parallel north">61&#176; N</a>, and longitudes <a href="/wiki/9th_meridian_west" title="9th meridian west">9&#176; W</a> and <a href="/wiki/2nd_meridian_east" title="2nd meridian east">2&#176; E</a>. Northern Ireland shares a 224-mile (360&#160;km) land boundary with the Republic of Ireland.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-factbook_153-1"><a href="#cite_note-factbook-153">[141]</a></sup> The coastline of Great Britain is 11,073 miles (17,820&#160;km) long.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UK_coastline_157-0"><a href="#cite_note-UK_coastline-157">[145]</a></sup> It is connected to <a href="/wiki/Continental_Europe" title="Continental Europe">continental Europe</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Channel_Tunnel" title="Channel Tunnel">Channel Tunnel</a>, which at 31 miles (50&#160;km) (24 miles (38&#160;km) underwater) is the longest underwater tunnel in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158">[146]</a></sup>\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Geography_of_England" title="Geography of England">England</a> accounts for just over half (53%) of the total area of the UK, covering 130,395 square kilometres (50,350&#160;sq&#160;mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159"><a href="#cite_note-159">[147]</a></sup> Most of the country consists of lowland terrain,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Atlapedia_154-1"><a href="#cite_note-Atlapedia-154">[142]</a></sup> with mountainous terrain north-west of the <a href="/wiki/Tees-Exe_line" title="Tees-Exe line">Tees-Exe line</a>; including the <a href="/wiki/Lake_District" title="Lake District">Cumbrian Mountains</a> of the Lake District, the <a href="/wiki/Pennines" title="Pennines">Pennines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Exmoor" title="Exmoor">Exmoor</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dartmoor" title="Dartmoor">Dartmoor</a>. The main rivers and estuaries are the <a href="/wiki/River_Thames" title="River Thames">Thames</a>, <a href="/wiki/River_Severn" title="River Severn">Severn</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Humber" title="Humber">Humber</a>. England\'s highest mountain is <a href="/wiki/Scafell_Pike" title="Scafell Pike">Scafell Pike</a> (978 metres (3,209&#160;ft)) in the <a href="/wiki/Lake_District" title="Lake District">Lake District</a>.\n</p>\n<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r856303569">@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti>.thumbinner{width:100%!important;max-width:none!important}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:none!important;width:100%!important;text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:229px;max-width:229px"><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:227px;max-width:227px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Keswick_Panorama_-_Oct_2009.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3822" data-file-width="10814" decoding="async" height="80" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Keswick_Panorama_-_Oct_2009.jpg/225px-Keswick_Panorama_-_Oct_2009.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Keswick_Panorama_-_Oct_2009.jpg/338px-Keswick_Panorama_-_Oct_2009.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Keswick_Panorama_-_Oct_2009.jpg/450px-Keswick_Panorama_-_Oct_2009.jpg 2x" width="225"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">The <a href="/wiki/Skiddaw" title="Skiddaw">Skiddaw massif</a>, town of <a href="/wiki/Keswick,_Cumbria" title="Keswick, Cumbria">Keswick</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Derwent_Water" title="Derwent Water">Derwent Water</a> in <a href="/wiki/Lake_District" title="Lake District">Lakeland</a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:227px;max-width:227px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Quiraing_Isle_of_Skye_Pano.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2123" data-file-width="5596" decoding="async" height="85" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Quiraing_Isle_of_Skye_Pano.jpg/225px-Quiraing_Isle_of_Skye_Pano.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Quiraing_Isle_of_Skye_Pano.jpg/338px-Quiraing_Isle_of_Skye_Pano.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Quiraing_Isle_of_Skye_Pano.jpg/450px-Quiraing_Isle_of_Skye_Pano.jpg 2x" width="225"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Isle_of_Skye" title="Isle of Skye">Skye</a> is one of the major islands in the <a href="/wiki/Inner_Hebrides" title="Inner Hebrides">Inner Hebrides</a> and part of the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Highlands" title="Scottish Highlands">Scottish Highlands</a></div></div></div></div>\n<p><a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Scotland" title="Geography of Scotland">Scotland</a> accounts for just under a third (32%) of the total area of the UK, covering 78,772 square kilometres (30,410&#160;sq&#160;mi)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[148]</a></sup> and including nearly eight hundred <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Scotland" title="List of islands of Scotland">islands</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[149]</a></sup> predominantly west and north of the mainland; notably the <a href="/wiki/Hebrides" title="Hebrides">Hebrides</a>, <a href="/wiki/Orkney" title="Orkney">Orkney Islands</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shetland" title="Shetland">Shetland Islands</a>. Scotland is the most mountainous country in the UK and its topography is distinguished by the <a href="/wiki/Highland_Boundary_Fault" title="Highland Boundary Fault">Highland Boundary Fault</a>&#8212;a <a href="/wiki/Fault_(geology)" title="Fault (geology)">geological rock fracture</a>&#8212;which traverses Scotland from <a href="/wiki/Isle_of_Arran" title="Isle of Arran">Arran</a> in the west to <a href="/wiki/Stonehaven" title="Stonehaven">Stonehaven</a> in the east.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[150]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Fault_(geology)" title="Fault (geology)">fault</a> separates two distinctively different regions; namely the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Highlands" title="Scottish Highlands">Highlands</a> to the north and west and the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Lowlands" title="Scottish Lowlands">lowlands</a> to the south and east. The more rugged Highland region contains the majority of Scotland\'s mountainous land, including <a href="/wiki/Ben_Nevis" title="Ben Nevis">Ben Nevis</a> which at 1,345 metres (4,413&#160;ft)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OS_revision_163-0"><a href="#cite_note-OS_revision-163">[151]</a></sup> is the highest point in the British Isles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[152]</a></sup> Lowland areas&#8212;especially the narrow waist of land between the <a href="/wiki/Firth_of_Clyde" title="Firth of Clyde">Firth of Clyde</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Firth_of_Forth" title="Firth of Forth">Firth of Forth</a> known as the <a href="/wiki/Central_Lowlands" title="Central Lowlands">Central Belt</a>&#8212;are flatter and home to most of the population including <a href="/wiki/Glasgow" title="Glasgow">Glasgow</a>, Scotland\'s largest city, and <a href="/wiki/Edinburgh" title="Edinburgh">Edinburgh</a>, its capital and political centre, although upland and mountainous terrain lies within the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Uplands" title="Southern Uplands">Southern Uplands</a>.\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Wales" title="Geography of Wales">Wales</a> accounts for less than a tenth (9%) of the total area of the UK, covering 20,779 square kilometres (8,020&#160;sq&#160;mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[153]</a></sup> Wales is mostly mountainous, though <a href="/wiki/South_Wales" title="South Wales">South Wales</a> is less mountainous than <a href="/wiki/North_Wales" title="North Wales">North</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mid_Wales" title="Mid Wales">mid Wales</a>. The main population and industrial areas are in South Wales, consisting of the coastal cities of <a href="/wiki/Cardiff" title="Cardiff">Cardiff</a>, <a href="/wiki/Swansea" title="Swansea">Swansea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Newport,_Wales" title="Newport, Wales">Newport</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/South_Wales_Valleys" title="South Wales Valleys">South Wales Valleys</a> to their north. The highest mountains in Wales are in <a href="/wiki/Snowdonia" title="Snowdonia">Snowdonia</a> and include <a href="/wiki/Snowdon" title="Snowdon">Snowdon</a> (<a href="/wiki/Welsh_language" title="Welsh language">Welsh</a>: <i lang="cy">Yr Wyddfa</i>) which, at 1,085 metres (3,560&#160;ft), is the highest peak in Wales.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Atlapedia_154-2"><a href="#cite_note-Atlapedia-154">[142]</a></sup> Wales has over 2,704 kilometres (1,680 miles) of coastline.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UK_coastline_157-1"><a href="#cite_note-UK_coastline-157">[145]</a></sup> Several islands lie off the Welsh mainland, the largest of which is <a href="/wiki/Anglesey" title="Anglesey">Anglesey</a> (<i>Ynys M&#244;n</i>) in the north-west.\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Ireland" title="Geography of Ireland">Northern Ireland</a>, separated from Great Britain by the <a href="/wiki/Irish_Sea" title="Irish Sea">Irish Sea</a> and <a href="/wiki/North_Channel_(Great_Britain_and_Ireland)" title="North Channel (Great Britain and Ireland)">North Channel</a>, has an area of 14,160 square kilometres (5,470&#160;sq&#160;mi) and is mostly hilly. It includes <a href="/wiki/Lough_Neagh" title="Lough Neagh">Lough Neagh</a> which, at 388 square kilometres (150&#160;sq&#160;mi), is the largest lake in the British Isles by area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[154]</a></sup> The highest peak in Northern Ireland is <a href="/wiki/Slieve_Donard" title="Slieve Donard">Slieve Donard</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Mourne_Mountains" title="Mourne Mountains">Mourne Mountains</a> at 852 metres (2,795&#160;ft).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Atlapedia_154-3"><a href="#cite_note-Atlapedia-154">[142]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Climate of the United Kingdom">Climate of the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<p>The United Kingdom has a temperate climate, with plentiful rainfall all year round.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-factbook_153-2"><a href="#cite_note-factbook-153">[141]</a></sup> The temperature varies with the seasons seldom dropping below &#8722;11&#160;<a href="/wiki/Celsius" title="Celsius">&#176;C</a> (12&#160;<a href="/wiki/Fahrenheit" title="Fahrenheit">&#176;F</a>) or rising above 35&#160;&#176;C (95&#160;&#176;F).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[155]</a></sup> The prevailing wind is from the south-west and bears frequent spells of mild and wet weather from the Atlantic Ocean,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-factbook_153-3"><a href="#cite_note-factbook-153">[141]</a></sup> although the eastern parts are mostly sheltered from this wind since the majority of the rain falls over the western regions the eastern parts are therefore the driest. Atlantic currents, warmed by the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_Stream" title="Gulf Stream">Gulf Stream</a>, bring mild winters;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[156]</a></sup> especially in the west where winters are wet and even more so over high ground. Summers are warmest in the south-east of England, being closest to the European mainland, and coolest in the north. Heavy snowfall can occur in winter and early spring on high ground, and occasionally settles to great depth away from the hills.\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px"><div class="thumbimage noresize" style="width:250px;"><div style="text-align: center;"><div class="noresize" role="img" style="width: 250px; line-height: 1; text-align: center; background-color: #ffffff; position: relative;"><img alt="" data-file-height="1313" data-file-width="759" decoding="async" height="432" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/United_Kingdom_countries.svg/250px-United_Kingdom_countries.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/United_Kingdom_countries.svg/375px-United_Kingdom_countries.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/United_Kingdom_countries.svg/500px-United_Kingdom_countries.svg.png 2x" width="250"/>\n<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:150.25px; top:292px"><big><a href="/wiki/England" title="England">England</a></big></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:87.75px; top:167px"><big><a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a></big></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:94px; top:317px"><big><a href="/wiki/Wales" title="Wales">Wales</a></big></div>\n<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:31.5px; top:229.5px"><big><a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland" title="Northern Ireland">Northern<br/>Ireland</a></big></div>\n</div></div></div><div class="thumbcaption">The four <a href="/wiki/Countries_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Countries of the United Kingdom">countries of the United Kingdom</a></div></div></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_geography_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Administrative geography of the United Kingdom">Administrative geography of the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<p>The geographical division of the United Kingdom into <a href="/wiki/Counties_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Counties of the United Kingdom">counties</a> or shires began in England and Scotland in the early Middle Ages and was complete throughout Great Britain and Ireland by the early Modern Period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[157]</a></sup> Administrative arrangements were developed separately in each country of the United Kingdom, with origins which often pre-dated the formation of the United Kingdom. Modern local government by elected councils, partly based on the ancient counties, was introduced separately: in England and Wales in a <a href="/wiki/Local_Government_Act_1888" title="Local Government Act 1888">1888 act</a>, Scotland in a <a href="/wiki/Local_Government_(Scotland)_Act_1889" title="Local Government (Scotland) Act 1889">1889 act</a> and Ireland in a <a href="/wiki/Local_Government_(Ireland)_Act_1898" title="Local Government (Ireland) Act 1898">1898 act</a>, meaning there is no consistent system of administrative or geographic demarcation across the United Kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN_170-0"><a href="#cite_note-UN-170">[158]</a></sup>\nUntil the 19th century there was little change to those arrangements, but there has since been a constant evolution of role and function.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-barlow_171-0"><a href="#cite_note-barlow-171">[159]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The organisation of <a href="/wiki/Local_government_in_England" title="Local government in England">local government in England</a> is complex, with the distribution of functions varying according to local arrangements. The upper-tier <a href="/wiki/Subdivisions_of_England" title="Subdivisions of England">subdivisions of England</a> are the nine <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_England" title="Regions of England">regions</a>, now used primarily for statistical purposes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[160]</a></sup> One region, <a href="/wiki/Greater_London_Authority" title="Greater London Authority">Greater London</a>, has had a directly elected assembly and mayor since 2000 following popular support for the proposal in a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greater_London_Authority_referendum,_1998" title="Greater London Authority referendum, 1998">referendum</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[161]</a></sup> It was intended that other regions would also be given their own elected <a href="/wiki/Regional_assembly_(England)" title="Regional assembly (England)">regional assemblies</a>, but a proposed assembly in the <a href="/wiki/North_East_England" title="North East England">North East</a> region was rejected by a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northern_England_devolution_referendums,_2004" title="Northern England devolution referendums, 2004">referendum in 2004</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[162]</a></sup> Below the regional tier, some parts of England have <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_and_non-metropolitan_counties_of_England" title="Metropolitan and non-metropolitan counties of England">county councils</a> and district councils and others have <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unitary_authorities" title="Unitary authorities">unitary authorities</a>; while London consists of 32 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/London_borough" title="London borough">London boroughs</a> and the <a href="/wiki/City_of_London" title="City of London">City of London</a>. Councillors are elected by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Plurality_voting_system" title="Plurality voting system">first-past-the-post</a> system in single-member wards or by the <a href="/wiki/Plurality-at-large_voting" title="Plurality-at-large voting">multi-member plurality system</a> in multi-member wards.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[163]</a></sup>\n</p><p>For <a href="/wiki/Local_government_in_Scotland" title="Local government in Scotland">local government purposes</a>, Scotland is divided into <a href="/wiki/Subdivisions_of_Scotland" title="Subdivisions of Scotland">32 council areas</a>, with wide variation in both size and population. The cities of <a href="/wiki/Glasgow" title="Glasgow">Glasgow</a>, Edinburgh, <a href="/wiki/Aberdeen" title="Aberdeen">Aberdeen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dundee" title="Dundee">Dundee</a> are separate council areas, as is the <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_the_Highland_council_area" title="Politics of the Highland council area">Highland Council</a>, which includes a third of Scotland\'s area but only just over 200,000&#160;people. Local councils are made up of elected councillors, of whom there are 1,223;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[164]</a></sup> they are paid a part-time salary. Elections are conducted by <a href="/wiki/Single_transferable_vote" title="Single transferable vote">single transferable vote</a> in multi-member wards that elect either three or four councillors. Each council elects a <a href="/wiki/Provost_(civil)" title="Provost (civil)">Provost</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Chairman" title="Chairman">Convenor</a>, to chair meetings of the council and to act as a figurehead for the area.\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Local_government_in_Wales" title="Local government in Wales">Local government in Wales</a> consists of 22 unitary authorities. These include the cities of Cardiff, Swansea and Newport, which are unitary authorities in their own right.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-unitary_177-0"><a href="#cite_note-unitary-177">[165]</a></sup> Elections are held every four years under the first-past-the-post system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-unitary_177-1"><a href="#cite_note-unitary-177">[165]</a></sup>\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Local_government_in_Northern_Ireland" title="Local government in Northern Ireland">Local government in Northern Ireland</a> has since 1973 been organised into 26 district councils, each elected by single transferable vote. Their powers are limited to services such as collecting waste, controlling dogs and maintaining parks and cemeteries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[166]</a></sup> In 2008 the executive agreed on proposals to create 11 new councils and replace the present system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[167]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Dependencies">Dependencies</span></h2>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/British_Overseas_Territories" title="British Overseas Territories">British Overseas Territories</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crown_dependencies" title="Crown dependencies">Crown dependencies</a>, <a href="/wiki/British_Islands" title="British Islands">British Islands</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_current_heads_of_government_in_the_United_Kingdom_and_dependencies#Crown_dependencies" title="List of current heads of government in the United Kingdom and dependencies">List of leaders of British dependencies</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cap_Juluca_-_Anguilla.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="188" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Cap_Juluca_-_Anguilla.jpg/250px-Cap_Juluca_-_Anguilla.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Cap_Juluca_-_Anguilla.jpg/375px-Cap_Juluca_-_Anguilla.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Cap_Juluca_-_Anguilla.jpg/500px-Cap_Juluca_-_Anguilla.jpg 2x" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cap_Juluca_-_Anguilla.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Anguilla" title="Anguilla">Anguilla</a>: Cap Juluca, Maundays Bay</div></div></div>\n<p>The United Kingdom has sovereignty over seventeen territories which do not form part of the United Kingdom itself: fourteen British Overseas Territories<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-overseasterrirories_36-1"><a href="#cite_note-overseasterrirories-36">[25]</a></sup> and three Crown dependencies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-overseasterrirories_36-2"><a href="#cite_note-overseasterrirories-36">[25]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[168]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The fourteen British Overseas Territories are: <a href="/wiki/Anguilla" title="Anguilla">Anguilla</a>; <a href="/wiki/Bermuda" title="Bermuda">Bermuda</a>; the <a href="/wiki/British_Antarctic_Territory" title="British Antarctic Territory">British Antarctic Territory</a>; the <a href="/wiki/British_Indian_Ocean_Territory" title="British Indian Ocean Territory">British Indian Ocean Territory</a>; the <a href="/wiki/British_Virgin_Islands" title="British Virgin Islands">British Virgin Islands</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Cayman_Islands" title="Cayman Islands">Cayman Islands</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Falkland_Islands" title="Falkland Islands">Falkland Islands</a>; <a href="/wiki/Gibraltar" title="Gibraltar">Gibraltar</a>; <a href="/wiki/Montserrat" title="Montserrat">Montserrat</a>; <a href="/wiki/Saint_Helena,_Ascension_and_Tristan_da_Cunha" title="Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha">Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Turks_and_Caicos_Islands" title="Turks and Caicos Islands">Turks and Caicos Islands</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Pitcairn_Islands" title="Pitcairn Islands">Pitcairn Islands</a>; <a href="/wiki/South_Georgia_and_the_South_Sandwich_Islands" title="South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands">South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Akrotiri_and_Dhekelia" title="Akrotiri and Dhekelia">Akrotiri and Dhekelia</a> on the island of <a href="/wiki/Cyprus" title="Cyprus">Cyprus</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[169]</a></sup> British claims in Antarctica are not universally recognised, mainly by Argentina, whose claims cover a majority of the British sector.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[170]</a></sup> Collectively Britain\'s overseas territories encompass an approximate land area of 1,727,570 square kilometres (667,018&#160;sq&#160;mi) and a population of approximately 260,000 people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[171]</a></sup>\n</p><p>They are the last remaining remnants of the British Empire and a 1999 UK government <a href="/wiki/White_paper" title="White paper">white paper</a> stated that: "[The] Overseas Territories are British for as long as they wish to remain British. Britain has willingly granted independence where it has been requested; and we will continue to do so where this is an option."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[172]</a></sup> Self-determination is also enshrined into the constitutions of several overseas territories and three have specifically voted to remain under British sovereignty (Bermuda in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bermudan_independence_referendum,_1995" title="Bermudan independence referendum, 1995">1995</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Independent_results_185-0"><a href="#cite_note-Independent_results-185">[173]</a></sup> Gibraltar in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gibraltar_sovereignty_referendum,_2002" title="Gibraltar sovereignty referendum, 2002">2002</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[174]</a></sup> and the Falkland Islands in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Falkland_Islands_sovereignty_referendum,_2013" title="Falkland Islands sovereignty referendum, 2013">2013</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[175]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The Crown dependencies are possessions of <a href="/wiki/The_Crown" title="The Crown">the Crown</a>, as opposed to overseas territories of the UK.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[176]</a></sup> They comprise three independently administered jurisdictions: the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Channel_Island" title="Channel Island">Channel Islands</a> of <a href="/wiki/Jersey" title="Jersey">Jersey</a> and <a href="/wiki/Guernsey" title="Guernsey">Guernsey</a> in the English Channel, and the <a href="/wiki/Isle_of_Man" title="Isle of Man">Isle of Man</a> in the Irish Sea. By mutual agreement, the British Government manages the islands\' foreign affairs and defence and the UK Parliament has the authority to legislate on their behalf. However, internationally, they are regarded as "territories for which the United Kingdom is responsible".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-International_recognition_189-0"><a href="#cite_note-International_recognition-189">[177]</a></sup> The power to pass legislation affecting the islands ultimately rests with their own respective legislative assemblies, with the assent of the Crown (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Her_Majesty%27s_Most_Honourable_Privy_Council" title="Her Majesty\'s Most Honourable Privy Council">Privy Council</a> or, in the case of the Isle of Man, in certain circumstances the Lieutenant-Governor).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[178]</a></sup> Since 2005 each Crown dependency has had a <a href="/wiki/List_of_current_heads_of_government_in_the_United_Kingdom_and_dependencies#Crown_dependencies" title="List of current heads of government in the United Kingdom and dependencies">Chief Minister</a> as its <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[179]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The British dependencies use a varied assortment of currencies. These include the British pound, US dollar, New Zealand dollar, euro or <a href="/wiki/List_of_British_currencies" title="List of British currencies">their own currencies, which may be pegged to either</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>\n</p>\n<div class="center"><div class="thumb tnone"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:802px;"><div class="noresize"><map name="ImageMap_1_643983063"><area alt="Akrotiri and Dhekelia" coords="453,92,521,140" href="/wiki/Akrotiri_and_Dhekelia" shape="rect" title="Akrotiri and Dhekelia"/><area alt="Akrotiri and Dhekelia" coords="443,148,446,151" href="/wiki/Akrotiri_and_Dhekelia" shape="rect" title="Akrotiri and Dhekelia"/><area alt="Gibraltar" coords="365,145,369,149" href="/wiki/Gibraltar" shape="rect" coords="286,410,296,411,300,421,303,431,335,440,357,444,372,489,316,489,302,475,273,447,275,419" href="/wiki/British_Antarctic_Territory" shape="poly" title="British Antarctic Territory"/><area alt="Isle of Man" coords="370,95,372,97" href="/wiki/Isle_of_Man" shape="rect" title="Isle of Man"/></map><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1964" data-file-width="3188" decoding="async" href="/wiki/File:United_Kingdom_(overseas%2Bcrown_dependencies),_administrative_divisions_-_Nmbrs_(multiple_zoom).svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Locations of UK dependencies (crown dependencies alphabetised, overseas territories numbered): <b>A</b> <a href="/wiki/Isle_of_Man" title="Isle of Man">Isle of Man</a>; <b>B</b> <a href="/wiki/Guernsey" title="Guernsey">Guernsey</a>; <b>C</b> <a href="/wiki/Jersey" title="Jersey">Jersey</a>; <b>1</b> United Kingdom; <b>2</b> <a href="/wiki/Gibraltar" title="Gibraltar">Gibraltar</a>; <b>3</b> <a href="/wiki/Akrotiri_and_Dhekelia" title="Akrotiri and Dhekelia">Akrotiri and Dhekelia</a>; <b>4</b> <a href="/wiki/Bermuda" title="Bermuda">Bermuda</a>; <b>5</b> <a href="/wiki/Turks_and_Caicos_Islands" title="Turks and Caicos Islands">Turks and Caicos Islands</a>; <b>6</b> <a href="/wiki/British_Virgin_Islands" title="British Virgin Islands">British Virgin Islands</a>; <b>7</b> <a href="/wiki/Anguilla" title="Anguilla">Anguilla</a>; <b>8</b> <a href="/wiki/Cayman_Islands" title="Cayman Islands">Cayman Islands</a>; <b>9</b> <a href="/wiki/Montserrat" title="Montserrat">Montserrat</a>; <b>10</b> <a href="/wiki/Pitcairn_Islands" title="Pitcairn Islands">Pitcairn Islands</a>; <b>11</b> <a href="/wiki/Saint_Helena,_Ascension_and_Tristan_da_Cunha" title="Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha">Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha</a>; <b>12</b> <a href="/wiki/British_Indian_Ocean_Territory" title="British Indian Ocean Territory">British Indian Ocean Territory</a>; <b>13</b> <a href="/wiki/Falkland_Islands" title="Falkland Islands">Falkland Islands</a>; <b>14</b> <a href="/wiki/South_Georgia_and_the_South_Sandwich_Islands" title="South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands">South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands</a>; <b>(15)</b> <a href="/wiki/British_Antarctic_Territory" title="British Antarctic Territory">British Antarctic Territory</a></div></div></div></div>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h2>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Politics of the United Kingdom">Politics of the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:305px;max-width:305px"><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:151px;max-width:151px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Queen_Elizabeth_II_in_March_2015.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2242" data-file-width="1698" decoding="async" height="197" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Queen_Elizabeth_II_in_March_2015.jpg/149px-Queen_Elizabeth_II_in_March_2015.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Queen_Elizabeth_II_in_March_2015.jpg/224px-Queen_Elizabeth_II_in_March_2015.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Queen_Elizabeth_II_in_March_2015.jpg/298px-Queen_Elizabeth_II_in_March_2015.jpg 2x" width="149"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Queen_Elizabeth_II" title="Queen Elizabeth II">Queen Elizabeth II</a>, Monarch since 1952</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:150px;max-width:150px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Theresa_May_UK_Home_Office_(cropped).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2112" data-file-width="1584" decoding="async" height="197" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Theresa_May_UK_Home_Office_%28cropped%29.jpg/148px-Theresa_May_UK_Home_Office_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Theresa_May_UK_Home_Office_%28cropped%29.jpg/222px-Theresa_May_UK_Home_Office_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/Theresa_May_UK_Home_Office_%28cropped%29.jpg/296px-Theresa_May_UK_Home_Office_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="148"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Theresa_May" title="Theresa May">Theresa May</a>, Prime Minister since 2016</div></div><div style="clear:left"></div></div></div>\n<p>The United Kingdom is a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary state</a> under a <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Queen_Elizabeth_II" title="Queen Elizabeth II">Queen Elizabeth II</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Monarchy of the United Kingdom">monarch</a> and head of state of the UK, as well as fifteen other independent countries. These sixteen countries are sometimes referred to as "<a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_realm" title="Commonwealth realm">Commonwealth realms</a>". The monarch has "the right to be consulted, the right to encourage, and the right to warn".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[180]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Constitution of the United Kingdom">Constitution of the United Kingdom</a> is <a href="/wiki/Uncodified_constitution" title="Uncodified constitution">uncodified</a> and consists mostly of a collection of disparate written sources, including <a href="/wiki/Statute" title="Statute">statutes</a>, judge-made <a href="/wiki/Case_law" title="Case law">case law</a> and international treaties, together with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Constitution#Conventions" title="British Constitution">constitutional conventions</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[181]</a></sup> As there is no technical difference between ordinary statutes and "constitutional law", the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Parliament of the United Kingdom">UK Parliament</a> can perform "constitutional reform" simply by passing <a href="/wiki/Act_of_Parliament_(UK)" title="Act of Parliament (UK)">Acts of Parliament</a>, and thus has the political power to change or abolish almost any written or unwritten element of the constitution. However, no Parliament can pass laws that future Parliaments cannot change.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[182]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Government">Government</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Government_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Government of the United Kingdom">Government of the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<p>The UK has a <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">parliamentary government</a> based on the <a href="/wiki/Westminster_system" title="Westminster system">Westminster system</a> that has been emulated around the world: a legacy of the British Empire. The parliament of the United Kingdom meets in the <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_Westminster" title="Palace of Westminster">Palace of Westminster</a> and has two houses: an elected <a href="/wiki/House_of_Commons_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="House of Commons of the United Kingdom">House of Commons</a> and an appointed <a href="/wiki/House_of_Lords" title="House of Lords">House of Lords</a>. All bills passed are given <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Royal_Assent" title="Royal Assent">Royal Assent</a> before becoming law.\n</p><p>The position of <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Prime Minister of the United Kingdom">prime minister</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[note 13]</a></sup> the UK\'s <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[183]</a></sup> belongs to the person most likely to command the <a href="/wiki/Confidence_and_supply" title="Confidence and supply">confidence</a> of the House of Commons; this individual is typically the leader of the political party or coalition of parties that holds the largest number of seats in that chamber. The prime minister chooses a cabinet and its members are formally appointed by the monarch to form <a href="/wiki/Government_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Government of the United Kingdom">Her Majesty\'s Government</a>. By convention, the monarch respects the prime minister\'s decisions of government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-npm_197-0"><a href="#cite_note-npm-197">[184]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:London_Parliament_2007-1.jpg"><img alt="Large sand-coloured building of Gothic design beside brown river and road bridge. The building has several large towers, including large clock tower." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1826" data-file-width="5070" decoding="async" height="101" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/London_Parliament_2007-1.jpg/280px-London_Parliament_2007-1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/London_Parliament_2007-1.jpg/420px-London_Parliament_2007-1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/London_Parliament_2007-1.jpg/560px-London_Parliament_2007-1.jpg 2x" width="280"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:London_Parliament_2007-1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_Westminster" title="Palace of Westminster">Palace of Westminster</a>, seat of both houses of the Parliament of the United Kingdom</div></div></div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Cabinet of the United Kingdom">cabinet</a> is traditionally drawn from members of the prime minister\'s party or coalition and mostly from the House of Commons but always from both legislative houses, the cabinet being <a href="/wiki/Responsible_government" title="Responsible government">responsible</a> to both. Executive power is exercised by the prime minister and cabinet, all of whom are sworn into the <a href="/wiki/Privy_Council_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Privy Council of the United Kingdom">Privy Council of the United Kingdom</a>, and become <a href="/wiki/Minister_of_the_Crown" title="Minister of the Crown">Ministers of the Crown</a>. The current Prime Minister is <a href="/wiki/Theresa_May" title="Theresa May">Theresa May</a>, who has been in office since 13 July 2016. May is also the leader of the <a href="/wiki/Conservative_Party_(UK)" title="Conservative Party (UK)">Conservative Party</a>. For elections to the House of Commons, the UK is divided into <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_constituencies" title="United Kingdom constituencies">650 constituencies</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Elections_and_voting&#8212;UK_Parliament_198-0"><a href="#cite_note-Elections_and_voting&#8212;UK_Parliament-198">[185]</a></sup> each electing a single member of parliament (MP) by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Plurality_voting_system" title="Plurality voting system">simple plurality</a>. <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Elections in the United Kingdom">General elections</a> are called by the monarch when the prime minister so advises. Prior to the <a href="/wiki/Fixed-term_Parliaments_Act_2011" title="Fixed-term Parliaments Act 2011">Fixed-term Parliaments Act 2011</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_Acts_1911_and_1949" title="Parliament Acts 1911 and 1949">Parliament Acts 1911 and 1949</a> required that a new election must be called no later than five years after the previous general election.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Parliament_Acts&#8212;UK_Parliament_199-0"><a href="#cite_note-The_Parliament_Acts&#8212;UK_Parliament-199">[186]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The Conservative Party, the <a href="/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK)" title="Labour Party (UK)">Labour Party</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Liberal_Democrats_(UK)" title="Liberal Democrats (UK)">Liberal Democrats</a> (formerly as the <a href="/wiki/Liberal_Party_(UK)" title="Liberal Party (UK)">Liberal Party</a>) have, in modern times, been considered the UK\'s three <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_the_United_Kingdom#Major_parties_in_the_House_of_Commons" title="List of political parties in the United Kingdom">major political parties</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[187]</a></sup> representing the British traditions of <a href="/wiki/Conservatism_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Conservatism in the United Kingdom">conservatism</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Socialism_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Socialism in the United Kingdom">socialism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Liberalism_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Liberalism in the United Kingdom">liberalism</a>, respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[188]</a></sup> However, in both the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_general_election,_2015" title="United Kingdom general election, 2015">2015</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_general_election,_2017" title="United Kingdom general election, 2017">2017</a> general elections, the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_National_Party" title="Scottish National Party">Scottish National Party</a> was the third-largest party by number of seats won, ahead of the Liberal Democrats. Most of the remaining seats were won by parties that contest elections only in one part of the UK: <a href="/wiki/Plaid_Cymru" title="Plaid Cymru">Plaid Cymru</a> (Wales only); and the <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Unionist_Party" title="Democratic Unionist Party">Democratic Unionist Party</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sinn_F%C3%A9in" title="Sinn F&#233;in">Sinn F&#233;in</a> (Northern Ireland only<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[note 14]</a></sup>). In accordance with party policy, no elected Sinn F&#233;in members of parliament have ever attended the House of Commons to speak on behalf of their constituents because of the requirement to take an oath of allegiance to the monarch.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[189]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Devolved_administrations">Devolved administrations</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Devolution_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Devolution in the United Kingdom">Devolution in the United Kingdom</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_current_heads_of_government_in_the_United_Kingdom_and_dependencies#Countries_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="List of current heads of government in the United Kingdom and dependencies">List of leaders of devolved administrations</a>, <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Executive" title="Northern Ireland Executive">Northern Ireland Executive</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Government" title="Scottish Government">Scottish Government</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Welsh_Government" title="Welsh Government">Welsh Government</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Scottish_Parliament,_Main_Debating_Chamber_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1650829.jpg"><img alt="Modern one-story building with grass on roof and large sculpted grass area in front. Behind are residential buildings in a mixture of styles." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="427" data-file-width="640" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Scottish_Parliament%2C_Main_Debating_Chamber_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1650829.jpg/220px-Scottish_Parliament%2C_Main_Debating_Chamber_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1650829.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Scottish_Parliament%2C_Main_Debating_Chamber_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1650829.jpg/330px-Scottish_Parliament%2C_Main_Debating_Chamber_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1650829.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Scottish_Parliament%2C_Main_Debating_Chamber_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1650829.jpg/440px-Scottish_Parliament%2C_Main_Debating_Chamber_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1650829.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Scottish_Parliament,_Main_Debating_Chamber_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1650829.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Parliament_Building" title="Scottish Parliament Building">Scottish Parliament Building</a> in <a href="/wiki/Holyrood,_Edinburgh" title="Holyrood, Edinburgh">Holyrood</a> is the seat of the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Parliament" title="Scottish Parliament">Scottish Parliament</a></div></div></div>\n<p>Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland each have their own <a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">government or executive</a>, led by a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_First_Ministers_in_the_UK" title="List of First Ministers in the UK">First Minister</a> (or, in the case of Northern Ireland, a <a href="/wiki/Diarchy" title="Diarchy">diarchal</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_Minister_and_deputy_First_Minister" title="First Minister and deputy First Minister">First Minister and deputy First Minister</a>), and a <a href="/wiki/Devolution" title="Devolution">devolved</a> <a href="/wiki/Unicameralism" title="Unicameralism">unicameral</a> legislature. England, the largest country of the United Kingdom, has no such devolved executive or legislature and is administered and legislated for directly by the UK\'s government and parliament on all issues. This situation has given rise to the so-called <a href="/wiki/West_Lothian_question" title="West Lothian question">West Lothian question</a>, which concerns the fact that members of parliament from Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland can vote, sometimes decisively,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[190]</a></sup> on matters that affect only England.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[191]</a></sup> The 2013 <a href="/wiki/Commission_on_the_consequences_of_devolution_for_the_House_of_Commons" title="Commission on the consequences of devolution for the House of Commons">McKay Commission</a> on this recommended that laws affecting only England should need support from a majority of English members of parliament.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbcnews250313_206-0"><a href="#cite_note-bbcnews250313-206">[192]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Prime_Minister_meets_the_First_Minister_of_Scotland.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="683" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Prime_Minister_meets_the_First_Minister_of_Scotland.jpg/220px-Prime_Minister_meets_the_First_Minister_of_Scotland.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Prime_Minister_meets_the_First_Minister_of_Scotland.jpg/330px-Prime_Minister_meets_the_First_Minister_of_Scotland.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Prime_Minister_meets_the_First_Minister_of_Scotland.jpg/440px-Prime_Minister_meets_the_First_Minister_of_Scotland.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Prime_Minister_meets_the_First_Minister_of_Scotland.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Prime Minister Theresa May meets <a href="/wiki/First_Minister_of_Scotland" title="First Minister of Scotland">First Minister of Scotland</a> <a href="/wiki/Nicola_Sturgeon" title="Nicola Sturgeon">Nicola Sturgeon</a> outside <a href="/wiki/10_Downing_Street" title="10 Downing Street">10 Downing Street</a>, the official residence of the British Prime Minister</div></div></div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Government" title="Scottish Government">Scottish Government</a> and <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Parliament" title="Scottish Parliament">Parliament</a> have wide-ranging powers over any matter that has not been specifically <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reserved_matters" title="Reserved matters">reserved</a> to the UK Parliament, including <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Scotland" title="Education in Scotland">education</a>, <a href="/wiki/NHS_Scotland" title="NHS Scotland">healthcare</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scots_law" title="Scots law">Scots law</a> and <a href="/wiki/Local_government_in_Scotland" title="Local government in Scotland">local government</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[193]</a></sup> In 2012, the UK and Scottish governments signed the <a href="/wiki/Edinburgh_Agreement_(2012)" title="Edinburgh Agreement (2012)">Edinburgh Agreement</a> setting out the terms for a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scottish_independence_referendum,_2014" title="Scottish independence referendum, 2014">referendum on Scottish independence</a> in 2014, which was defeated 55.3% to 44.7% &#8211; resulting in Scotland remaining a devolved part of the United Kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc-result_208-0"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-result-208">[194]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Welsh_Government" title="Welsh Government">Welsh Government</a> and the <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_for_Wales" title="National Assembly for Wales">National Assembly for Wales</a> have more limited powers than those devolved to Scotland.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[195]</a></sup> The Assembly is able to legislate on devolved matters through <a href="/wiki/Act_of_the_National_Assembly_for_Wales" title="Act of the National Assembly for Wales">Acts of the Assembly</a>, which require no prior consent from Westminster.\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Executive" title="Northern Ireland Executive">Northern Ireland Executive</a> and <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Assembly" title="Northern Ireland Assembly">Assembly</a> have powers similar to those devolved to Scotland. The Executive is led by a <a href="/wiki/Diarchy" title="Diarchy">diarchy</a> representing <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Designated_Unionist" title="Designated Unionist">unionist</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Designated_Nationalist" title="Designated Nationalist">nationalist</a> members of the Assembly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-northernireland1_210-0"><a href="#cite_note-northernireland1-210">[196]</a></sup> Devolution to Northern Ireland is contingent on participation by the Northern Ireland administration in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/North-South_Ministerial_Council" title="North-South Ministerial Council">North-South Ministerial Council</a>, where the Northern Ireland Executive cooperates and develops joint and shared policies with the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Ireland" title="Government of Ireland">Government of Ireland</a>. The British and Irish governments co-operate on non-devolved matters affecting Northern Ireland through the <a href="/wiki/British%E2%80%93Irish_Intergovernmental_Conference" title="British&#8211;Irish Intergovernmental Conference">British&#8211;Irish Intergovernmental Conference</a>, which assumes the responsibilities of the Northern Ireland administration in the event of its non-operation.\n</p><p>The UK does not have a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Codified_constitution" title="Codified constitution">codified constitution</a> and constitutional matters are not among the powers devolved to Scotland, Wales or Northern Ireland. Under the doctrine of <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_sovereignty_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Parliamentary sovereignty in the United Kingdom">parliamentary sovereignty</a>, the UK Parliament could, in theory, therefore, abolish the Scottish Parliament, Welsh Assembly or Northern Ireland Assembly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[197]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[198]</a></sup> Indeed, in 1972, the UK Parliament <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland_(Temporary_Provisions)_Act_1972" title="Northern Ireland (Temporary Provisions) Act 1972">unilaterally prorogued</a> the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Northern_Ireland" title="Parliament of Northern Ireland">Parliament of Northern Ireland</a>, setting a precedent relevant to contemporary devolved institutions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[199]</a></sup> In practice, it would be politically difficult for the UK Parliament to abolish devolution to the Scottish Parliament and the Welsh Assembly, given the political entrenchment created by referendum decisions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[200]</a></sup> The political constraints placed upon the UK Parliament\'s power to interfere with devolution in Northern Ireland are even greater than in relation to Scotland and Wales, given that devolution in Northern Ireland rests upon an international agreement with the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Ireland" title="Government of Ireland">Government of Ireland</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[201]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_and_criminal_justice">Law and criminal justice</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Law_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Law of the United Kingdom">Law of the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Royal_courts_of_justice.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Royal_courts_of_justice.jpg/220px-Royal_courts_of_justice.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Royal_courts_of_justice.jpg/330px-Royal_courts_of_justice.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Royal_courts_of_justice.jpg/440px-Royal_courts_of_justice.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Royal_courts_of_justice.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Royal_Courts_of_Justice" title="Royal Courts of Justice">Royal Courts of Justice</a> of <a href="/wiki/England_and_Wales" title="England and Wales">England and Wales</a></div></div></div>\n<p>The United Kingdom does not have a single legal system as Article 19 of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Union" title="Treaty of Union">1706 Treaty of Union</a> provided for the continuation of Scotland\'s separate legal system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[202]</a></sup> Today the UK has three distinct <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Legal_systems_of_the_world" title="Legal systems of the world">systems of law</a>: <a href="/wiki/English_law" title="English law">English law</a>, <a href="/wiki/Courts_of_Northern_Ireland" title="Courts of Northern Ireland">Northern Ireland law</a> and <a href="/wiki/Scots_law" title="Scots law">Scots law</a>. A new <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Supreme Court of the United Kingdom">Supreme Court of the United Kingdom</a> came into being in October 2009 to replace the <a href="/wiki/Judicial_functions_of_the_House_of_Lords" title="Judicial functions of the House of Lords">Appellate Committee of the House of Lords</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217"><a href="#cite_note-217">[203]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[204]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Judicial_Committee_of_the_Privy_Council" title="Judicial Committee of the Privy Council">Judicial Committee of the Privy Council</a>, including the same members as the Supreme Court, is the highest court of appeal for several independent Commonwealth countries, the <a href="/wiki/British_Overseas_Territories" title="British Overseas Territories">British Overseas Territories</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Crown_Dependencies" title="Crown Dependencies">Crown Dependencies</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[205]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Both English law, which applies in <a href="/wiki/England_and_Wales" title="England and Wales">England and Wales</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland_law" title="Northern Ireland law">Northern Ireland law</a> are based on <a href="/wiki/Common_law" title="Common law">common-law</a> principles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[206]</a></sup> The essence of common law is that, subject to statute, the law is developed by judges in courts, applying statute, <a href="/wiki/Precedent" title="Precedent">precedent</a> and common sense to the facts before them to give explanatory judgements of the relevant legal principles, which are reported and binding in future similar cases (<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stare_decisis" title="Stare decisis">stare decisis</a></i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[207]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Courts_of_England_and_Wales" title="Courts of England and Wales">courts of England and Wales</a> are headed by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Senior_Courts_of_England_and_Wales" title="Senior Courts of England and Wales">Senior Courts of England and Wales</a>, consisting of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Court_of_Appeal_of_England_and_Wales" title="Court of Appeal of England and Wales">Court of Appeal</a>, the <a href="/wiki/High_Court_of_Justice" title="High Court of Justice">High Court of Justice</a> (for civil cases) and the <a href="/wiki/Crown_Court" title="Crown Court">Crown Court</a> (for criminal cases). The Supreme Court is the highest court in the land for both criminal and civil appeal cases in England, Wales and Northern Ireland and any decision it makes is binding on every other court in the same jurisdiction, often having a persuasive effect in other jurisdictions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[208]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:High_Court_of_Justiciary.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="600" decoding="async" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/High_Court_of_Justiciary.jpg/170px-High_Court_of_Justiciary.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/High_Court_of_Justiciary.jpg/255px-High_Court_of_Justiciary.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/High_Court_of_Justiciary.jpg/340px-High_Court_of_Justiciary.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:High_Court_of_Justiciary.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/High_Court_of_Justiciary" title="High Court of Justiciary">High Court of Justiciary</a>&#8212;the <a href="/wiki/College_of_Justice" title="College of Justice">supreme</a> <a href="/wiki/Criminal_justice" title="Criminal justice">criminal court</a> of <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a></div></div></div>\n<p>Scots law is a hybrid system based on both common-law and <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">civil-law</a> principles. The chief courts are the <a href="/wiki/Court_of_Session" title="Court of Session">Court of Session</a>, for civil cases,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[209]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/High_Court_of_Justiciary" title="High Court of Justiciary">High Court of Justiciary</a>, for criminal cases.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[210]</a></sup> The Supreme Court of the United Kingdom serves as the highest court of appeal for civil cases under Scots law.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[211]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sheriff_Court" title="Sheriff Court">Sheriff courts</a> deal with most civil and criminal cases including conducting criminal trials with a jury, known as sheriff solemn court, or with a sheriff and no jury, known as sheriff summary Court.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[212]</a></sup> The Scots legal system is unique in having three possible <a href="/wiki/Verdict" title="Verdict">verdicts</a> for a criminal trial: "<a href="/wiki/Guilt_(law)" title="Guilt (law)">guilty</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Acquittal" title="Acquittal">not guilty</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/Not_proven" title="Not proven">not proven</a>". Both "not guilty" and "not proven" result in an acquittal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[213]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Crime in England and Wales increased in the period between 1981 and 1995, though since that peak there has been an overall fall of 66% in recorded crime from 1995 to 2015,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[214]</a></sup> according to <a href="/wiki/Crime_statistics_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Crime statistics in the United Kingdom">crime statistics</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prison_population_of_England_and_Wales" title="Prison population of England and Wales">prison population of England and Wales</a> has increased to 86,000, giving England and Wales the highest rate of incarceration in Western Europe at 148 per 100,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[215]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ICPS_230-0"><a href="#cite_note-ICPS-230">[216]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Her_Majesty%27s_Prison_Service" title="Her Majesty\'s Prison Service">Her Majesty\'s Prison Service</a>, which reports to the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Justice_(United_Kingdom)" title="Ministry of Justice (United Kingdom)">Ministry of Justice</a>, manages most of the prisons within England and Wales. The murder rate in England and Wales has stabilised in the first half of the 2010s with a murder rate around 1 per 100,000 which is half the peak in 2002 and similar to the rate in the 1980s<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[217]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[218]</a></sup> Crime in Scotland fell slightly in 2014/2015 to its lowest level in 39 years in with 59 killings for a murder rate of 1.1 per 100,000. Scotland\'s prisons are overcrowded but the prison population is shrinking.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[219]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Foreign relations of the United Kingdom">Foreign relations of the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<p>The UK is a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Big_Five_(United_Nations)" title="Big Five (United Nations)">permanent member</a> of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a>, a member of <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">Commonwealth of Nations</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G7_finance_ministers" title="G7 finance ministers">G7 finance ministers</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G7_forum" title="G7 forum">G7 forum</a> (previously the <i>G8 forum</i>), the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G-20_major_economies" title="G-20 major economies">G20</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">OECD</a>, the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">WTO</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">OSCE</a>. It is also a <a href="/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union" title="Member state of the European Union">member state of the European Union</a> in the process of withdrawal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234"><a href="#cite_note-234">[220]</a></sup> The UK is said to have a "<a href="/wiki/Special_Relationship" title="Special Relationship">Special Relationship</a>" with the United States and a close partnership with France&#8212;the "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Entente_cordiale" title="Entente cordiale">Entente cordiale</a>"&#8212;and shares nuclear weapons technology with both countries;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[221]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[222]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Portuguese_Alliance" title="Anglo-Portuguese Alliance">Anglo-Portuguese Alliance</a> is considered to be the oldest currently binding military alliance in the world. The UK is also closely linked with the Republic of Ireland; the two countries share a <a href="/wiki/Common_Travel_Area" title="Common Travel Area">Common Travel Area</a> and co-operate through the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British-Irish_Intergovernmental_Conference" title="British-Irish Intergovernmental Conference">British-Irish Intergovernmental Conference</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British-Irish_Council" title="British-Irish Council">British-Irish Council</a>. Britain\'s global presence and influence is further amplified through its trading relations, foreign investments, <a href="/wiki/Official_development_assistance" title="Official development assistance">official development assistance</a> and military engagements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[223]</a></sup> Canada, Australia and New Zealand are the most favourably viewed countries in the world by <a href="/wiki/British_people" title="British people">British people</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238">[224]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[225]</a></sup> sharing <a href="/wiki/CANZUK#Origins_and_relationship" title="CANZUK">a number of close diplomatic, military and cultural ties with the UK</a>. There is considerable public and political support for increased trade, foreign policy co-operation and mobility of citizens between the UK and Canada, Australia and New Zealand under a proposal known by the acronym "<a href="/wiki/CANZUK" title="CANZUK">CANZUK</a>" &#8211; with 68% of British people stating that they would endorse the proposition in principle.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[226]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[227]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/British_Armed_Forces" title="British Armed Forces">British Armed Forces</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:HMS_Queen_Elizabeth_(R08)_underway_during_trials_with_HMS_Sutherland_(F81)_and_HMS_Iron_Duke_(F234)_on_28_June_2017_(45162784).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2400" data-file-width="3600" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/HMS_Queen_Elizabeth_%28R08%29_underway_during_trials_with_HMS_Sutherland_%28F81%29_and_HMS_Iron_Duke_%28F234%29_on_28_June_2017_%2845162784%29.jpg/220px-HMS_Queen_Elizabeth_%28R08%29_underway_during_trials_with_HMS_Sutherland_%28F81%29_and_HMS_Iron_Duke_%28F234%29_on_28_June_2017_%2845162784%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/HMS_Queen_Elizabeth_%28R08%29_underway_during_trials_with_HMS_Sutherland_%28F81%29_and_HMS_Iron_Duke_%28F234%29_on_28_June_2017_%2845162784%29.jpg/330px-HMS_Queen_Elizabeth_%28R08%29_underway_during_trials_with_HMS_Sutherland_%28F81%29_and_HMS_Iron_Duke_%28F234%29_on_28_June_2017_%2845162784%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/HMS_Queen_Elizabeth_%28R08%29_underway_during_trials_with_HMS_Sutherland_%28F81%29_and_HMS_Iron_Duke_%28F234%29_on_28_June_2017_%2845162784%29.jpg/440px-HMS_Queen_Elizabeth_%28R08%29_underway_during_trials_with_HMS_Sutherland_%28F81%29_and_HMS_Iron_Duke_%28F234%29_on_28_June_2017_%2845162784%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:HMS_Queen_Elizabeth_(R08)_underway_during_trials_with_HMS_Sutherland_(F81)_and_HMS_Iron_Duke_(F234)_on_28_June_2017_(45162784).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/HMS_Queen_Elizabeth_(R08)" title="HMS Queen Elizabeth (R08)">HMS&#160;<i>Queen Elizabeth</i></a>, a <a href="/wiki/Queen_Elizabeth-class_aircraft_carrier" title="Queen Elizabeth-class aircraft carrier"><i>Queen Elizabeth</i>-class</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Supercarrier" title="Supercarrier">supercarrier</a> on sea trials in June 2017.</div></div></div>\n<p>The armed forces of the United Kingdom&#8212;officially, <i><a href="/wiki/British_Armed_Forces" title="British Armed Forces">Her Majesty\'s Armed Forces</a></i>&#8212;consist of three professional service branches: the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">Royal Navy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Royal_Marines" title="Royal Marines">Royal Marines</a> (forming the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Naval_Service_(United_Kingdom)" title="Naval Service (United Kingdom)">Naval Service</a>), the <a href="/wiki/British_Army" title="British Army">British Army</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Air_Force" title="Royal Air Force">Royal Air Force</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[228]</a></sup> The forces are managed by the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_(United_Kingdom)" title="Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)">Ministry of Defence</a> and controlled by the <a href="/wiki/Defence_Council_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Defence Council of the United Kingdom">Defence Council</a>, chaired by the <a href="/wiki/Secretary_of_State_for_Defence" title="Secretary of State for Defence">Secretary of State for Defence</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Commander-in-Chief" title="Commander-in-Chief">Commander-in-Chief</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Monarchy of the United Kingdom">British monarch</a>, to whom members of the forces swear an oath of allegiance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Speaker_243-0"><a href="#cite_note-Speaker-243">[229]</a></sup> The Armed Forces are charged with protecting the UK and its overseas territories, promoting the UK\'s global security interests and supporting international peacekeeping efforts. They are active and regular participants in <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>, including the <a href="/wiki/Allied_Rapid_Reaction_Corps" title="Allied Rapid Reaction Corps">Allied Rapid Reaction Corps</a>, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Five_Power_Defence_Arrangements" title="Five Power Defence Arrangements">Five Power Defence Arrangements</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/RIMPAC" title="RIMPAC">RIMPAC</a> and other worldwide coalition operations. Overseas garrisons and facilities are maintained in <a href="/wiki/RAF_Ascension_Island" title="RAF Ascension Island">Ascension Island</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_of_Belize" title="Military of Belize">Belize</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_Forces_based_in_Brunei" title="Military Forces based in Brunei">Brunei</a>, <a href="/wiki/British_Army_Training_Unit_Suffield" title="British Army Training Unit Suffield">Canada</a>, <a href="/wiki/British_Forces_Cyprus" title="British Forces Cyprus">Cyprus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Diego_Garcia" title="Diego Garcia">Diego Garcia</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Military_of_the_Falkland_Islands" title="Military of the Falkland Islands">Falkland Islands</a>, <a href="/wiki/British_Forces_Germany" title="British Forces Germany">Germany</a>, <a href="/wiki/British_Forces_Gibraltar" title="British Forces Gibraltar">Gibraltar</a>, <a href="/wiki/British_Army_Training_Unit_Kenya" title="British Army Training Unit Kenya">Kenya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Qatar" title="Qatar">Qatar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Facilities_244-0"><a href="#cite_note-Facilities-244">[230]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[231]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The British armed forces played a key role in establishing the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a> as the <a href="/wiki/Superpower" title="Superpower">dominant world power</a> in the 18th, 19th and early 20th centuries. By emerging victorious from conflicts, Britain has often been able to decisively <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Vienna" title="Congress of Vienna">influence world events</a>. Since the end of the British Empire, the UK has remained a major military power. Following the end of the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>, defence policy has a stated assumption that "the most demanding operations" will be undertaken as part of a coalition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[232]</a></sup> UK military operations in <a href="/wiki/Bosnian_War" title="Bosnian War">Bosnia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kosovo_War" title="Kosovo War">Kosovo</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Role_of_the_United_Kingdom_in_the_War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%93present)" title="Role of the United Kingdom in the War in Afghanistan (2001&#8211;present)">Afghanistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Operation_Telic" title="Operation Telic">Iraq</a> and <a href="/wiki/2011_military_intervention_in_Libya" title="2011 military intervention in Libya">Libya</a>, have followed this approach. Setting aside the <a href="/wiki/British_military_intervention_in_the_Sierra_Leone_Civil_War" title="British military intervention in the Sierra Leone Civil War">intervention in Sierra Leone</a> in 2000, the last occasion on which the British military fought alone was the <a href="/wiki/Falklands_War" title="Falklands War">Falklands War</a> of 1982.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>\n</p><p>According to various sources, including the <a href="/wiki/Stockholm_International_Peace_Research_Institute" title="Stockholm International Peace Research Institute">Stockholm International Peace Research Institute</a> and the <a href="/wiki/International_Institute_for_Strategic_Studies" title="International Institute for Strategic Studies">International Institute for Strategic Studies</a>, the United Kingdom has the fourth- or fifth-highest <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures" title="List of countries by military expenditures">military expenditure</a> in the world. Total defence spending amounts to 2.0% of national GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SIPRI_247-0"><a href="#cite_note-SIPRI-247">[233]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Economy of the United Kingdom">Economy of the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Overview">Overview</span></h3>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Banco_de_Inglaterra,_Londres,_Inglaterra,_2014-08-11,_DD_141.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3548" data-file-width="4978" decoding="async" height="157" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Banco_de_Inglaterra%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-11%2C_DD_141.JPG/220px-Banco_de_Inglaterra%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-11%2C_DD_141.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Banco_de_Inglaterra%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-11%2C_DD_141.JPG/330px-Banco_de_Inglaterra%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-11%2C_DD_141.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Banco_de_Inglaterra%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-11%2C_DD_141.JPG/440px-Banco_de_Inglaterra%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-11%2C_DD_141.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Banco_de_Inglaterra,_Londres,_Inglaterra,_2014-08-11,_DD_141.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_England" title="Bank of England">Bank of England</a>&#8212;the <a href="/wiki/Central_bank" title="Central bank">central bank</a> of the United Kingdom and the model on which most modern central banks have been based</div></div></div>\n<p>The UK has a partially regulated <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">market economy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[234]</a></sup> Based on market <a href="/wiki/Exchange_rate" title="Exchange rate">exchange rates</a>, the UK is today
