the fifth-largest economy in the world and the second-largest in Europe after Germany. <a href="/wiki/HM_Treasury" title="HM Treasury">HM Treasury</a>, led by the <a href="/wiki/Chancellor_of_the_Exchequer" title="Chancellor of the Exchequer">Chancellor of the Exchequer</a>, is responsible for developing and executing the government\'s <a href="/wiki/Public_finance" title="Public finance">public finance</a> policy and <a href="/wiki/Economic_policy" title="Economic policy">economic policy</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_England" title="Bank of England">Bank of England</a> is the UK\'s <a href="/wiki/Central_bank" title="Central bank">central bank</a> and is responsible for issuing notes and coins in the nation\'s currency, the <a href="/wiki/Pound_sterling" title="Pound sterling">pound sterling</a>. Banks in Scotland and Northern Ireland retain the right to issue their own notes, subject to retaining enough Bank of England notes in reserve to cover their issue. The pound sterling is the world\'s third-largest <a href="/wiki/Reserve_currency" title="Reserve currency">reserve currency</a> (after the US dollar and the euro).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[235]</a></sup> Since 1997 the Bank of England\'s <a href="/wiki/Monetary_Policy_Committee" title="Monetary Policy Committee">Monetary Policy Committee</a>, headed by the <a href="/wiki/Governor_of_the_Bank_of_England" title="Governor of the Bank of England">Governor of the Bank of England</a>, has been responsible for setting <a href="/wiki/Official_bank_rate" title="Official bank rate">interest rates</a> at the level necessary to achieve the overall inflation target for the economy that is set by the Chancellor each year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250"><a href="#cite_note-250">[236]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The UK <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_sector_of_the_economy" title="Tertiary sector of the economy">service sector</a> makes up around 79% of GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[237]</a></sup> London is one of the three "command centres" of <a href="/wiki/International_trade" title="International trade">the global economy</a> (alongside <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tokyo" title="Tokyo">Tokyo</a>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[238]</a></sup> it is the world\'s largest financial centre alongside New York,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Global_Financial_Centres_7_253-0"><a href="#cite_note-Global_Financial_Centres_7-253">[239]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mastercard_254-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mastercard-254">[240]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-forbes.com_255-0"><a href="#cite_note-forbes.com-255">[241]</a></sup> and it has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_by_GDP" title="List of cities by GDP">largest city GDP</a> in Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Global_city_GDP_rankings_2008-2025_256-0"><a href="#cite_note-Global_city_GDP_rankings_2008-2025-256">[242]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Tourism in the United Kingdom">Tourism</a> is very important to the British economy; with over 27&#160;million tourists arriving in 2004, the United Kingdom is ranked as the sixth major tourist destination in the world and London has the most international visitors of any city in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[243]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[244]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Creative_industries" title="Creative industries">creative industries</a> accounted for 7% GVA in 2005 and grew at an average of 6% per annum between 1997 and 2005.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[245]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Industrial_Revolution" title="Industrial Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a> started in the UK with an initial concentration on the textile industry,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Europa_260-0"><a href="#cite_note-Europa-260">[246]</a></sup> followed by other heavy industries such as <a href="/wiki/Shipbuilding" title="Shipbuilding">shipbuilding</a>, coal mining and <a href="/wiki/Steelmaking" title="Steelmaking">steelmaking</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[247]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[248]</a></sup> British merchants, shippers and bankers developed overwhelming advantage over those of other nations allowing the UK to dominate international trade in the 19th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[249]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[250]</a></sup> As other nations industrialised, coupled with economic decline after two world wars, the United Kingdom began to lose its competitive advantage and heavy industry declined, by degrees, throughout the 20th century. Manufacturing remains a significant part of the economy but accounted for only 16.7% of national output in 2003.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[251]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2017_Jaguar_XE_Portfolio_Diesel_Automatic_2.0_Front.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2212" data-file-width="4764" decoding="async" height="102" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/2017_Jaguar_XE_Portfolio_Diesel_Automatic_2.0_Front.jpg/220px-2017_Jaguar_XE_Portfolio_Diesel_Automatic_2.0_Front.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/2017_Jaguar_XE_Portfolio_Diesel_Automatic_2.0_Front.jpg/330px-2017_Jaguar_XE_Portfolio_Diesel_Automatic_2.0_Front.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/2017_Jaguar_XE_Portfolio_Diesel_Automatic_2.0_Front.jpg/440px-2017_Jaguar_XE_Portfolio_Diesel_Automatic_2.0_Front.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2017_Jaguar_XE_Portfolio_Diesel_Automatic_2.0_Front.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Jaguar cars, including the <a href="/wiki/Jaguar_XE" title="Jaguar XE">Jaguar XE</a> as shown, are designed, developed and manufactured in the UK</div></div></div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Automotive industry in the United Kingdom">automotive industry</a> is a significant part of the UK manufacturing sector and employs around 800,000 people, with a turnover in 2015 of &#163;70 billion, generating &#163;34.6 billion of exports (11.8% of the UK\'s total export goods). In 2015, the UK produced around 1.6 million passenger vehicles and 94,500 commercial vehicles. The UK is a major centre for engine manufacturing: in 2015 around 2.4 million engines were produced. The UK <a href="/wiki/Auto_racing" title="Auto racing">motorsport</a> industry employs around 41,000 people, comprises around 4,500 companies and has an annual turnover of around &#163;6 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[252]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Aerospace_industry_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Aerospace industry in the United Kingdom">aerospace industry of the UK</a> is the second- or third-largest national aerospace industry in the world depending upon the method of measurement and has an annual turnover of around &#163;30 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[253]</a></sup> The wings for the <a href="/wiki/Airbus_A380" title="Airbus A380">Airbus A380</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/A350_XWB" title="A350 XWB">A350 XWB</a> are designed and manufactured at <a href="/wiki/Airbus_UK" title="Airbus UK">Airbus UK</a>\'s Broughton facility, whilst over a quarter of the value of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Boeing_787" title="Boeing 787">Boeing 787</a> comes from UK manufacturers including Eaton, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Messier-Bugatti-Dowty" title="Messier-Bugatti-Dowty">Messier-Bugatti-Dowty</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rolls-Royce_Holdings" title="Rolls-Royce Holdings">Rolls-Royce</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:British_Airways_A380-841_G-XLEA_(16948377692).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2198" data-file-width="4421" decoding="async" height="109" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/British_Airways_A380-841_G-XLEA_%2816948377692%29.jpg/220px-British_Airways_A380-841_G-XLEA_%2816948377692%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/British_Airways_A380-841_G-XLEA_%2816948377692%29.jpg/330px-British_Airways_A380-841_G-XLEA_%2816948377692%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/British_Airways_A380-841_G-XLEA_%2816948377692%29.jpg/440px-British_Airways_A380-841_G-XLEA_%2816948377692%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:British_Airways_A380-841_G-XLEA_(16948377692).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Engines and wings for the <a href="/wiki/Airbus_A380" title="Airbus A380">Airbus A380</a> are manufactured in the UK</div></div></div>\n<p><a href="/wiki/BAE_Systems" title="BAE Systems">BAE Systems</a> plays a critical role in some of the world\'s biggest defence aerospace projects. In the UK, the company makes large sections of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Typhoon_Eurofighter" title="Typhoon Eurofighter">Typhoon Eurofighter</a> and assembles the aircraft for the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Air_Force" title="Royal Air Force">Royal Air Force</a>. It is also a principal subcontractor on the <a href="/wiki/Lockheed_Martin_F-35_Lightning_II" title="Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II">F35</a> Joint Strike Fighter&#8212;the world\'s largest single defence project&#8212;for which it designs and manufactures a range of components. It also manufactures the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BAE_Hawk" title="BAE Hawk">Hawk</a>, the world\'s most successful jet training aircraft.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-theengineer.co.uk_268-0"><a href="#cite_note-theengineer.co.uk-268">[254]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Airbus_UK" title="Airbus UK">Airbus UK</a> also manufactures the wings for the <a href="/wiki/Airbus_A400M_Atlas" title="Airbus A400M Atlas">A400&#160;m</a> military transporter. Rolls-Royce is the world\'s second-largest aero-engine manufacturer. Its engines power more than 30 types of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Commercial_aircraft" title="Commercial aircraft">commercial aircraft</a> and it has more than 30,000 engines in service in the civil and defence sectors.\n</p><p>The UK space industry was worth &#163;9.1bn in 2011 and employed 29,000 people. It is growing at a rate of 7.5% annually, according to its umbrella organisation, the <a href="/wiki/UK_Space_Agency" title="UK Space Agency">UK Space Agency</a>. In 2013, the British Government pledged &#163;60&#160;m to the <a href="/wiki/Skylon_(spacecraft)" title="Skylon (spacecraft)">Skylon</a> project: this investment will provide support at a "crucial stage" to allow a full-scale prototype of the <a href="/wiki/SABRE_(rocket_engine)" title="SABRE (rocket engine)">SABRE</a> engine to be built.\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Pharmaceutical_industry_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Pharmaceutical industry in the United Kingdom">pharmaceutical industry</a> plays an important role in the UK economy and the country has the third-highest share of global pharmaceutical R&amp;D expenditures.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pharmsectorbis_269-0"><a href="#cite_note-pharmsectorbis-269">[255]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[256]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Agriculture is intensive, highly mechanised and efficient by European standards, producing about 60% of food needs with less than 1.6% of the labour force (535,000 workers).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[257]</a></sup> Around two-thirds of production is devoted to livestock, one-third to arable crops. Farmers are subsidised by the EU\'s <a href="/wiki/Common_Agricultural_Policy" title="Common Agricultural Policy">Common Agricultural Policy</a>. The UK retains a significant, though much reduced fishing industry. It is also rich in a number of natural resources including coal, petroleum, natural gas, tin, limestone, iron ore, salt, clay, chalk, gypsum, lead, silica and an abundance of arable land.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[258]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r856303569" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:463px;max-width:463px"><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:241px;max-width:241px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_City_London.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2383" data-file-width="4370" decoding="async" height="130" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/The_City_London.jpg/239px-The_City_London.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/The_City_London.jpg/359px-The_City_London.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/The_City_London.jpg/478px-The_City_London.jpg 2x" width="239"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">The <a href="/wiki/City_of_London" title="City of London">City of London</a> is one of the world\'s largest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_financial_centre" title="International financial centre">financial centres</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Global_Financial_Centres_7_253-1"><a href="#cite_note-Global_Financial_Centres_7-253">[239]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mastercard_254-1"><a href="#cite_note-Mastercard-254">[240]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-forbes.com_255-1"><a href="#cite_note-forbes.com-255">[241]</a></sup></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:218px;max-width:218px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:London_MMB_%C2%BB007_River_Thames_and_Canary_Wharf.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2262" data-file-width="3747" decoding="async" height="130" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/London_MMB_%C2%BB007_River_Thames_and_Canary_Wharf.jpg/216px-London_MMB_%C2%BB007_River_Thames_and_Canary_Wharf.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/London_MMB_%C2%BB007_River_Thames_and_Canary_Wharf.jpg/324px-London_MMB_%C2%BB007_River_Thames_and_Canary_Wharf.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/London_MMB_%C2%BB007_River_Thames_and_Canary_Wharf.jpg/432px-London_MMB_%C2%BB007_River_Thames_and_Canary_Wharf.jpg 2x" width="216"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">The <a href="/wiki/Canary_Wharf" title="Canary Wharf">Canary Wharf</a> is one of the two main financial centres of the UK along with the City of London</div></div><div style="clear:left"></div></div></div>\n<p>In the final quarter of 2008, the UK economy officially entered <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Late-2000s_recession" title="Late-2000s recession">recession</a> for the first time since 1991.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[259]</a></sup> Following the likes of the United States, France and many major economies, in 2013, the UK lost its top AAA credit rating for the first time since 1978 with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Moody%27s_Investment_Services" title="Moody\'s Investment Services">Moodys</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fitch_Ratings" title="Fitch Ratings">Fitch</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Credit_agency" title="Credit agency">credit agency</a>, but, unlike the other major economies, retained its triple A rating with <a href="/wiki/Standard_%26_Poor%27s" title="Standard &amp; Poor\'s">Standard &amp; Poor\'s</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[260]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275"><a href="#cite_note-275">[261]</a></sup> By the end of 2014, UK growth was the fastest in both the G7 and in Europe,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[262]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[263]</a></sup> and by September 2015, the unemployment rate was down to a seven-year low of 5.3%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[264]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Since the 1980s, UK <a href="/wiki/Economic_inequality" title="Economic inequality">economic inequality</a>, like Canada, Australia and the United States, has grown faster than in other developed countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279">[265]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Beckford_280-0"><a href="#cite_note-Beckford-280">[266]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Poverty_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Poverty in the United Kingdom">poverty line in the UK</a> is commonly defined as being 60% of the median household income.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[note 15]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Office_for_National_Statistics" title="Office for National Statistics">Office for National Statistics</a> has estimated that in 2011, 14 million people were at risk of <a href="/wiki/Poverty_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Poverty in the United Kingdom">poverty</a> or social exclusion, and that one person in 20 (5.1%) was experiencing "severe material depression",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Andrews_282-0"><a href="#cite_note-Andrews-282">[267]</a></sup> up from 3 million people in 1977.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Glynn_283-0"><a href="#cite_note-Glynn-283">[268]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Physorg_284-0"><a href="#cite_note-Physorg-284">[269]</a></sup> Although the UK does not have an official poverty measure, the Joseph Rowntree Foundation and the Social Metrics Commission estimate, based on government data, that there are 14 million people in poverty in the UK.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[270]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[271]</a></sup> 1.5 million people experienced destitution in 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287"><a href="#cite_note-287">[272]</a></sup> In 2018, the UN Special Rapporteur on Extreme Poverty and Human Rights visited the UK and found that government policies and cuts to social support are "entrenching high levels of poverty and inflicting unnecessary misery in one of the richest countries in the world."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[273]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:162px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Clarks_Willis_Lad_school_shoes.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1348" data-file-width="855" decoding="async" height="252" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Clarks_Willis_Lad_school_shoes.jpg/160px-Clarks_Willis_Lad_school_shoes.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Clarks_Willis_Lad_school_shoes.jpg/240px-Clarks_Willis_Lad_school_shoes.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Clarks_Willis_Lad_school_shoes.jpg/320px-Clarks_Willis_Lad_school_shoes.jpg 2x" width="160"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Clarks_Willis_Lad_school_shoes.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/C._%26_J._Clark" title="C. &amp; J. Clark">Clarks</a> was founded in 1825 and has since become a leader and specialist in school shoes for children</div></div></div>\n<p><a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_external_debt" title="List of countries by external debt">The UK has an external debt</a> of $9.6 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trillion_(short_scale)" title="Trillion (short scale)">trillion</a> dollars, which is the second highest in the world after the US. As a percentage of GDP, external debt is 408%, which is the third highest in the world after Luxembourg and Iceland.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[274]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[275]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[276]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[277]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[278]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The combination of the UK\'s relatively lax regulatory regime and London\'s financial institutions providing sophisticated methods to <a href="/wiki/Money_laundering" title="Money laundering">launder</a> proceeds from criminal activity around the world, including those from drug trade, makes the City of London a global hub for illicit finance and the UK a safe haven for the world\'s major-league <a href="/wiki/Tax_avoidance" title="Tax avoidance">tax dodgers</a>, according to research papers and reports published in the mid-2010s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[279]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[280]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[281]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[282]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[283]</a></sup> The reports on the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Panama_papers" title="Panama papers">Panama papers</a> published in April 2016 singled out the UK as being "at the heart of super-rich tax-avoidance network."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[284]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Science and technology in the United Kingdom">Science and technology in the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Darwin_restored2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4311" data-file-width="3180" decoding="async" height="230" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Darwin_restored2.jpg/170px-Darwin_restored2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Darwin_restored2.jpg/255px-Darwin_restored2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Darwin_restored2.jpg/340px-Darwin_restored2.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Darwin_restored2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Charles_Darwin" title="Charles Darwin">Charles Darwin</a> (1809&#8211;1882), whose theory of <a href="/wiki/Evolution" title="Evolution">evolution by natural selection</a> is the foundation of modern biological sciences</div></div></div>\n<p>England and Scotland were leading centres of the <a href="/wiki/Scientific_Revolution" title="Scientific Revolution">Scientific Revolution</a> from the 17th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[285]</a></sup> The United Kingdom led the Industrial Revolution from the 18th century,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Europa_260-1"><a href="#cite_note-Europa-260">[246]</a></sup> and has continued to produce scientists and engineers credited with important advances.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301"><a href="#cite_note-301">[286]</a></sup> Major theorists from the 17th and 18th centuries include <a href="/wiki/Isaac_Newton" title="Isaac Newton">Isaac Newton</a>, whose <a href="/wiki/Newton%27s_laws_of_motion" title="Newton\'s laws of motion">laws of motion</a> and illumination of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gravitation" title="Gravitation">gravity</a> have been seen as a keystone of modern science;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302"><a href="#cite_note-302">[287]</a></sup> from the 19th century <a href="/wiki/Charles_Darwin" title="Charles Darwin">Charles Darwin</a>, whose theory of <a href="/wiki/Evolution" title="Evolution">evolution</a> by <a href="/wiki/Natural_selection" title="Natural selection">natural selection</a> was fundamental to the development of modern biology, and <a href="/wiki/James_Clerk_Maxwell" title="James Clerk Maxwell">James Clerk Maxwell</a>, who formulated classical <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Electromagnetic_theory" title="Electromagnetic theory">electromagnetic theory</a>; and more recently <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Hawking" title="Stephen Hawking">Stephen Hawking</a>, who has advanced major theories in the fields of <a href="/wiki/Cosmology" title="Cosmology">cosmology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Quantum_gravity" title="Quantum gravity">quantum gravity</a> and the investigation of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Black_holes" title="Black holes">black holes</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303"><a href="#cite_note-303">[288]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Major scientific discoveries from the 18th century include <a href="/wiki/Hydrogen" title="Hydrogen">hydrogen</a> by <a href="/wiki/Henry_Cavendish" title="Henry Cavendish">Henry Cavendish</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[289]</a></sup> from the 20th century <a href="/wiki/Penicillin" title="Penicillin">penicillin</a> by <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Fleming" title="Alexander Fleming">Alexander Fleming</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[290]</a></sup> and the structure of <a href="/wiki/DNA" title="DNA">DNA</a>, by <a href="/wiki/Francis_Crick" title="Francis Crick">Francis Crick</a> and others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[291]</a></sup> Famous British engineers and inventors of the Industrial Revolution include <a href="/wiki/James_Watt" title="James Watt">James Watt</a>, <a href="/wiki/George_Stephenson" title="George Stephenson">George Stephenson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Richard_Arkwright" title="Richard Arkwright">Richard Arkwright</a>, <a href="/wiki/Robert_Stephenson" title="Robert Stephenson">Robert Stephenson</a> and <a href="/wiki/Isambard_Kingdom_Brunel" title="Isambard Kingdom Brunel">Isambard Kingdom Brunel</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[292]</a></sup> Other major engineering projects and applications by people from the UK include the <a href="/wiki/Steam_locomotive" title="Steam locomotive">steam locomotive</a>, developed by <a href="/wiki/Richard_Trevithick" title="Richard Trevithick">Richard Trevithick</a> and <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Vivian" title="Andrew Vivian">Andrew Vivian</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[293]</a></sup> from the 19th century the <a href="/wiki/Electric_motor" title="Electric motor">electric motor</a> by <a href="/wiki/Michael_Faraday" title="Michael Faraday">Michael Faraday</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Incandescent_light_bulb" title="Incandescent light bulb">incandescent light bulb</a> by <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Swan" title="Joseph Swan">Joseph Swan</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[294]</a></sup> and the first practical telephone, patented by <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Graham_Bell" title="Alexander Graham Bell">Alexander Graham Bell</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[295]</a></sup> and in the 20th century the world\'s first working television system by <a href="/wiki/John_Logie_Baird" title="John Logie Baird">John Logie Baird</a> and others,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311"><a href="#cite_note-311">[296]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Jet_engine" title="Jet engine">jet engine</a> by <a href="/wiki/Frank_Whittle" title="Frank Whittle">Frank Whittle</a>, the basis of the modern computer by <a href="/wiki/Alan_Turing" title="Alan Turing">Alan Turing</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/World_Wide_Web" title="World Wide Web">World Wide Web</a> by <a href="/wiki/Tim_Berners-Lee" title="Tim Berners-Lee">Tim Berners-Lee</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[297]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Scientific research and development remains important in British universities, with many establishing <a href="/wiki/Science_park" title="Science park">science parks</a> to facilitate production and co-operation with industry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[298]</a></sup> Between 2004 and 2008 the UK produced 7% of the world\'s scientific research papers and had an 8% share of scientific citations, the third and second highest in the world (after the United States and China, respectively).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314"><a href="#cite_note-314">[299]</a></sup> Scientific journals produced in the UK include <i><a href="/wiki/Nature_(journal)" title="Nature (journal)">Nature</a></i>, the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BMJ" title="BMJ">British Medical Journal</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Lancet" title="The Lancet">The Lancet</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[300]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Transport in the United Kingdom">Transport in the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Heathrow_T5.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="815" data-file-width="1669" decoding="async" height="107" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Heathrow_T5.jpg/220px-Heathrow_T5.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Heathrow_T5.jpg/330px-Heathrow_T5.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Heathrow_T5.jpg/440px-Heathrow_T5.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Heathrow_T5.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/London_Heathrow_Terminal_5" title="London Heathrow Terminal 5">Heathrow Terminal 5 building</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/London_Heathrow_Airport" title="London Heathrow Airport">London Heathrow Airport</a> is one of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World%27s_busiest_airports_by_international_passenger_traffic" title="World\'s busiest airports by international passenger traffic">busiest airports by international passenger traffic</a> worldwide<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc1_316-0"><a href="#cite_note-bbc1-316">[301]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-airport_317-0"><a href="#cite_note-airport-317">[302]</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>A radial road network totals 29,145 miles (46,904&#160;km) of main roads, 2,173 miles (3,497&#160;km) of motorways and 213,750 miles (344,000&#160;km) of paved roads.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-factbook_153-4"><a href="#cite_note-factbook-153">[141]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/M25_motorway" title="M25 motorway">M25</a>, encircling London, is the largest and busiest bypass in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318">[303]</a></sup> In 2009 there were a total of 34&#160;million licensed vehicles in Great Britain.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319"><a href="#cite_note-319">[304]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="7140" data-file-width="8466" decoding="async" height="186" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg/220px-St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg/330px-St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg/440px-St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/St_Pancras_railway_station" title="St Pancras railway station">London St Pancras International</a> is the UK\'s 13th busiest railway terminus. The station is one of London\'s main domestic and international transport hubs providing both commuter rail and high speed rail services across the UK and to Paris, <a href="/wiki/Lille" title="Lille">Lille</a> and <a href="/wiki/Brussels" title="Brussels">Brussels</a></div></div></div>\n<p>The UK has a railway network of 10,072 miles (16,209&#160;km) in <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Great_Britain" title="Rail transport in Great Britain">Great Britain</a> and 189 miles (304&#160;km) in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Railways" title="Northern Ireland Railways">Northern Ireland</a>. Railways in Northern Ireland are operated by <a href="/wiki/NI_Railways" title="NI Railways">NI Railways</a>, a subsidiary of state-owned <a href="/wiki/Translink_(Northern_Ireland)" title="Translink (Northern Ireland)">Translink</a>. In Great Britain, the <a href="/wiki/British_Rail" title="British Rail">British Rail</a> network was <a href="/wiki/Privatisation_of_British_Rail" title="Privatisation of British Rail">privatised</a> between 1994 and 1997, which was followed by a rapid rise in passenger numbers following years of decline, although the <a href="/wiki/Impact_of_the_privatisation_of_British_Rail" title="Impact of the privatisation of British Rail">factors behind this are disputed</a>. The UK was ranked eighth among national European rail systems in the 2017 European Railway Performance Index assessing intensity of use, quality of service and safety.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[305]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Network_Rail" title="Network Rail">Network Rail</a> owns and manages most of the fixed assets (tracks, signals etc.). About 20 privately owned <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Train_Operating_Companies" title="Train Operating Companies">Train Operating Companies</a> operate passenger trains, which carried 1.68 billion passengers in 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[306]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[307]</a></sup> There are also some 1,000 freight trains in daily operation.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title="The time period mentioned near this tag is ambiguous. (November 2015)">when?</span></a></i>]</sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-factbook_153-5"><a href="#cite_note-factbook-153">[141]</a></sup> The British Government is to spend &#163;30 billion on a new high-speed railway line, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/HS2" title="HS2">HS2</a>, to be operational by 2026.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[308]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Crossrail" title="Crossrail">Crossrail</a>, under construction in London, is Europe\'s largest construction project with a &#163;15 billion projected cost.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[309]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325"><a href="#cite_note-325">[310]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In the year from October 2009 to September 2010 UK airports handled a total of 211.4&#160;million passengers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-caastats_326-0"><a href="#cite_note-caastats-326">[311]</a></sup> In that period the three largest airports were <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/London_Heathrow_Airport" title="London Heathrow Airport">London Heathrow Airport</a> (65.6&#160;million passengers), <a href="/wiki/Gatwick_Airport" title="Gatwick Airport">Gatwick Airport</a> (31.5&#160;million passengers) and <a href="/wiki/London_Stansted_Airport" title="London Stansted Airport">London Stansted Airport</a> (18.9&#160;million passengers).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-caastats_326-1"><a href="#cite_note-caastats-326">[311]</a></sup> London Heathrow Airport, located 15 miles (24&#160;km) west of the capital, has the most international passenger traffic of any airport in the world<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc1_316-1"><a href="#cite_note-bbc1-316">[301]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-airport_317-1"><a href="#cite_note-airport-317">[302]</a></sup> and is the hub for the UK flag carrier <a href="/wiki/British_Airways" title="British Airways">British Airways</a>, as well as <a href="/wiki/Virgin_Atlantic" title="Virgin Atlantic">Virgin Atlantic</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327">[312]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Energy in the United Kingdom">Energy in the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Oil_platform_in_the_North_SeaPros.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1704" data-file-width="2560" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Oil_platform_in_the_North_SeaPros.jpg/220px-Oil_platform_in_the_North_SeaPros.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Oil_platform_in_the_North_SeaPros.jpg/330px-Oil_platform_in_the_North_SeaPros.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Oil_platform_in_the_North_SeaPros.jpg/440px-Oil_platform_in_the_North_SeaPros.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Oil_platform_in_the_North_SeaPros.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>An oil platform in the <a href="/wiki/North_Sea" title="North Sea">North Sea</a></div></div></div>\n<p>In 2006, the UK was the world\'s ninth-largest consumer of energy and the 15th-largest producer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[313]</a></sup> The UK is home to a number of large energy companies, including two of the six oil and gas "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Supermajor" title="Supermajor">supermajors</a>"&#8212;<a href="/wiki/BP" title="BP">BP</a> and <a href="/wiki/Royal_Dutch_Shell" title="Royal Dutch Shell">Royal Dutch Shell</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[314]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[315]</a></sup> In 2011, 40% of the UK\'s electricity was produced by gas, 30% by coal, 19% by nuclear power and 4.2% by wind, hydro, biofuels and wastes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-world-nuclear.org_331-0"><a href="#cite_note-world-nuclear.org-331">[316]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 2013, the UK produced 914&#160;thousand barrels per day (bbl/d) of oil and consumed 1,507&#160;thousand bbl/d.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[317]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333">[318]</a></sup> Production is now in decline and the UK has been a net importer of oil since 2005.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eiaoil_334-0"><a href="#cite_note-eiaoil-334">[319]</a></sup> In 2010<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> the UK had around 3.1&#160;billion barrels of proven <a href="/wiki/North_Sea_oil" title="North Sea oil">crude oil reserves</a>, the largest of any EU member state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eiaoil_334-1"><a href="#cite_note-eiaoil-334">[319]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 2009, the UK was the 13th-largest producer of natural gas in the world and the largest producer in the EU.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eiagas_335-0"><a href="#cite_note-eiagas-335">[320]</a></sup> Production is now in decline and the UK has been a net importer of natural gas since 2004.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eiagas_335-1"><a href="#cite_note-eiagas-335">[320]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Coal production played a key role in the UK economy in the 19th and 20th centuries. In the mid-1970s, 130 million tonnes of coal were produced annually, not falling below 100 million tonnes until the early 1980s. During the 1980s and 1990s the industry was scaled back considerably. In 2011, the UK produced 18.3 million tonnes of coal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eiaoverview_336-0"><a href="#cite_note-eiaoverview-336">[321]</a></sup> In 2005 it had proven recoverable coal reserves of 171&#160;million tons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eiaoverview_336-1"><a href="#cite_note-eiaoverview-336">[321]</a></sup> The UK <a href="/wiki/Coal_Authority" title="Coal Authority">Coal Authority</a> has stated there is a potential to produce between 7&#160;billion tonnes and 16&#160;billion tonnes of coal through <a href="/wiki/Underground_coal_gasification" title="Underground coal gasification">underground coal gasification (UCG)</a> or \'<a href="/wiki/Hydraulic_fracturing" title="Hydraulic fracturing">fracking\'</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Coal_2_337-0"><a href="#cite_note-Coal_2-337">[322]</a></sup> and that, based on current UK coal consumption, such reserves could last between 200 and 400 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Coal_3_338-0"><a href="#cite_note-Coal_3-338">[323]</a></sup> However, environmental and social concerns have been raised over chemicals getting into the water table and minor earthquakes damaging homes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[324]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340">[325]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In the late 1990s, nuclear power plants contributed around 25% of total annual electricity generation in the UK, but this has gradually declined as old plants have been shut down and ageing-related problems affect plant availability. In 2012, the UK had 16 reactors normally generating about 19% of its electricity. All but one of the reactors will be retired by 2023. Unlike Germany and Japan, the UK intends to build a new generation of nuclear plants from about 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-world-nuclear.org_331-1"><a href="#cite_note-world-nuclear.org-331">[316]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The total of all renewable electricity sources provided for 14.9% of the electricity generated in the United Kingdom in 2013,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DUKES_341-0"><a href="#cite_note-DUKES-341">[326]</a></sup> reaching 53.7 TWh of electricity generated. The UK is <a href="/wiki/Wind_power_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Wind power in the United Kingdom">one of the best sites in Europe for wind energy</a>, and wind power production is its fastest growing supply, in 2014 it generated 9.3% of the UK\'s total electricity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Roadmap_342-0"><a href="#cite_note-Roadmap-342">[327]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343"><a href="#cite_note-343">[328]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344">[329]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Water_supply_and_sanitation">Water supply and sanitation</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Water supply and sanitation in the United Kingdom">Water supply and sanitation in the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<p>Access to improved water supply and sanitation in the UK is universal. It is estimated that 96.7% of households are connected to the sewer network.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[330]</a></sup> According to the Environment Agency, total water abstraction for public water supply in the UK was 16,406 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Megalitre" title="Megalitre">megalitres</a> per day in 2007.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346"><a href="#cite_note-346">[331]</a></sup> Drinking water standards and wastewater discharge standards in the UK, as in other countries of the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>, are determined by the EU (see <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_the_European_Union" title="Water supply and sanitation in the European Union">Water supply and sanitation in the European Union</a>).<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>\n</p><p>In England and Wales water and sewerage services are provided by 10 private regional water and sewerage companies and 13 mostly smaller private "water only" companies. In Scotland water and sewerage services are provided by a single public company, <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Water" title="Scottish Water">Scottish Water</a>. In Northern Ireland water and sewerage services are also provided by a single public entity, <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Water" title="Northern Ireland Water">Northern Ireland Water</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demography_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Demography of the United Kingdom">Demography of the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Population_density_UK_2011_census.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="16686" data-file-width="9413" decoding="async" height="390" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Population_density_UK_2011_census.png/220px-Population_density_UK_2011_census.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Population_density_UK_2011_census.png/330px-Population_density_UK_2011_census.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Population_density_UK_2011_census.png/440px-Population_density_UK_2011_census.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Population_density_UK_2011_census.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map of population density in the UK as at the 2011 census</div></div></div>\n<p>A <a href="/wiki/Census_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Census in the United Kingdom">census</a> is taken simultaneously in all parts of the UK every ten years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[332]</a></sup> In the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_Census_2011" title="United Kingdom Census 2011">2011 census</a> the total population of the United Kingdom was 63,181,775.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2011census_348-0"><a href="#cite_note-2011census-348">[333]</a></sup> It is the third-largest in the European Union, the fifth-largest in the Commonwealth and the 22nd-largest in the world. In mid-2014 and mid-2015 net long-term international migration contributed more to population growth. In mid-2012 and mid-2013 natural change contributed the most to population growth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pop2015_349-0"><a href="#cite_note-pop2015-349">[334]</a></sup> Between 2001 and 2011 the population increased by an average annual rate of approximately 0.7%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2011census_348-1"><a href="#cite_note-2011census-348">[333]</a></sup> This compares to 0.3% per year in the period 1991 to 2001 and 0.2% in the decade 1981 to 1991.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pop2010_350-0"><a href="#cite_note-pop2010-350">[335]</a></sup> The 2011 census also confirmed that the proportion of the population aged 0&#8211;14 has nearly halved (31% in 1911 compared to 18 in 2011) and the proportion of older people aged 65 and over has more than tripled (from 5 to 16%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2011census_348-2"><a href="#cite_note-2011census-348">[333]</a></sup>\n</p><p>England\'s population in 2011 was 53 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2011_UK_censuses_351-0"><a href="#cite_note-2011_UK_censuses-351">[336]</a></sup> It is one of the most densely populated countries in the world, with 420&#160;people resident per square kilometre in mid-2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pop2015_349-1"><a href="#cite_note-pop2015-349">[334]</a></sup> with a particular concentration in London and the south-east.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[337]</a></sup> The 2011 census put Scotland\'s population at 5.3 million,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353"><a href="#cite_note-353">[338]</a></sup> Wales at 3.06 million and Northern Ireland at 1.81 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2011_UK_censuses_351-1"><a href="#cite_note-2011_UK_censuses-351">[336]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 2012 the average <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">total fertility rate</a> (TFR) across the UK was 1.92 children per woman.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TFR_354-0"><a href="#cite_note-TFR-354">[339]</a></sup> While a rising birth rate is contributing to current population growth, it remains considerably below the \'baby boom\' peak of 2.95 children per woman in 1964,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boseley_355-0"><a href="#cite_note-Boseley-355">[340]</a></sup> below the replacement rate of 2.1, but higher than the 2001 record low of 1.63.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TFR_354-1"><a href="#cite_note-TFR-354">[339]</a></sup> In 2011, 47.3% of births in the UK were to unmarried women.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[341]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Office_for_National_Statistics" title="Office for National Statistics">Office for National Statistics</a> published a bulletin in 2015 showing that, out of the UK population aged 16 and over, 1.7% identify as lesbian, gay, or bisexual (2.0% of males and 1.5% of females). 4.5% of respondents responded with "other", "I don\'t know", or did not respond.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[342]</a></sup>\n</p><p><br/>\n</p>\n<table class="navbox" width="97%">\n<tbody><tr>\n<th colspan="10" style="padding:0.3em 0; line-height:1.2em;"><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini" style="float: left; margin-left:0.75em"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Largest_Urban_Areas_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Template:Largest Urban Areas of the United Kingdom"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Largest_Urban_Areas_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Template talk:Largest Urban Areas of the United Kingdom"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Largest_Urban_Areas_of_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div> <span style="font-size:120%;">Largest urban areas of the United Kingdom</span><br/><span style="font-weight:normal;">(England and Wales: 2011 census built-up style="text-align:left;">1,199,629</td>\n<td><a href="/wiki/Glasgow" title="Glasgow">Glasgow</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">15</td>\n<td align="left"><b><a title="Brighton">Brighton</a>\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">6</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><b><a href="/wiki/Liverpool_Urban_Area" title="Liverpool Urban conurbation</a></b></td>\n<td align="left">466,266</td>\n<td><a href="/wiki/Bournemouth" title="Bournemouth">Bournemouth</a>\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td style="text-align:left;">855,569</td>\n<td><a href="/wiki/Southampton" title="Southampton">Southampton</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">17</td>\n<td align="left"><b><a href="/wiki/Cardiff_Urban_Area" title="Cardiff Urban Area">Cardiff Urban Area</a></b></td>\n<td align="left">390,214</td>\n<td><a href="/wiki/Cardiff" title="Cardiff">Cardiff</a>\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">8</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><b><a href="/wiki/Tyneside" title="Tyneside">Tyneside</a></b></td>\n<td style="text-align:left;">774,891</td>\n<td><a href="/wiki/Newcastle_upon_Tyne" title="Newcastle upon Tyne">Newcastle</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">18</td>\n<td align="left"><b><a href="/wiki/Teesside" title="Teesside">Teesside</a></b></td>\n<td align="left">376,633</td>\n<td><a href="/wiki/Middlesbrough" title="Middlesbrough">Middlesbrough</a>\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">9</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><b><a href="/wiki/Nottingham_Urban_Area" title="Nottingham Urban Area">Nottingham Urban Area</a></b></td>\n<td style="text-align:left;">729,977</td>\n<td><a href="/wiki/Nottingham" title="Nottingham">Nottingham</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">19</td>\n<td align="left"><b><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Potteries_Urban_Area" title="The Potteries Urban Area">The Potteries Urban Area</a></b></td>\n<td align="left">372,775</td>\n<td><a href="/wiki/Stoke-on-Trent" title="Stoke-on-Trent">Stoke-on-Trent</a>\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">10</td>\n<td style="text-align:left;"><b><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sheffield_Urban_Area" title="Sheffield Urban Area">Sheffield Urban Area</a></b></td>\n<td style="text-align:left;">685,368</td>\n<td><a href="/wiki/Sheffield" title="Sheffield">Sheffield</a></td>\n<td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">20</td>\n<td align="left"><b><a href="/wiki/Coventry_and_Bedworth_Urban_Area" title="Coventry and Bedworth Urban Area">Coventry and Bedworth Urban Area</a></b></td>\n<td align="left">359,262</td>\n<td><a href="/wiki/Coventry" title="Coventry">Coventry</a>\n</td></tr>\n</tbody></table>\n<div style="clear:both;"></div>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnic_groups">Ethnic groups</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Ethnic groups in the United Kingdom">Ethnic groups in the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Non-white_in_the_2011_census.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="16576" data-file-width="9352" decoding="async" height="390" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Non-white_in_the_2011_census.png/220px-Non-white_in_the_2011_census.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Non-white_in_the_2011_census.png/330px-Non-white_in_the_2011_census.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Non-white_in_the_2011_census.png/440px-Non-white_in_the_2011_census.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Non-white_in_the_2011_census.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map showing the percentage of the population who are not white according to the 2011 census.</div></div></div>\n<p>Historically, indigenous British people were thought to be <a href="/wiki/Genetic_history_of_the_British_Isles" title="Genetic history of the British Isles">descended from the various ethnic groups</a> that settled there before the 12th century: the <a href="/wiki/Celts" title="Celts">Celts</a>, Romans, Anglo-Saxons, Norse and the <a href="/wiki/Normans" title="Normans">Normans</a>. <a href="/wiki/Welsh_people" title="Welsh people">Welsh people</a> could be the oldest ethnic group in the UK.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[346]</a></sup> A 2006 genetic study shows that more than 50% of England\'s gene pool contains <a href="/wiki/Germanic_peoples" title="Germanic peoples">Germanic</a> Y chromosomes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362"><a href="#cite_note-362">[347]</a></sup> Another 2005 genetic analysis indicates that "about 75% of the traceable ancestors of the modern British population had arrived in the British isles by about 6,200 years ago, at the start of the British Neolithic or Stone Age", and that the British broadly share a common ancestry with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Basque_people" title="Basque people">Basque people</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363"><a href="#cite_note-363">[348]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364"><a href="#cite_note-364">[349]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Henderson_365-0"><a href="#cite_note-Henderson-365">[350]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The UK has a history of small-scale non-white immigration, with <a href="/wiki/Liverpool" title="Liverpool">Liverpool</a> having the oldest Black population in the country dating back to at least the 1730s during the period of the African slave trade. During this period it is estimated the Afro-Caribbean population of Great Britain was 10,000 to 15,000<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[351]</a></sup> which later declined due to the abolition of slavery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[352]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Costello_368-0"><a href="#cite_note-Costello-368">[353]</a></sup> The UK also has the oldest <a href="/wiki/British_Chinese" title="British Chinese">Chinese</a> community in Europe, dating to the arrival of Chinese seamen in the 19th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chinese_369-0"><a href="#cite_note-Chinese-369">[354]</a></sup> In 1950 there were probably fewer than 20,000 non-white residents in Britain, almost all born overseas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[355]</a></sup> In 1951 there were an estimated 94,500 people living in Britain who had been born in South Asia, China, Africa and the Caribbean, just under 0.2% of the UK population. By 1961 this number had more than quadrupled to 384,000, just over 0.7% of the United Kingdom population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[356]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Since 1948 substantial immigration from Africa, the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean" title="Caribbean">Caribbean</a> and South Asia has been a legacy of ties forged by the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[357]</a></sup> Migration from new EU member states in <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central</a> and Eastern Europe since 2004 has resulted in growth in these population groups, although some of this migration has been temporary.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Vargas_373-0"><a href="#cite_note-Vargas-373">[358]</a></sup> Since the 1990s, there has been substantial diversification of the immigrant population, with migrants to the UK coming from a much wider range of countries than previous waves, which tended to involve larger numbers of migrants coming from a relatively small number of countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[359]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375">[360]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-376"><a href="#cite_note-376">[361]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Academics have argued that the <a href="/wiki/Classification_of_ethnicity_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Classification of ethnicity in the United Kingdom">ethnicity categories</a> employed in British national statistics, which were first introduced in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1991_UK_census" title="1991 UK census">1991 census</a>, involve confusion between the concepts of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethnicity" title="Ethnicity">ethnicity</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Race_(human_classification)" title="Race (human classification)">race</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-377"><a href="#cite_note-377">[362]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kertzer_378-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kertzer-378">[363]</a></sup> In <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_Census_2011" title="United Kingdom Census 2011">2011</a><sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, 87.2% of the UK population identified themselves as white, meaning 12.8% of the UK population identify themselves as of one of number of <a href="/wiki/Minority_group" title="Minority group">ethnic minority</a> groups.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ethnicity2011_379-0"><a href="#cite_note-ethnicity2011-379">[364]</a></sup> In the 2001 census, this figure was 7.9% of the UK population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ethnicity2001_380-0"><a href="#cite_note-ethnicity2001-380">[365]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Because of differences in the wording of the census forms used in England and Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland, data on the <a href="/wiki/Other_White" title="Other White">Other White</a> group is not available for the UK as a whole, but in England and Wales this was the fastest growing group between the 2001 and 2011 censuses, increasing by 1.1 million (1.8 percentage points).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[366]</a></sup> Amongst groups for which comparable data is available for all parts of the UK level, the Other Asian category increased from 0.4 to 1.4% of the population between 2001 and 2011, while the <a href="/wiki/Mixed_(United_Kingdom_ethnicity_category)" title="Mixed (United Kingdom ethnicity category)">Mixed</a> category rose from 1.2% to 2%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ethnicity2011_379-1"><a href="#cite_note-ethnicity2011-379">[364]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Ethnic diversity varies significantly across the UK. 30.4% of London\'s population and 37.4% of <a href="/wiki/Leicester" title="Leicester">Leicester</a>\'s was estimated to be non-white in 2005<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[367]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[368]</a></sup> whereas less than 5% of the populations of <a href="/wiki/North_East_England" title="North East England">North East England</a>, Wales and the <a href="/wiki/South_West_England" title="South West England">South West</a> were from ethnic minorities, according to the 2001 census.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[369]</a></sup> In 2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, 31.4% of primary and 27.9% of secondary pupils at <a href="/wiki/State_school" title="State school">state schools</a> in England were members of an ethnic minority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[370]</a></sup> The 1991 census was the first UK census to have a question on <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_group" title="Ethnic group">ethnic group</a>. In the 1991 UK census 94.1% of people reported themselves as being White British, White Irish or White Other with 5.9% of people reporting themselves as coming from other minority groups<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386">[371]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<table class="wikitable" style="float: right; margin-left: 1em; clear: right; text-align:right; font-size:85%;">\n<tbody><tr>\n<th colspan="2" rowspan="2">Ethnic group\n</th>\n<th colspan="2">Population (absolute)\n</th>\n<th>Population (%)\n</th></tr>\n<tr>\n<th>2001<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387"><a href="#cite_note-387">[372]</a></sup>\n</th>\n<th>2011\n</th>\n<th>2011<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ethnicity2011_379-2"><a href="#cite_note-ethnicity2011-379">[364]</a></sup>\n</th></tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="visibility:hidden;color:transparent;">0</span>87.1&#160;%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="text-align:left">White: Gypsy / Traveller /<br/>Irish Traveller<sup class="reference" style="visibility:hidden;color:transparent;">0</span>2.3&#160;%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td style="text-align:left">Pakistani</td>\n<td>747,285</td>\n<td>1,174,983</td>\n<td><span style="visibility:hidden;color:transparent;">0</span><span style="visibility:hidden;color:transparent;">0</span>1.9&#160;%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td style="text-align:left">Bangladeshi</td>\n<td>283,063</td>\n<td>451,529</td>\n<td><span style="visibility:hidden;color:transparent;">0</span><span style="visibility:hidden;color:transparent;">0</span>0.7&#160;%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td style="text-align:left">Chinese</td>\n<td>247,403</td>\n<td>433,150</td>\n<td><span style="visibility:hidden;color:transparent;">0</span><span style="visibility:hidden;color:transparent;">0</span>0.7&#160;%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td style="text-align:left">other Asian</td>\n<td>247,664</td>\n<td>861,815</td>\n<td><span style="visibility:hidden;color:transparent;">0</span><span style="visibility:hidden;color:transparent;">0</span>1.4&#160;%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="text-align:left">Black / African / Caribbean /<br/>Black British</td>\n<td>1,148,738<br/>&#160;</td>\n<td>1,904,684<br/><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[note 17]</a></sup></td>\n<td><span style="visibility:hidden;color:transparent;">0</span><span style="visibility:hidden;color:transparent;">0</span>3.0&#160;%<br/>&#160;\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="text-align:left">mixed / multiple ethnic groups</td>\n<td>677,117</td>\n<td>1,250,229</td>\n<td><span style="visibility:hidden;color:transparent;">0</span><span style="visibility:hidden;color:transparent;">0</span>2.0&#160;%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="text-align:left">other ethnic group</td>\n<td>230,615</td>\n<td>580,374</td>\n<td><span style="visibility:hidden;color:transparent;">0</span><span style="visibility:hidden;color:transparent;">0</span>0.9&#160;%\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan="2" style="text-align:left"><b>Total</b></td>\n<td><b>58,789,194</b></td>\n<td><b>63,182,178</b></td>\n<td><b>100.0&#160;%</b>\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Languages of the United Kingdom">Languages of the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:402px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Anglospeak.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1468" data-file-width="2664" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Anglospeak.png/400px-Anglospeak.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Anglospeak.png/600px-Anglospeak.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Anglospeak.png/800px-Anglospeak.png 2x" width="400"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Anglospeak.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/English-speaking_world" title="English-speaking world">English-speaking world</a>. States and territories in dark blue have a majority of native speakers, while those where English is an official but not a majority language are shaded in light blue. English is also one of the official languages <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_the_European_Union" title="Languages of the European Union">of the European Union</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EUlang_392-0"><a href="#cite_note-EUlang-392">[375]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Official_languages_of_the_United_Nations" title="Official languages of the United Nations">the United Nations</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393"><a href="#cite_note-393">[376]</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>The UK\'s <i>de facto</i> official language is English.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-direct.gov.uk_394-0"><a href="#cite_note-direct.gov.uk-394">[377]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-thecommonwealth.org_395-0"><a href="#cite_note-thecommonwealth.org-395">[378]</a></sup> It is estimated that 95% of the UK\'s population are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Monolingual" title="Monolingual">monolingual</a> English speakers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_languages_396-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_languages-396">[379]</a></sup> 5.5% of the population are estimated to speak languages brought to the UK as a result of relatively recent immigration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_languages_396-1"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_languages-396">[379]</a></sup> South Asian languages, including <a href="/wiki/Punjabi_language" title="Punjabi language">Punjabi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hindi" title="Hindi">Hindi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bengali_language" title="Bengali language">Bengali</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gujarati_language" title="Gujarati language">Gujarati</a>, are the largest grouping and are spoken by 2.7% of the UK population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_languages_396-2"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_languages-396">[379]</a></sup> According to the 2011 census, <a href="/wiki/Polish_language" title="Polish language">Polish</a> has become the second-largest language spoken in England and has 546,000 speakers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[380]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Four <a href="/wiki/Celtic_languages" title="Celtic languages">Celtic languages</a> are spoken in the UK: <a href="/wiki/Welsh_language" title="Welsh language">Welsh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Irish_language" title="Irish language">Irish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Gaelic" title="Scottish Gaelic">Scottish Gaelic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cornish_language" title="Cornish language">Cornish</a>. All are recognised as regional or minority languages, by the European Union, under the <a href="/wiki/European_Charter_for_Regional_or_Minority_Languages" title="European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages">European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Framework_Convention_for_the_Protection_of_National_Minorities" title="Framework Convention for the Protection of National Minorities">Framework Convention for the Protection of National Minorities</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[381]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-reglang_4-1"><a href="#cite_note-reglang-4">[2]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[382]</a></sup> As it is an EU member state, this therefore obliges the UK government to provide them specific measures of protection and promotion. In the 2001 Census over a fifth (21%) of the population of Wales said they could speak Welsh,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[383]</a></sup> an increase from the 1991 Census (18%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[384]</a></sup> In addition it is estimated that about 200,000 Welsh speakers live in England.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[385]</a></sup> In the same census in Northern Ireland 167,487 people (10.4%) stated that they had "some knowledge of Irish" (see <a href="/wiki/Irish_language_in_Northern_Ireland" title="Irish language in Northern Ireland">Irish language in Northern Ireland</a>), almost exclusively in the <a href="/wiki/Irish_nationalism" title="Irish nationalism">nationalist</a> (mainly Catholic) population. Over 92,000 people in Scotland (just under 2% of the population) had some Gaelic language ability, including 72% of those living in the <a href="/wiki/Outer_Hebrides" title="Outer Hebrides">Outer Hebrides</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403"><a href="#cite_note-403">[386]</a></sup> The number of schoolchildren being taught through Welsh, Scottish Gaelic and Irish is increasing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404"><a href="#cite_note-404">[387]</a></sup> Among emigrant-descended populations some Scottish Gaelic is still <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Gaelic" title="Canadian Gaelic">spoken in Canada</a> (principally <a href="/wiki/Nova_Scotia" title="Nova Scotia">Nova Scotia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cape_Breton_Island" title="Cape Breton Island">Cape Breton Island</a>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Edwards2010_405-0"><a href="#cite_note-Edwards2010-405">[388]</a></sup> and Welsh in <a href="/wiki/Patagonia" title="Patagonia">Patagonia</a>, Argentina.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Koch2006_406-0"><a href="#cite_note-Koch2006-406">[389]</a></sup>\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Scots_language" title="Scots language">Scots</a>, a language descended from early northern <a href="/wiki/Middle_English" title="Middle English">Middle English</a>, has limited <a href="/wiki/European_Charter_for_Regional_or_Minority_Languages" title="European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages">recognition</a> alongside its regional variant, <a href="/wiki/Ulster_Scots_dialects" title="Ulster Scots dialects">Ulster Scots</a> in Northern Ireland, without specific commitments to protection and promotion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-reglang_4-2"><a href="#cite_note-reglang-4">[2]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407"><a href="#cite_note-407">[390]</a></sup>\n</p><p>It is compulsory for pupils to study a second language up to the age of 14 in England.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408"><a href="#cite_note-408">[391]</a></sup> French and German are the two most commonly taught second languages in England and Scotland. All pupils in Wales are taught Welsh as a second language up to age 16, or are <a href="/wiki/Welsh_medium_education" title="Welsh medium education">taught in Welsh</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409">[392]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Religion in the United Kingdom">Religion in the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:West_Side_of_Westminster_Abbey,_London_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1406999.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="640" data-file-width="481" decoding="async" height="226" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/West_Side_of_Westminster_Abbey%2C_London_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1406999.jpg/170px-West_Side_of_Westminster_Abbey%2C_London_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1406999.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/West_Side_of_Westminster_Abbey%2C_London_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1406999.jpg/255px-West_Side_of_Westminster_Abbey%2C_London_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1406999.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/West_Side_of_Westminster_Abbey%2C_London_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1406999.jpg/340px-West_Side_of_Westminster_Abbey%2C_London_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1406999.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:West_Side_of_Westminster_Abbey,_London_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1406999.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Westminster_Abbey" title="Westminster Abbey">Westminster Abbey</a> is used for the <a href="/wiki/Coronation" title="Coronation">coronation</a> of <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Monarchy of the United Kingdom">British monarchs</a></div></div></div>\n<p>Forms of Christianity have dominated religious life in what is now the United Kingdom for over 1400 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410"><a href="#cite_note-410">[393]</a></sup> Although a majority of citizens still identify with Christianity in many surveys, regular church attendance has fallen dramatically since the middle of the 20th century,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[394]</a></sup> while immigration and demographic change have contributed to the growth of other faiths, most notably Islam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412"><a href="#cite_note-412">[395]</a></sup> This has led some commentators to variously describe the UK as a multi-faith,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413"><a href="#cite_note-413">[396]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Secularism" title="Secularism">secularised</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[397]</a></sup> or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Post-Christian" title="Post-Christian">post-Christian</a> society.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[398]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Neasden_Temple_-_Shree_Swaminarayan_Hindu_Mandir_-_Gate.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1631" data-file-width="2223" decoding="async" height="183" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Neasden_Temple_-_Shree_Swaminarayan_Hindu_Mandir_-_Gate.jpg/250px-Neasden_Temple_-_Shree_Swaminarayan_Hindu_Mandir_-_Gate.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Neasden_Temple_-_Shree_Swaminarayan_Hindu_Mandir_-_Gate.jpg/375px-Neasden_Temple_-_Shree_Swaminarayan_Hindu_Mandir_-_Gate.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Neasden_Temple_-_Shree_Swaminarayan_Hindu_Mandir_-_Gate.jpg/500px-Neasden_Temple_-_Shree_Swaminarayan_Hindu_Mandir_-_Gate.jpg 2x" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Neasden_Temple_-_Shree_Swaminarayan_Hindu_Mandir_-_Gate.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/BAPS_Shri_Swaminarayan_Mandir_London" title="BAPS Shri Swaminarayan Mandir London">BAPS Shri Swaminarayan Mandir in London, United Kingdom</a> is the largest <a href="/wiki/Hindu_temple" title="Hindu temple">Hindu temple</a> in the United Kingdom.</div></div></div>\n<p>In the 2001 census 71.6% of all respondents indicated that they were Christians, with the next largest faiths being Islam (2.8%), <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a> (1.0%), <a href="/wiki/Sikhism" title="Sikhism">Sikhism</a> (0.6%), <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a> (0.5%), <a
