href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a> (0.3%) and all other religions (0.3%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-416"><a href="#cite_note-416">[399]</a></sup> 15% of respondents stated that they had <a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">no religion</a>, with a further 7% not stating a religious preference.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-417"><a href="#cite_note-417">[400]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Tearfund" title="Tearfund">Tearfund</a> survey in 2007 showed only one in ten Britons actually attend church weekly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418"><a href="#cite_note-418">[401]</a></sup> Between the 2001 and 2011 census there was a decrease in the number of people who identified as Christian by 12%, whilst the percentage of those reporting no religious affiliation doubled. This contrasted with growth in the other main religious group categories, with the number of Muslims increasing by the most substantial margin to a total of about 5%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Philby_10-1"><a href="#cite_note-Philby-10">[7]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Islam in the United Kingdom">Muslim population</a> has increased from 1.6 million in 2001 to 2.7 million in 2011,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419"><a href="#cite_note-419">[402]</a></sup> making it the second-largest religious group in the United Kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[403]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In a 2016 survey conducted by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Social_Attitudes" title="British Social Attitudes">BSA (British Social Attitudes)</a> on religious affiliation; 53% of respondents indicated \'<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Irreligious" title="Irreligious">no religion\'</a>, while 41% indicated they were Christians, followed by 6% who affiliated with other religions (e.g. <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a>, etc.).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bsa2017_421-0"><a href="#cite_note-bsa2017-421">[404]</a></sup> Among Christians, adherents to the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_England" title="Church of England">Church of England</a> constituted 15%, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Church" title="Roman Catholic Church">Roman Catholic Church</a> &#8211; 9%, other Christians (including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Presbyterians" title="Presbyterians">Presbyterians</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Methodists" title="Methodists">Methodists</a>, other <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestants" title="Protestants">Protestants</a>, as well as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox" title="Eastern Orthodox">Eastern Orthodox</a>) &#8211; 17%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bsa2017_421-1"><a href="#cite_note-bsa2017-421">[404]</a></sup> 71% of young people aged 18&#8211;24 said they had no religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bsa2017_421-2"><a href="#cite_note-bsa2017-421">[404]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Church_of_England" title="Church of England">Church of England</a> is the <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">established church</a> in England.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-422"><a href="#cite_note-422">[405]</a></sup> It retains a <a href="/wiki/Lords_Spiritual" title="Lords Spiritual">representation</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Parliament of the United Kingdom">UK Parliament</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Monarchy of the United Kingdom">British monarch</a> is its <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Governor_of_the_Church_of_England" title="Supreme Governor of the Church of England">Supreme Governor</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[406]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Scotland" title="Religion in Scotland">Scotland</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_Scotland" title="Church of Scotland">Church of Scotland</a> is recognised as the <a href="/wiki/National_church" title="National church">national church</a>. It is not <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">subject to state control</a>, and the British monarch is an ordinary member, required to swear an oath to "maintain and preserve the <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestant Religion</a> and <a href="/wiki/Presbyterian_polity" title="Presbyterian polity">Presbyterian Church Government</a>" upon his or her accession.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-424"><a href="#cite_note-424">[407]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-425"><a href="#cite_note-425">[408]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Church_in_Wales" title="Church in Wales">Church in Wales</a> was disestablished in 1920 and, as the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_Ireland" title="Church of Ireland">Church of Ireland</a> was disestablished in 1870 before the <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_Ireland" title="Partition of Ireland">partition of Ireland</a>, there is no established church in Northern Ireland.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426"><a href="#cite_note-426">[409]</a></sup> Although there are no UK-wide data in the 2001 census on adherence to individual Christian denominations, it has been estimated that 62% of Christians are Anglican, 13.5% <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholic</a>, 6% <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Presbyterian" title="Presbyterian">Presbyterian</a>, 3.4% <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Methodist" title="Methodist">Methodist</a> with small numbers of other Protestant denominations such as <a href="/wiki/Plymouth_Brethren" title="Plymouth Brethren">Plymouth Brethren</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Orthodox</a> churches.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-peach_427-0"><a href="#cite_note-peach-427">[410]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Migration">Migration</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Modern_immigration_to_the_United_Kingdom" title="Modern immigration to the United Kingdom">Modern immigration to the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Foreign-born_population_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Foreign-born population of the United Kingdom">Foreign-born population of the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:United_Kingdom_foreign_born_population_by_country_of_birth.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="415" data-file-width="940" decoding="async" height="132" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/United_Kingdom_foreign_born_population_by_country_of_birth.png/300px-United_Kingdom_foreign_born_population_by_country_of_birth.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/United_Kingdom_foreign_born_population_by_country_of_birth.png/450px-United_Kingdom_foreign_born_population_by_country_of_birth.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/United_Kingdom_foreign_born_population_by_country_of_birth.png/600px-United_Kingdom_foreign_born_population_by_country_of_birth.png 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:United_Kingdom_foreign_born_population_by_country_of_birth.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Estimated foreign-born population by country of birth from April 2007&#160;to March 2008</div></div></div>\n<p>The United Kingdom has experienced successive waves of migration. The <a href="/wiki/Great_Famine_(Ireland)" title="Great Famine (Ireland)">Great Famine</a> in Ireland, then part of the United Kingdom, resulted in perhaps a million people migrating to Great Britain.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-428"><a href="#cite_note-428">[411]</a></sup> Throughout the 19th century a small population of German immigrants built up, numbering 28,644 in England and Wales in 1861. London held around half of this population, and other small communities existed in Manchester, Bradford and elsewhere. The German immigrant community was the largest group until 1891, when it became second to Russian Jews.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-429"><a href="#cite_note-429">[412]</a></sup> England has had small Jewish communities for many centuries, subject to occasional expulsions, but British Jews numbered fewer than 10,000 at the start of the 19th century. After 1881 Russian Jews suffered bitter persecutions, and, out of some 2,000,000 who left Russia by 1914, around 120,000 settled permanently in Britain, overtaking the Germans to be the largest ethnic minority from outside the British Isles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[413]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431">[414]</a></sup> The population had increased to 370,000 by 1938.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-432"><a href="#cite_note-432">[415]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-433"><a href="#cite_note-433">[416]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434"><a href="#cite_note-434">[417]</a></sup> Unable to return to Poland at the end of the Second World War, over 120,000 <a href="/wiki/Polish_Armed_Forces_in_the_West" title="Polish Armed Forces in the West">Polish veterans</a> remained in the UK permanently.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435"><a href="#cite_note-435">[418]</a></sup> After the Second World War, there was significant immigration from the colonies and newly independent former colonies, many from the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean" title="Caribbean">Caribbean</a> and <a href="/wiki/Indian_subcontinent" title="Indian subcontinent">Indian subcontinent</a>, partly as a legacy of empire and partly driven by labour shortages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-436"><a href="#cite_note-436">[419]</a></sup> In 1841, 0.25% of the population of <a href="/wiki/England_and_Wales" title="England and Wales">England and Wales</a> was born in a foreign country. In 1901, 1.5% of the population was foreign born.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-437"><a href="#cite_note-437">[420]</a></sup> By 1931, this figure had risen to 2.6%, and by 1951 it was 4.4%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Coleman2013_438-0"><a href="#cite_note-Coleman2013-438">[421]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 2014 the <a href="/wiki/Net_migration_rate" title="Net migration rate">net increase</a> was 318,000: immigration was 641,000, up from 526,000 in 2013, while the number of people emigrating (for more than 12 months) was 323,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-439"><a href="#cite_note-439">[422]</a></sup> One of the more recent trends in migration has been the arrival of workers from the new EU member states in Eastern Europe, known as the <a href="/wiki/A8_countries" title="A8 countries">A8 countries</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Vargas_373-1"><a href="#cite_note-Vargas-373">[358]</a></sup> Citizens of the European Union, including those of the UK, have the right to live and work in any EU member state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-440"><a href="#cite_note-440">[423]</a></sup> The UK applied temporary restrictions to citizens of Romania and Bulgaria, which joined the EU in January 2007.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-441"><a href="#cite_note-441">[424]</a></sup> Research conducted by the <a href="/wiki/Migration_Policy_Institute" title="Migration Policy Institute">Migration Policy Institute</a> for the <a href="/wiki/Equality_and_Human_Rights_Commission" title="Equality and Human Rights Commission">Equality and Human Rights Commission</a> suggests that, between May 2004 and September 2009, 1.5&#160;million workers migrated from the new EU member states to the UK, two-thirds of them Polish, but that many subsequently returned home, resulting in a net increase in the number of nationals of the new member states in the UK of some 700,000 over that period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MPI_442-0"><a href="#cite_note-MPI-442">[425]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[426]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Late-2000s_recession" title="Late-2000s recession">late-2000s recession</a> in the UK reduced the economic incentive for Poles to migrate to the UK,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444"><a href="#cite_note-444">[427]</a></sup> the migration becoming temporary and circular.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445"><a href="#cite_note-445">[428]</a></sup> In 2009, for the first time since enlargement, more nationals of the eight central and eastern European states that had joined the EU in 2004 left the UK than arrived.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-A8_leaving_446-0"><a href="#cite_note-A8_leaving-446">[429]</a></sup> In 2011, citizens of the new EU member states made up 13% of the immigrants entering the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-447"><a href="#cite_note-447">[430]</a></sup> In 2010, there were 7.0 million foreign-born residents in the UK, corresponding to 11.3% of the total population. Of these, 4.76 million (7.7%) were born outside the EU and 2.24 million (3.6%) were born in another EU Member State.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-448"><a href="#cite_note-448">[431]</a></sup> The proportion of foreign-born people in the UK remains slightly below that of many other European countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-449"><a href="#cite_note-449">[432]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Immigration is now contributing to a rising population<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-450"><a href="#cite_note-450">[433]</a></sup> with arrivals and UK-born children of migrants accounting for about half of the population increase between 1991 and 2001. Over a quarter (27.0%) of live births in 2014 were to mothers born outside the UK, according to official statistics released in 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-451"><a href="#cite_note-451">[434]</a></sup> Analysis of <a href="/wiki/Office_for_National_Statistics" title="Office for National Statistics">Office for National Statistics</a> (ONS) data shows that a net total of 2.3&#160;million migrants moved to the UK in the 15 years from 1991 to 2006.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-452"><a href="#cite_note-452">[435]</a></sup> The ONS reported that net migration rose from 2009 to 2010 by 21% to 239,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-453"><a href="#cite_note-453">[436]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 2013, approximately 208,000 foreign nationals were naturalised as British citizens, the highest number since records began in 1962. This figure fell to around 125,800 in 2014. Between 2009 and 2013, the average number of people granted British citizenship per year was 195,800. The main countries of previous nationality of those naturalised in 2014 were <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nigeria" title="Nigeria">Nigeria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepal</a>, China, South Africa, <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Poland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Somalia" title="Somalia">Somalia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Blinder2015_454-0"><a href="#cite_note-Blinder2015-454">[437]</a></sup> The total number of grants of settlement, which confers <a href="/wiki/Permanent_residency" title="Permanent residency">permanent residence</a> in the UK without granting British citizenship,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-455"><a href="#cite_note-455">[438]</a></sup> was approximately 154,700 in 2013, compared to 241,200 in 2010 and 129,800 in 2012.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Blinder2015_454-1"><a href="#cite_note-Blinder2015-454">[437]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<table class="wikitable floatright" style="text-align: right; width: 200px;">\n<tbody><tr>\n<th>Year\n</th>\n<th>Foreign born population of England and Wales\n</th>\n<th>Total population<br/><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Coleman2013_438-1"><a href="#cite_note-Coleman2013-438">[421]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-456"><a href="#cite_note-456">[439]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-457"><a href="#cite_note-457">[440]</a></sup><br/><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-458"><a href="#cite_note-458">[441]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-459"><a href="#cite_note-459">[442]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-460"><a href="#cite_note-460">[443]</a></sup>\n</th>\n<th>Irish born population\n</th>\n<th>Percentage of total population that was born abroad\n</th></tr>\n<tr>\n<th>1851\n</th>\n<td>100,000\n</td>\n<td>17,900,000\n</td>\n<td>520,000\n</td>\n<td>0.6\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th>1861\n</th>\n<td>150,000\n</td>\n<td>20,100,000\n</td>\n<td>600,000\n</td>\n<td>0.7\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th>1871\n</th>\n<td>200,000\n</td>\n<td>22,700,000\n</td>\n<td>565,000\n</td>\n<td>0.9\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th>1881\n</th>\n<td>275,000\n</td>\n<td>26,000,000\n</td>\n<td>560,000\n</td>\n<td>1.1\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th>1891\n</th>\n<td>350,000\n</td>\n<td>29,000,000\n</td>\n<td>460,000\n</td>\n<td>1.2\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th>1901\n</th>\n<td>475,000\n</td>\n<td>32,500,000\n</td>\n<td>425,000\n</td>\n<td>1.5\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th>1911\n</th>\n<td>900,000\n</td>\n<td>32,500,000\n</td>\n<td>375,000\n</td>\n<td>2.5\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th>1921\n</th>\n<td>750,000\n</td>\n<td>37,900,000\n</td>\n<td>365,000\n</td>\n<td>2\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th>1931\n</th>\n<td>1,080,000\n</td>\n<td>40,000,000\n</td>\n<td>380,000\n</td>\n<td>2.7\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th>1951\n</th>\n<td>1,875,000\n</td>\n<td>43,700,000\n</td>\n<td>470,000\n</td>\n<td>4.3\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th>1961\n</th>\n<td>2,290,000\n</td>\n<td>46,000,000\n</td>\n<td>645,000\n</td>\n<td>5.0\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th>1971\n</th>\n<td>3,100,000\n</td>\n<td>48,700,000\n</td>\n<td>585,000\n</td>\n<td>6.4\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th>1981\n</th>\n<td>3,220,000\n</td>\n<td>48,500,000\n</td>\n<td>580,000\n</td>\n<td>6.6\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th>1991\n</th>\n<td>3,625,000\n</td>\n<td>49,900,000\n</td>\n<td>570,000\n</td>\n<td>7.3\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th>2001\n</th>\n<td>4,600,000\n</td>\n<td>52,500,000\n</td>\n<td>475,000\n</td>\n<td>8.8\n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<th>2011\n</th>\n<td>7,500,000\n</td>\n<td>56,000,000\n</td>\n<td>400,000\n</td>\n<td>13.4\n</td></tr></tbody></table>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:British_expats_countrymap.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="415" data-file-width="940" decoding="async" height="132" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/British_expats_countrymap.svg/300px-British_expats_countrymap.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/British_expats_countrymap.svg/450px-British_expats_countrymap.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/British_expats_countrymap.svg/600px-British_expats_countrymap.svg.png 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:British_expats_countrymap.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Estimated number of British citizens living overseas by country in 2006</div></div></div>\n<p>The British Government has introduced a <a href="/wiki/Points-based_immigration_system_(United_Kingdom)" title="Points-based immigration system (United Kingdom)">points-based immigration system</a> for immigration from outside the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Area" title="European Economic Area">European Economic Area</a> to replace former schemes, including the Scottish Government\'s <a href="/wiki/Fresh_Talent_Initiative" title="Fresh Talent Initiative">Fresh Talent Initiative</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-461"><a href="#cite_note-461">[444]</a></sup> In June 2010 the government introduced a temporary limit of 24,000 on immigration from outside the EU, aiming to discourage applications before a permanent cap was imposed in April 2011.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-462"><a href="#cite_note-462">[445]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Emigration was an important feature of British society in the 19th century. Between 1815 and 1930 around 11.4&#160;million people emigrated from Britain and 7.3&#160;million from Ireland. Estimates show that by the end of the 20th century some 300&#160;million people of British and Irish descent were permanently settled around the globe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-463"><a href="#cite_note-463">[446]</a></sup> Today, at least 5.5&#160;million UK-born people live abroad,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BritsAbroad_464-0"><a href="#cite_note-BritsAbroad-464">[447]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-465"><a href="#cite_note-465">[448]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-466"><a href="#cite_note-466">[449]</a></sup> mainly in Australia, Spain, the United States and Canada.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BritsAbroad_464-1"><a href="#cite_note-BritsAbroad-464">[447]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-467"><a href="#cite_note-467">[450]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Education in the United Kingdom">Education in the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<p>Education in the United Kingdom is a <a href="/wiki/Devolution" title="Devolution">devolved</a> matter, with each country having a separate education system.\n</p><p>Considering the four systems together, about 38 per cent of the United Kingdom population has a university or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/College_degree" title="College degree">college degree</a>, which is the highest percentage in Europe, and among the highest percentages in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-468"><a href="#cite_note-468">[451]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-469"><a href="#cite_note-469">[452]</a></sup> The United Kingdom trails only the United States in terms of representation on lists of top 100 universities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-470"><a href="#cite_note-470">[453]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-471"><a href="#cite_note-471">[454]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-472"><a href="#cite_note-472">[455]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-473"><a href="#cite_note-473">[456]</a></sup>\n</p><p>A <a href="/wiki/Social_Mobility_and_Child_Poverty_Commission" title="Social Mobility and Child Poverty Commission">government commission\'s</a> report in 2014 found that privately educated people comprise 7% of the general population of the UK but much larger percentages of the top professions, the most extreme case quoted being 71% of senior judges.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SMCPC20140828_474-0"><a href="#cite_note-SMCPC20140828-474">[457]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Guardian20140828_475-0"><a href="#cite_note-Guardian20140828-475">[458]</a></sup>\n</p><p><b>England</b>\n</p>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_England" title="Education in England">Education in England</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tom_Quad,_Christ_Church_2004-01-21.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1011" data-file-width="1819" decoding="async" height="122" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Tom_Quad%2C_Christ_Church_2004-01-21.jpg/220px-Tom_Quad%2C_Christ_Church_2004-01-21.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Tom_Quad%2C_Christ_Church_2004-01-21.jpg/330px-Tom_Quad%2C_Christ_Church_2004-01-21.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Tom_Quad%2C_Christ_Church_2004-01-21.jpg/440px-Tom_Quad%2C_Christ_Church_2004-01-21.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tom_Quad,_Christ_Church_2004-01-21.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Christ_Church,_Oxford" title="Christ Church, Oxford">Christ Church, Oxford</a> is part of the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Oxford" title="University of Oxford">University of Oxford</a>, which traces its foundations back to c. 1096</div></div></div>\n<p>Whilst <a href="/wiki/Education_in_England" title="Education in England">education in England</a> is the responsibility of the <a href="/wiki/Secretary_of_State_for_Education" title="Secretary of State for Education">Secretary of State for Education</a>, the day-to-day administration and funding of state schools is the responsibility of <a href="/wiki/Local_education_authority" title="Local education authority">local authorities</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-476"><a href="#cite_note-476">[459]</a></sup> Universally free of charge state education was introduced piecemeal between 1870 and 1944.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-477"><a href="#cite_note-477">[460]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-478"><a href="#cite_note-478">[461]</a></sup> Education is now mandatory from ages five to sixteen, and in England youngsters must stay in education or training until they are 18.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-479"><a href="#cite_note-479">[462]</a></sup> In 2011, the <a href="/wiki/Trends_in_International_Mathematics_and_Science_Study" title="Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study">Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study</a> (TIMSS) rated 13&#8211;14-year-old pupils in England and Wales 10th in the world for maths and 9th for science.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-480"><a href="#cite_note-480">[463]</a></sup> The majority of children are educated in state-sector schools, a small proportion of which select on the grounds of academic ability. Two of the top ten performing schools in terms of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GCSE" title="GCSE">GCSE</a> results in 2006 were state-run <a href="/wiki/Grammar_school" title="Grammar school">grammar schools</a>. In 2010, over half of places at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Oxford" title="University of Oxford">University of Oxford</a> and the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Cambridge" title="University of Cambridge">University of Cambridge</a> were taken by students from state schools,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-481"><a href="#cite_note-481">[464]</a></sup> while the proportion of children in England attending private schools is around 7% which rises to 18% of those over 16.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-482"><a href="#cite_note-482">[465]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-483"><a href="#cite_note-483">[466]</a></sup> England has the two oldest universities in English-speaking world, Universities of <a href="/wiki/University_of_Oxford" title="University of Oxford">Oxford</a> and <a href="/wiki/University_of_Cambridge" title="University of Cambridge">Cambridge</a> (jointly known as "<a href="/wiki/Oxbridge" title="Oxbridge">Oxbridge</a>") with history of over eight centuries.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>\n</p><p>Since the establishment of <a href="/wiki/Bedford_College,_London" title="Bedford College, London">Bedford College</a> (<a href="/wiki/University_of_London" title="University of London">London</a>), <a href="/wiki/Girton_College,_Cambridge" title="Girton College, Cambridge">Girton College</a> (Cambridge) and <a href="/wiki/Somerville_College,_Oxford" title="Somerville College, Oxford">Somerville College</a> (Oxford) in the <a href="/wiki/19th_century" title="19th century">19th century</a>, women also can obtain a university degree.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:KingsCollegeChapelWest.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1025" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/KingsCollegeChapelWest.jpg/220px-KingsCollegeChapelWest.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/KingsCollegeChapelWest.jpg/330px-KingsCollegeChapelWest.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/KingsCollegeChapelWest.jpg/440px-KingsCollegeChapelWest.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:KingsCollegeChapelWest.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/King%27s_College,_Cambridge" title="King\'s College, Cambridge">King\'s College (right)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Clare_College,_Cambridge" title="Clare College, Cambridge">Clare College (left)</a>, both part of the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Cambridge" title="University of Cambridge">University of Cambridge</a>, which was founded in 1209</div></div></div>\n<p><b>Scotland</b>\n</p>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Scotland" title="Education in Scotland">Education in Scotland</a></div>\n<p><a href="/wiki/Education_in_Scotland" title="Education in Scotland">Education in Scotland</a> is the responsibility of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cabinet_Secretary_for_Education_and_Lifelong_Learning" title="Cabinet Secretary for Education and Lifelong Learning">Cabinet Secretary for Education and Lifelong Learning</a>, with day-to-day administration and funding of state schools the responsibility of Local Authorities. Two <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scottish_public_bodies" title="Scottish public bodies">non-departmental public bodies</a> have key roles in Scottish education. The <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Qualifications_Authority" title="Scottish Qualifications Authority">Scottish Qualifications Authority</a> is responsible for the development, accreditation, assessment and certification of qualifications other than degrees which are delivered at secondary schools, <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_education" title="Tertiary education">post-secondary</a> colleges of <a href="/wiki/Further_education" title="Further education">further education</a> and other centres.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-484"><a href="#cite_note-484">[467]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Learning_and_Teaching_Scotland" title="Learning and Teaching Scotland">Learning and Teaching Scotland</a> provides advice, resources and staff development to education professionals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-485"><a href="#cite_note-485">[468]</a></sup> Scotland first legislated for compulsory education in 1496.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-486"><a href="#cite_note-486">[469]</a></sup> The proportion of children in Scotland attending private schools is just over 4% in 2016, but it has been falling slowly in recent years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-487"><a href="#cite_note-487">[470]</a></sup> Scottish students who attend <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scottish_universities" title="Scottish universities">Scottish universities</a> pay neither <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tuition_fees" title="Tuition fees">tuition fees</a> nor graduate endowment charges, as fees were abolished in 2001 and the graduate endowment scheme was abolished in 2008.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-488"><a href="#cite_note-488">[471]</a></sup>\n</p><p><b>Wales</b>\n</p>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Wales" title="Education in Wales">Education in Wales</a></div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/Welsh_Government" title="Welsh Government">Welsh Government</a> has responsibility for <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Wales" title="Education in Wales">education in Wales</a>. A significant number of Welsh students are taught either wholly or largely in the <a href="/wiki/Welsh_language" title="Welsh language">Welsh language</a>; lessons in Welsh are compulsory for all until the age of 16.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-489"><a href="#cite_note-489">[472]</a></sup> There are plans to increase the provision of Welsh-medium schools as part of the policy of creating a fully bilingual Wales.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>\n</p><p><b>Northern Ireland</b>\n</p>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Northern_Ireland" title="Education in Northern Ireland">Education in Northern Ireland</a></div>\n<p><a href="/wiki/Education_in_Northern_Ireland" title="Education in Northern Ireland">Education in Northern Ireland</a> is the responsibility of the <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Education_(Northern_Ireland)" title="Department of Education (Northern Ireland)">Minister of Education</a>, although responsibility at a local level is administered by the <a href="/wiki/Education_Authority" title="Education Authority">Education Authority</a> which is further sub-divided into five geographical areas. The <a href="/wiki/Council_for_the_Curriculum,_Examinations_%26_Assessment" title="Council for the Curriculum, Examinations &amp; Assessment">Council for the Curriculum, Examinations &amp; Assessment</a> (CCEA) is the body responsible for advising the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Executive" title="Northern Ireland Executive">government</a> on what should be taught in Northern Ireland\'s schools, monitoring standards and awarding qualifications.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-490"><a href="#cite_note-490">[473]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Healthcare">Healthcare</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Healthcare in the United Kingdom">Healthcare in the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:15th_Sep_2012-Abdn_Children%27s_Hosp_%26_Emergency_Care_Centre_10.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3216" data-file-width="4288" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/15th_Sep_2012-Abdn_Children%27s_Hosp_%26_Emergency_Care_Centre_10.JPG/220px-15th_Sep_2012-Abdn_Children%27s_Hosp_%26_Emergency_Care_Centre_10.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/15th_Sep_2012-Abdn_Children%27s_Hosp_%26_Emergency_Care_Centre_10.JPG/330px-15th_Sep_2012-Abdn_Children%27s_Hosp_%26_Emergency_Care_Centre_10.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/15th_Sep_2012-Abdn_Children%27s_Hosp_%26_Emergency_Care_Centre_10.JPG/440px-15th_Sep_2012-Abdn_Children%27s_Hosp_%26_Emergency_Care_Centre_10.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:15th_Sep_2012-Abdn_Children%27s_Hosp_%26_Emergency_Care_Centre_10.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Royal_Aberdeen_Children%27s_Hospital" title="Royal Aberdeen Children\'s Hospital">Royal Aberdeen Children\'s Hospital</a>, an <a href="/wiki/NHS_Scotland" title="NHS Scotland">NHS Scotland</a> specialist <a href="/wiki/Children%27s_hospital" title="Children\'s hospital">children\'s hospital</a></div></div></div>\n<p>Healthcare in the United Kingdom is a <a href="/wiki/Devolution" title="Devolution">devolved matter</a> and each country has its own system of private and <a href="/wiki/Publicly_funded_health_care" title="Publicly funded health care">publicly funded health care</a>, together with <a href="/wiki/Alternative_medicine" title="Alternative medicine">alternative</a>, holistic and complementary treatments. Public healthcare is provided to all <a href="/wiki/British_nationality_law" title="British nationality law">UK permanent residents</a> and is mostly free at the point of need, being paid for from general taxation. The <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a>, in 2000, ranked the provision of healthcare in the United Kingdom as fifteenth best in Europe and eighteenth in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Who2000_491-0"><a href="#cite_note-Who2000-491">[474]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-492"><a href="#cite_note-492">[475]</a></sup> Since 1979 expenditure on healthcare has been increased significantly to bring it closer to the European Union average.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-493"><a href="#cite_note-493">[476]</a></sup> The UK spends around 8.4% of its gross domestic product on healthcare, which is 0.5 percentage points below the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a> average and about one percentage point below the average of the European Union.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-494"><a href="#cite_note-494">[477]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Regulatory bodies are organised on a UK-wide basis such as the <a href="/wiki/General_Medical_Council" title="General Medical Council">General Medical Council</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Nursing_and_Midwifery_Council" title="Nursing and Midwifery Council">Nursing and Midwifery Council</a> and non-governmental-based, such as the <a href="/wiki/Royal_College" title="Royal College">Royal Colleges</a>. However, political and operational responsibility for healthcare lies with four national <a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">executives</a>; <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_England" title="Healthcare in England">healthcare in England</a> is the responsibility of the UK Government; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Northern_Ireland" title="Healthcare in Northern Ireland">healthcare in Northern Ireland</a> is the responsibility of the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Executive" title="Northern Ireland Executive">Northern Ireland Executive</a>; <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Scotland" title="Healthcare in Scotland">healthcare in Scotland</a> is the responsibility of the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Government" title="Scottish Government">Scottish Government</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Wales" title="Healthcare in Wales">healthcare in Wales</a> is the responsibility of the <a href="/wiki/Welsh_Government" title="Welsh Government">Welsh Government</a>. Each <a href="/wiki/National_Health_Service" title="National Health Service">National Health Service</a> has different policies and priorities, resulting in contrasts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-495"><a href="#cite_note-495">[478]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-496"><a href="#cite_note-496">[479]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Culture of the United Kingdom">Culture of the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<p>The culture of the United Kingdom has been influenced by many factors including: the nation\'s island status; its <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="History of the United Kingdom">history</a> as a western liberal democracy and a major power; as well as being a <a href="/wiki/Political_union" title="Political union">political union</a> of four countries with each preserving elements of distinctive traditions, customs and symbolism. As a result of the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a>, British influence can be observed in the <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">language</a>, <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Culture of the United Kingdom">culture</a> and <a href="/wiki/Common_law" title="Common law">legal systems</a> of many of its former colonies including Australia, Canada, India, Ireland, New Zealand, Pakistan, South Africa and the United States. The substantial cultural influence of the United Kingdom has led it to be described as a "cultural superpower".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-culture_135-1"><a href="#cite_note-culture-135">[123]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sheridan_136-1"><a href="#cite_note-sheridan-136">[124]</a></sup> A global opinion poll for the BBC saw the United Kingdom ranked the third most positively viewed nation in the world (behind Germany and Canada) in 2013 and 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-497"><a href="#cite_note-497">[480]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-498"><a href="#cite_note-498">[481]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/British_literature" title="British literature">British literature</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:William_Shakespeare_Chandos_Portrait.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="513" data-file-width="400" decoding="async" height="218" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/William_Shakespeare_Chandos_Portrait.jpg/170px-William_Shakespeare_Chandos_Portrait.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/William_Shakespeare_Chandos_Portrait.jpg/255px-William_Shakespeare_Chandos_Portrait.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/William_Shakespeare_Chandos_Portrait.jpg/340px-William_Shakespeare_Chandos_Portrait.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:William_Shakespeare_Chandos_Portrait.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Chandos_portrait" title="Chandos portrait">Chandos portrait</a>, believed to depict <a href="/wiki/William_Shakespeare" title="William Shakespeare">William Shakespeare</a></div></div></div>\n<p>"British literature" refers to literature associated with the United Kingdom, the <a href="/wiki/Isle_of_Man" title="Isle of Man">Isle of Man</a> and the Channel Islands. Most British literature is in the English language. In 2005, some 206,000 books were published in the United Kingdom and in 2006 it was the <a href="/wiki/Books_published_per_country_per_year" title="Books published per country per year">largest publisher of books</a> in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Reuters_499-0"><a href="#cite_note-Reuters-499">[482]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The English playwright and poet <a href="/wiki/William_Shakespeare" title="William Shakespeare">William Shakespeare</a> is widely regarded as the greatest dramatist of all time,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-500"><a href="#cite_note-500">[483]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-501"><a href="#cite_note-501">[484]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-502"><a href="#cite_note-502">[485]</a></sup> and his contemporaries <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Marlowe" title="Christopher Marlowe">Christopher Marlowe</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ben_Jonson" title="Ben Jonson">Ben Jonson</a> have also been held in continuous high esteem. More recently the playwrights <a href="/wiki/Alan_Ayckbourn" title="Alan Ayckbourn">Alan Ayckbourn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Harold_Pinter" title="Harold Pinter">Harold Pinter</a>, <a href="/wiki/Michael_Frayn" title="Michael Frayn">Michael Frayn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tom_Stoppard" title="Tom Stoppard">Tom Stoppard</a> and <a href="/wiki/David_Edgar_(playwright)" title="David Edgar (playwright)">David Edgar</a> have combined elements of surrealism, realism and radicalism.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>\n</p><p>Notable pre-modern and early-modern English writers include <a href="/wiki/Geoffrey_Chaucer" title="Geoffrey Chaucer">Geoffrey Chaucer</a> (14th century), <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Malory" title="Thomas Malory">Thomas Malory</a> (15th century), <a href="/wiki/Thomas_More" title="Thomas More">Sir Thomas More</a> (16th century), <a href="/wiki/John_Bunyan" title="John Bunyan">John Bunyan</a> (17th century) and <a href="/wiki/John_Milton" title="John Milton">John Milton</a> (17th century).<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> In the 18th century <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Defoe" title="Daniel Defoe">Daniel Defoe</a> (author of <i><a href="/wiki/Robinson_Crusoe" title="Robinson Crusoe">Robinson Crusoe</a></i>) and <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Richardson" title="Samuel Richardson">Samuel Richardson</a> were pioneers of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Modern_novel" title="Modern novel">modern novel</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> In the 19th century there followed further innovation by <a href="/wiki/Jane_Austen" title="Jane Austen">Jane Austen</a>, the gothic novelist <a href="/wiki/Mary_Shelley" title="Mary Shelley">Mary Shelley</a>, the children\'s writer <a href="/wiki/Lewis_Carroll" title="Lewis Carroll">Lewis Carroll</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Bront%C3%AB_family" title="Bront&#235; family">Bront&#235; sisters</a>, the social campaigner <a href="/wiki/Charles_Dickens" title="Charles Dickens">Charles Dickens</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Naturalism_(literature)" title="Naturalism (literature)">naturalist</a> <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Hardy" title="Thomas Hardy">Thomas Hardy</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Literary_realism" title="Literary realism">realist</a> <a href="/wiki/George_Eliot" title="George Eliot">George Eliot</a>, the visionary poet <a href="/wiki/William_Blake" title="William Blake">William Blake</a> and <a href="/wiki/Romanticism" title="Romanticism">Romantic</a> poet <a href="/wiki/William_Wordsworth" title="William Wordsworth">William Wordsworth</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> 20th-century English writers include the science-fiction novelist <a href="/wiki/H._G._Wells" title="H. G. Wells">H. G. Wells</a>; the writers of children\'s classics <a href="/wiki/Rudyard_Kipling" title="Rudyard Kipling">Rudyard Kipling</a>, <a href="/wiki/A._A._Milne" title="A. A. Milne">A. A. Milne</a> (the creator of <a href="/wiki/Winnie-the-Pooh" title="Winnie-the-Pooh">Winnie-the-Pooh</a>), <a href="/wiki/Roald_Dahl" title="Roald Dahl">Roald Dahl</a> and <a href="/wiki/Enid_Blyton" title="Enid Blyton">Enid Blyton</a>; the controversial <a href="/wiki/D._H._Lawrence" title="D. H. Lawrence">D. H. Lawrence</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Modernism" title="Modernism">modernist</a> <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Woolf" title="Virginia Woolf">Virginia Woolf</a>; the satirist <a href="/wiki/Evelyn_Waugh" title="Evelyn Waugh">Evelyn Waugh</a>; the prophetic novelist <a href="/wiki/George_Orwell" title="George Orwell">George Orwell</a>; the popular novelists <a href="/wiki/W._Somerset_Maugham" title="W. Somerset Maugham">W. Somerset Maugham</a> and <a href="/wiki/Graham_Greene" title="Graham Greene">Graham Greene</a>;<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> the crime writer <a href="/wiki/Agatha_Christie" title="Agatha Christie">Agatha Christie</a> (the <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_fiction_authors" title="List of best-selling fiction authors">best-selling novelist</a> of all time);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-503"><a href="#cite_note-503">[486]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ian_Fleming" title="Ian Fleming">Ian Fleming</a> (the creator of <a href="/wiki/James_Bond" title="James Bond">James Bond</a>); the poets <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/T.S._Eliot" title="T.S. Eliot">T.S. Eliot</a>, <a href="/wiki/Philip_Larkin" title="Philip Larkin">Philip Larkin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ted_Hughes" title="Ted Hughes">Ted Hughes</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Fantasy_literature" title="Fantasy literature">fantasy</a> writers <a href="/wiki/J._R._R._Tolkien" title="J. R. R. Tolkien">J. R. R. Tolkien</a>, <a href="/wiki/C._S._Lewis" title="C. S. Lewis">C. S. Lewis</a> and <a href="/wiki/J._K._Rowling" title="J. K. Rowling">J. K. Rowling</a>; the graphic novelists <a href="/wiki/Alan_Moore" title="Alan Moore">Alan Moore</a> and <a href="/wiki/Neil_Gaiman" title="Neil Gaiman">Neil Gaiman</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dickens_by_Watkins_1858.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="786" data-file-width="626" decoding="async" height="213" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Dickens_by_Watkins_1858.png/170px-Dickens_by_Watkins_1858.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Dickens_by_Watkins_1858.png/255px-Dickens_by_Watkins_1858.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Dickens_by_Watkins_1858.png/340px-Dickens_by_Watkins_1858.png 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Dickens_by_Watkins_1858.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A photograph of <a href="/wiki/Victorian_era" title="Victorian era">Victorian-era</a> novelist <a href="/wiki/Charles_Dickens" title="Charles Dickens">Charles Dickens</a></div></div></div>\n<p><a href="/wiki/Scottish_literature" title="Scottish literature">Scotland\'s contributions</a> include the detective writer <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Conan_Doyle" title="Arthur Conan Doyle">Arthur Conan Doyle</a> (the creator of <a href="/wiki/Sherlock_Holmes" title="Sherlock Holmes">Sherlock Holmes</a>), romantic literature by <a href="/wiki/Walter_Scott" title="Walter Scott">Sir Walter Scott</a>, the children\'s writer <a href="/wiki/J._M._Barrie" title="J. M. Barrie">J. M. Barrie</a>, the epic adventures of <a href="/wiki/Robert_Louis_Stevenson" title="Robert Louis Stevenson">Robert Louis Stevenson</a> and the celebrated poet <a href="/wiki/Robert_Burns" title="Robert Burns">Robert Burns</a>. More recently the modernist and nationalist <a href="/wiki/Hugh_MacDiarmid" title="Hugh MacDiarmid">Hugh MacDiarmid</a> and <a href="/wiki/Neil_M._Gunn" title="Neil M. Gunn">Neil M. Gunn</a> contributed to the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Renaissance" title="Scottish Renaissance">Scottish Renaissance</a>. A more grim outlook is found in <a href="/wiki/Ian_Rankin" title="Ian Rankin">Ian Rankin</a>\'s stories and the psychological horror-comedy of <a href="/wiki/Iain_Banks" title="Iain Banks">Iain Banks</a>. Scotland\'s capital, Edinburgh, was UNESCO\'s first worldwide <a href="/wiki/City_of_Literature" title="City of Literature">City of Literature</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-504"><a href="#cite_note-504">[487]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Britain\'s oldest known poem, <i><a href="/wiki/Y_Gododdin" title="Y Gododdin">Y Gododdin</a></i>, was composed in <i><a href="/wiki/Hen_Ogledd" title="Hen Ogledd">Yr Hen Ogledd</a></i> (<i>The Old North</i>), most likely in the late 6th century. It was written in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cumbric_language" title="Cumbric language">Cumbric</a> or <a href="/wiki/Old_Welsh" title="Old Welsh">Old Welsh</a> and contains the earliest known reference to <a href="/wiki/King_Arthur" title="King Arthur">King Arthur</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-505"><a href="#cite_note-505">[488]</a></sup> From around the seventh century, the connection between Wales and the Old North was lost, and the focus of Welsh-language culture shifted to Wales, where Arthurian legend was further developed by <a href="/wiki/Geoffrey_of_Monmouth" title="Geoffrey of Monmouth">Geoffrey of Monmouth</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-506"><a href="#cite_note-506">[489]</a></sup> Wales\'s most celebrated medieval poet, <a href="/wiki/Dafydd_ap_Gwilym" title="Dafydd ap Gwilym">Dafydd ap Gwilym</a> (<i>fl.</i>1320&#8211;1370), composed poetry on themes including nature, religion and especially love. He is widely regarded as one of the greatest European poets of his age.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-507"><a href="#cite_note-507">[490]</a></sup> Until the late 19th century the majority of <a href="/wiki/Welsh_literature" title="Welsh literature">Welsh literature</a> was in Welsh and much of the prose was religious in character. <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Owen" title="Daniel Owen">Daniel Owen</a> is credited as the first Welsh-language novelist, publishing <i><a href="/wiki/Rhys_Lewis_(novel)" title="Rhys Lewis (novel)">Rhys Lewis</a></i> in 1885. The best-known of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anglo-Welsh_poetry" title="Anglo-Welsh poetry">Anglo-Welsh poets</a> are both Thomases. <a href="/wiki/Dylan_Thomas" title="Dylan Thomas">Dylan Thomas</a> became famous on both sides of the Atlantic in the mid-20th century. He is remembered for his poetry&#8212;his "<a href="/wiki/Do_not_go_gentle_into_that_good_night" title="Do not go gentle into that good night">Do not go gentle into that good night</a>; Rage, rage against the dying of the light" is one of the most quoted couplets of English language verse&#8212;and for his "play for voices", <i><a href="/wiki/Under_Milk_Wood" title="Under Milk Wood">Under Milk Wood</a></i>. The influential <a href="/wiki/Church_in_Wales" title="Church in Wales">Church in Wales</a> "poet-priest" and <a href="/wiki/Welsh_nationalism" title="Welsh nationalism">Welsh nationalist</a> <a href="/wiki/R._S._Thomas" title="R. S. Thomas">R. S. Thomas</a> was nominated for the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">Nobel Prize in Literature</a> in 1996. Leading Welsh novelists of the twentieth century include <a href="/wiki/Richard_Llewellyn" title="Richard Llewellyn">Richard Llewellyn</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kate_Roberts_(author)" title="Kate Roberts (author)">Kate Roberts</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-508"><a href="#cite_note-508">[491]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-509"><a href="#cite_note-509">[492]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Authors of other nationalities, particularly from <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">Commonwealth</a> countries, the Republic of Ireland and the United States, have lived and worked in the UK. Significant examples through the centuries include <a href="/wiki/Jonathan_Swift" title="Jonathan Swift">Jonathan Swift</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oscar_Wilde" title="Oscar Wilde">Oscar Wilde</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bram_Stoker" title="Bram Stoker">Bram Stoker</a>, <a href="/wiki/George_Bernard_Shaw" title="George Bernard Shaw">George Bernard Shaw</a>, <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Conrad" title="Joseph Conrad">Joseph Conrad</a>, <a href="/wiki/T._S._Eliot" title="T. S. Eliot">T. S. Eliot</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ezra_Pound" title="Ezra Pound">Ezra Pound</a> and, more recently, British authors born abroad such as <a href="/wiki/Kazuo_Ishiguro" title="Kazuo Ishiguro">Kazuo Ishiguro</a> and <a href="/wiki/Salman_Rushdie" title="Salman Rushdie">Sir Salman Rushdie</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-510"><a href="#cite_note-510">[493]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-511"><a href="#cite_note-511">[494]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Music of the United Kingdom">Music of the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rock_music_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Rock music in the United Kingdom">Rock music in the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Fabs.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1110" data-file-width="1110" decoding="async" height="170" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/The_Fabs.JPG/170px-The_Fabs.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/The_Fabs.JPG/255px-The_Fabs.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/The_Fabs.JPG/340px-The_Fabs.JPG 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Fabs.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/The_Beatles" title="The Beatles">The Beatles</a> are the most commercially successful and critically acclaimed band in popular music, selling over a billion records<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Beatles_sales_512-0"><a href="#cite_note-Beatles_sales-512">[495]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McCartney_513-0"><a href="#cite_note-McCartney-513">[496]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Guinness_514-0"><a href="#cite_note-Guinness-514">[497]</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>Various styles of music are popular in the UK from the indigenous <a href="/wiki/Folk_music" title="Folk music">folk music</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Folk_music_of_England" title="Folk music of England">England</a>, <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Wales#Folk_music" title="Music of Wales">Wales</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Folk_music_of_Scotland" title="Folk music of Scotland">Scotland</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Folk_music_of_Northern_Ireland" title="Folk music of Northern Ireland">Northern Ireland</a> to <a href="/wiki/Heavy_metal_music" title="Heavy metal music">heavy metal</a>. Notable composers of classical music from the United Kingdom and the countries that preceded it include <a href="/wiki/William_Byrd" title="William Byrd">William Byrd</a>, <a href="/wiki/Henry_Purcell" title="Henry Purcell">Henry Purcell</a>, <a href="/wiki/Edward_Elgar" title="Edward Elgar">Sir Edward Elgar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gustav_Holst" title="Gustav Holst">Gustav Holst</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Sullivan" title="Arthur Sullivan">Sir Arthur Sullivan</a> (most famous for working with the librettist <a href="/wiki/W._S._Gilbert" title="W. S. Gilbert">Sir W. S. Gilbert</a>), <a href="/wiki/Ralph_Vaughan_Williams" title="Ralph Vaughan Williams">Ralph Vaughan Williams</a> and <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Britten" title="Benjamin Britten">Benjamin Britten</a>, pioneer of modern British opera. <a href="/wiki/Harrison_Birtwistle" title="Harrison Birtwistle">Sir Harrison Birtwistle</a> is one of the foremost living composers. The UK is also home to world-renowned symphonic orchestras and choruses such as the <a href="/wiki/BBC_Symphony_Orchestra" title="BBC Symphony Orchestra">BBC Symphony Orchestra</a> and the <a href="/wiki/London_Symphony_Chorus" title="London Symphony Chorus">London Symphony Chorus</a>. Notable conductors include <a href="/wiki/Simon_Rattle" title="Simon Rattle">Sir Simon Rattle</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Barbirolli" title="John Barbirolli">Sir John Barbirolli</a> and <a href="/wiki/Malcolm_Sargent" title="Malcolm Sargent">Sir Malcolm Sargent</a>. Some of the notable <a href="/wiki/Film_score" title="Film score">film score</a> composers include <a href="/wiki/John_Barry_(composer)" title="John Barry (composer)">John Barry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Clint_Mansell" title="Clint Mansell">Clint Mansell</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mike_Oldfield" title="Mike Oldfield">Mike Oldfield</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/John_Powell_(composer)" title="John Powell (composer)">John Powell</a>, <a href="/wiki/Craig_Armstrong_(composer)" title="Craig Armstrong (composer)">Craig Armstrong</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Arnold" title="David Arnold">David Arnold</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Murphy_(composer)" title="John Murphy (composer)">John Murphy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Monty_Norman" title="Monty Norman">Monty Norman</a> and <a href="/wiki/Harry_Gregson-Williams" title="Harry Gregson-Williams">Harry Gregson-Williams</a>. <a href="/wiki/George_Frideric_Handel" title="George Frideric Handel">George Frideric Handel</a> became a <a href="/wiki/Naturalization" title="Naturalization">naturalised</a> <a href="/wiki/British_nationality_law" title="British nationality law">British citizen</a> and wrote the British coronation anthem, while some of his best works, such as <i><a href="/wiki/Messiah_(Handel)" title="Messiah (Handel)">Messiah</a></i>, were written in the English language.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Handel_515-0"><a href="#cite_note-Handel-515">[498]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-516"><a href="#cite_note-516">[499]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Lloyd_Webber" title="Andrew Lloyd Webber">Andrew Lloyd Webber</a> is a prolific composer of musical theatre. His works have dominated London\'s <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/West_End_Theatre" title="West End Theatre">West End</a> since the late 20th century and have also been a commercial success worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-517"><a href="#cite_note-517">[500]</a></sup>\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/The_Beatles" title="The Beatles">The Beatles</a> have international sales of over one billion units and are the <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_music_artists" title="List of best-selling music artists">biggest-selling</a> and most influential band in the history of popular music.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Beatles_sales_512-1"><a href="#cite_note-Beatles_sales-512">[495]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McCartney_513-1"><a href="#cite_note-McCartney-513">[496]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Guinness_514-1"><a href="#cite_note-Guinness-514">[497]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-518"><a href="#cite_note-518">[501]</a></sup> Other prominent British contributors to have influenced popular music over the last 50 years include <a href="/wiki/The_Rolling_Stones" title="The Rolling Stones">The Rolling Stones</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pink_Floyd" title="Pink Floyd">Pink Floyd</a>, <a href="/wiki/Queen_(band)" title="Queen (band)">Queen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Led_Zeppelin" title="Led Zeppelin">Led Zeppelin</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Bee_Gees" title="Bee Gees">Bee Gees</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Elton_John" title="Elton John">Elton John</a>, all of whom have worldwide record sales of 200&#160;million or more.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-519"><a href="#cite_note-519">[502]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-520"><a href="#cite_note-520">[503]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-521"><a href="#cite_note-521">[504]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-522"><a href="#cite_note-522">[505]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-523"><a href="#cite_note-523">[506]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-524"><a href="#cite_note-524">[507]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Brit_Awards" title="Brit Awards">Brit Awards</a> are the <a href="/wiki/British_Phonographic_Industry" title="British Phonographic Industry">BPI\'s</a> annual music awards, and some of the British recipients of the Outstanding Contribution to Music award include; <a href="/wiki/The_Who" title="The Who">The Who</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Bowie" title="David Bowie">David Bowie</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eric_Clapton" title="Eric Clapton">Eric Clapton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rod_Stewart" title="Rod Stewart">Rod Stewart</a> and <a href="/wiki/The_Police" title="The Police">The Police</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-525"><a href="#cite_note-525">[508]</a></sup> More recent UK music acts that have had international success include <a href="/wiki/Coldplay" title="Coldplay">Coldplay</a>, <a href="/wiki/Radiohead" title="Radiohead">Radiohead</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oasis_(band)" title="Oasis (band)">Oasis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arctic_Monkeys" title="Arctic Monkeys">Arctic Monkeys</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spice_Girls" title="Spice Girls">Spice Girls</a>, <a href="/wiki/Robbie_Williams" title="Robbie Williams">Robbie Williams</a>, <a href="/wiki/Amy_Winehouse" title="Amy Winehouse">Amy Winehouse</a> and <a href="/wiki/Adele" title="Adele">Adele</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-526"><a href="#cite_note-526">[509]</a></sup>\n</p><p>A number of UK cities are known for their music. Acts from <a href="/wiki/Liverpool" title="Liverpool">Liverpool</a> have had 54 UK chart number one hit singles, more per capita than any other city worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Liverpool_vs_Stavanger_527-0"><a href="#cite_note-Liverpool_vs_Stavanger-527">[510]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Glasgow" title="Glasgow">Glasgow</a>\'s contribution to music was recognised in 2008 when it was named a <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/City_of_Music_(UNESCO)" title="City of Music (UNESCO)">City of Music</a>, one of only three cities in the world to have this honour.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-528"><a href="#cite_note-528">[511]</a></sup>\n</p><p>As of 2016, <a href="/wiki/Pop_music" title="Pop music">pop</a> remains the most popular music genre in the UK with 33.4% of unit sales, followed by <a href="/wiki/Hip_hop_music" title="Hip hop music">hip-hop</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rhythm_and_blues" title="Rhythm and blues">R&amp;B</a> at 24.5% of unit sales.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_529-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-529">[512]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rock_music" title="Rock music">Rock</a> is not far behind at 22.6% of unit sales.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_529-1"><a href="#cite_note-:0-529">[512]</a></sup> The modern UK is known to produce some of the most prominent world rappers along with the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Stormzy" title="Stormzy">Stormzy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kano_(rapper)" title="Kano (rapper)">Kano</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yxng_Bane" title="Yxng Bane">Yxng Bane</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ramz_(rapper)" title="Ramz (rapper)">Ramz</a> and <a href="/wiki/Skepta" title="Skepta">Skepta</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-530"><a href="#cite_note-530">[513]</a></sup> The sharp increase of hip-hop and R&amp;B listeners in the UK in the last three years is often explained by an easier access to the genre due to the higher usage of streaming platforms such as <a href="/wiki/Spotify" title="Spotify">Spotify</a> and <a href="/wiki/SoundCloud" title="SoundCloud">SoundCloud</a> where hip-hop and R&amp;B is the most popular genre,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-531"><a href="#cite_note-531">[514]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-532"><a href="#cite_note-532">[515]</a></sup> and also by the rising of new hip-hop and R&amp;B sub-genres popular among the <a href="/wiki/Millennials" title="Millennials">Millennials</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Generation_Z" title="Generation Z">Generation Z</a> (post-Millennials), mainly developed in the US with artists popular in the UK, such as phonk rap<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-533"><a href="#cite_note-533">[516]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-534"><a href="#cite_note-534">[517]</a></sup> (e.g. <a href="/wiki/ASAP_Rocky" title="ASAP Rocky">A$AP Rocky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lil_Uzi_Vert" title="Lil Uzi Vert">Lil Uzi Vert</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chance_the_Rapper" title="Chance the Rapper">Chance the Rapper</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lil_Skies" title="Lil Skies">Lil Skies</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Alternative_R%26B" title="Alternative R&amp;B">alternative R&amp;B</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-535"><a href="#cite_note-535">[518]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-536"><a href="#cite_note-536">[519]</a></sup> (e.g. <a href="/wiki/The_Weeknd" title="The Weeknd">The Weeknd</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beyonc%C3%A9" title="Beyonc&#233;">Beyonc&#233;</a>, <a href="/wiki/Janelle_Mon%C3%A1e" title="Janelle Mon&#225;e">Janelle Mon&#225;e</a>, <a href="/wiki/SZA_(singer)" title="SZA (singer)">SZA</a>).\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Visual_art">Visual art</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Art_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Art of the United Kingdom">Art of the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Turner_selfportrait.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="1182" decoding="async" height="221" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Turner_selfportrait.jpg/170px-Turner_selfportrait.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Turner_selfportrait.jpg/255px-Turner_selfportrait.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Turner_selfportrait.jpg/340px-Turner_selfportrait.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Turner_selfportrait.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/J._M._W._Turner" title="J. M. W. Turner">J. M. W. Turner</a> self-portrait, oil on canvas, c. 1799</div></div></div>\n<p>The history of British visual art forms part of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_art_history" title="Western art history">western art history</a>. Major British artists include: the <a href="/wiki/Romanticism" title="Romanticism">Romantics</a> <a href="/wiki/William_Blake" title="William Blake">William Blake</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Constable" title="John Constable">John Constable</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Palmer" title="Samuel Palmer">Samuel Palmer</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/J.M.W._Turner" title="J.M.W. Turner">J.M.W. Turner</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Portrait" title="Portrait">portrait</a> painters <a href="/wiki/Joshua_Reynolds" title="Joshua Reynolds">Sir Joshua Reynolds</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lucian_Freud" title="Lucian Freud">Lucian Freud</a>; the landscape artists <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Gainsborough" title="Thomas Gainsborough">Thomas Gainsborough</a> and <a href="/wiki/L._S._Lowry" title="L. S. Lowry">L. S. Lowry</a>; the pioneer of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arts_and_Crafts_Movement" title="Arts and Crafts Movement">Arts and Crafts Movement</a> <a href="/wiki/William_Morris" title="William Morris">William Morris</a>; the figurative painter <a href="/wiki/Francis_Bacon" title="Francis Bacon">Francis Bacon</a>; the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pop_artist" title="Pop artist">Pop artists</a> <a href="/wiki/Peter_Blake_(artist)" title="Peter Blake (artist)">Peter Blake</a>, <a href="/wiki/Richard_Hamilton_(artist)" title="Richard Hamilton (artist)">Richard Hamilton</a> and <a href="/wiki/David_Hockney" title="David Hockney">David Hockney</a>; the pioneers of <a href="/wiki/Conceptual_art" title="Conceptual art">Conceptual art</a> movement <a href="/wiki/Art_%26_Language" title="Art &amp; Language">Art &amp; Language</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-537"><a href="#cite_note-537">[520]</a></sup> the collaborative duo <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gilbert_and_George" title="Gilbert and George">Gilbert and George</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Abstract_art" title="Abstract art">abstract</a> artist <a href="/wiki/Howard_Hodgkin" title="Howard Hodgkin">Howard Hodgkin</a>; and the sculptors <a href="/wiki/Antony_Gormley" title="Antony Gormley">Antony Gormley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anish_Kapoor" title="Anish Kapoor">Anish Kapoor</a> and <a href="/wiki/Henry_Moore" title="Henry Moore">Henry Moore</a>. During the late 1980s and 1990s the <a href="/wiki/Saatchi_Gallery" title="Saatchi Gallery">Saatchi Gallery</a> in London helped to bring to public attention a group of multi-genre artists who would become known as the "<a href="/wiki/Young_British_Artists" title="Young British Artists">Young British Artists</a>": <a href="/wiki/Damien_Hirst" title="Damien Hirst">Damien Hirst</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chris_Ofili" title="Chris Ofili">Chris Ofili</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rachel_Whiteread" title="Rachel Whiteread">Rachel Whiteread</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tracey_Emin" title="Tracey Emin">Tracey Emin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mark_Wallinger" title="Mark Wallinger">Mark Wallinger</a>, <a href="/wiki/Steve_McQueen_(director)" title="Steve McQueen (director)">Steve McQueen</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sam_Taylor-Wood" title="Sam Taylor-Wood">Sam Taylor-Wood</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Jake_and_Dinos_Chapman" title="Jake and Dinos Chapman">Chapman Brothers</a> are among the better-known members of this loosely affiliated movement.\n</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Royal_Academy" title="Royal Academy">Royal Academy</a> in London is a key organisation for the promotion of the visual arts in the United Kingdom. Major schools of art in the UK include: the six-school <a href="/wiki/University_of_the_Arts_London" title="University of the Arts London">University of the Arts London</a>, which includes the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_Saint_Martins_College_of_Art_and_Design" title="Central Saint Martins College of Art and Design">Central Saint Martins College of Art and Design</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chelsea_College_of_Art_and_Design" title="Chelsea College of Art and Design">Chelsea College of Art and Design</a>; <a href="/wiki/Goldsmiths,_University_of_London" title="Goldsmiths, University of London">Goldsmiths, University of London</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Slade_School_of_Fine_Art" title="Slade School of Fine Art">Slade School of Fine Art</a> (part of <a href="/wiki/University_College_London" title="University College London">University College London</a>); the <a href="/wiki/Glasgow_School_of_Art" title="Glasgow School of Art">Glasgow School of Art</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Royal_College_of_Art" title="Royal College of Art">Royal College of Art</a>; and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Ruskin_School_of_Drawing_and_Fine_Art" title="The Ruskin School of Drawing and Fine Art">The Ruskin School of Drawing and Fine Art</a> (part of the University of Oxford). The <a href="/wiki/Courtauld_Institute_of_Art" title="Courtauld Institute of Art">Courtauld Institute of Art</a> is a leading centre for the teaching of the <a href="/wiki/History_of_art" title="History of art">history of art</a>. Important art galleries in the United Kingdom include the <a href="/wiki/National_Gallery" title="National Gallery">National Gallery</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Portrait_Gallery_(London)" title="National Portrait Gallery (London)">National Portrait Gallery</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tate_Britain" title="Tate Britain">Tate Britain</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tate_Modern" title="Tate Modern">Tate Modern</a> (the most-visited modern art gallery in the world, with around 4.7&#160;million visitors per year).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-538"><a href="#cite_note-538">[521]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cinema">Cinema</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Cinema of the United Kingdom">Cinema of the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hitchcock,_Alfred_02.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="890" data-file-width="802" decoding="async" height="189" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Hitchcock%2C_Alfred_02.jpg/170px-Hitchcock%2C_Alfred_02.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Hitchcock%2C_Alfred_02.jpg/255px-Hitchcock%2C_Alfred_02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Hitchcock%2C_Alfred_02.jpg/340px-Hitchcock%2C_Alfred_02.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hitchcock,_Alfred_02.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Alfred_Hitchcock" title="Alfred Hitchcock">Alfred Hitchcock</a> has been ranked as one of the greatest and most influential British filmmakers of all time<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-539"><a href="#cite_note-539">[522]</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>The United Kingdom has had a considerable influence on the history of the cinema. The British directors <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Hitchcock" title="Alfred Hitchcock">Alfred Hitchcock</a>, whose film <i><a href="/wiki/Vertigo_(film)" title="Vertigo (film)">Vertigo</a></i> is considered by some critics as the <a href="/wiki/List_of_films_considered_the_best" title="List of films considered the best">best film of all time</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc_540-0"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-540">[523]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/David_Lean" title="David Lean">David Lean</a> are among the most critically acclaimed of all-time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-541"><a href="#cite_note-541">[524]</a></sup> Other important directors including <a href="/wiki/Charlie_Chaplin" title="Charlie Chaplin">Charlie Chaplin</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-542"><a href="#cite_note-542">[525]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Michael_Powell" title="Michael Powell">Michael Powell</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-543"><a href="#cite_note-543">[526]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Carol_Reed" title="Carol Reed">Carol Reed</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-544"><a href="#cite_note-544">[527]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Edgar_Wright" title="Edgar Wright">Edgar Wright</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-545"><a href="#cite_note-545">[528]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Nolan" title="Christopher Nolan">Christopher Nolan</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-546"><a href="#cite_note-546">[529]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Ridley_Scott" title="Ridley Scott">Ridley Scott</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-547"><a href="#cite_note-547">[530]</a></sup> Many British actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including: <a href="/wiki/Julie_Andrews" title="Julie Andrews">Julie Andrews</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-548"><a href="#cite_note-548">[531]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Richard_Burton" title="Richard Burton">Richard Burton</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-549"><a href="#cite_note-549">[532]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Michael_Caine" title="Michael Caine">Michael Caine</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-550"><a
