href="#cite_note-550">[533]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Colin_Firth" title="Colin Firth">Colin Firth</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-551"><a href="#cite_note-551">[534]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Gary_Oldman" title="Gary Oldman">Gary Oldman</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-552"><a href="#cite_note-552">[535]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ben_Kingsley" title="Ben Kingsley">Ben Kingsley</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-553"><a href="#cite_note-553">[536]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ian_McKellen" title="Ian McKellen">Ian McKellen</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-554"><a href="#cite_note-554">[537]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Liam_Neeson" title="Liam Neeson">Liam Neeson</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-555"><a href="#cite_note-555">[538]</a></sup> Charlie Chaplin,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-556"><a href="#cite_note-556">[539]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sean_Connery" title="Sean Connery">Sean Connery</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-557"><a href="#cite_note-557">[540]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vivien_Leigh" title="Vivien Leigh">Vivien Leigh</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-558"><a href="#cite_note-558">[541]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/David_Niven" title="David Niven">David Niven</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-559"><a href="#cite_note-559">[542]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Laurence_Olivier" title="Laurence Olivier">Laurence Olivier</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-560"><a href="#cite_note-560">[543]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Peter_Sellers" title="Peter Sellers">Peter Sellers</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-561"><a href="#cite_note-561">[544]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kate_Winslet" title="Kate Winslet">Kate Winslet</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-562"><a href="#cite_note-562">[545]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Anthony_Hopkins" title="Anthony Hopkins">Anthony Hopkins</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-563"><a href="#cite_note-563">[546]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Day-Lewis" title="Daniel Day-Lewis">Daniel Day-Lewis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-564"><a href="#cite_note-564">[547]</a></sup> Some of the most commercially successful films of all time have been produced in the United Kingdom, including two of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_highest-grossing_film_series" title="List of highest-grossing film series">highest-grossing film franchises</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_(film_series)" title="Harry Potter (film series)">Harry Potter</a></i> and <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/James_Bond_(film_series)" title="James Bond (film series)">James Bond</a></i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-565"><a href="#cite_note-565">[548]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ealing_Studios" title="Ealing Studios">Ealing Studios</a> has a claim to being the oldest continuously working film studio in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-566"><a href="#cite_note-566">[549]</a></sup>\n</p><p>Despite a history of important and successful productions, the industry has often been characterised by a debate about its identity and the level of American and European influence.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> British producers are active in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_co-productions" title="International co-productions">international co-productions</a> and British actors, directors and crew feature regularly in American films.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Many successful Hollywood films have been based on British people, <a href="/wiki/British_literature" title="British literature">stories</a> or events, including <i><a href="/wiki/Titanic_(1997_film)" title="Titanic (1997 film)">Titanic</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings_(film_series)" title="The Lord of the Rings (film series)">The Lord of the Rings</a></i>, and <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pirates_of_the_Caribbean_films" title="Pirates of the Caribbean films">Pirates of the Caribbean</a></i>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>\n</p><p>In 2009, British films grossed around $2&#160;billion worldwide and achieved a market share of around 7% globally and 17% in the United Kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-statistics_567-0"><a href="#cite_note-statistics-567">[550]</a></sup> UK box-office takings totalled &#163;944&#160;million in 2009, with around 173&#160;million admissions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-statistics_567-1"><a href="#cite_note-statistics-567">[550]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/British_Film_Institute" title="British Film Institute">British Film Institute</a> has produced a poll ranking of what it considers to be the 100 greatest British films of all time, the <a href="/wiki/BFI_Top_100_British_films" title="BFI Top 100 British films">BFI Top 100 British films</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-568"><a href="#cite_note-568">[551]</a></sup> The annual <a href="/wiki/British_Academy_Film_Awards" title="British Academy Film Awards">British Academy Film Awards</a> are hosted by the <a href="/wiki/British_Academy_of_Film_and_Television_Arts" title="British Academy of Film and Television Arts">British Academy of Film and Television Arts</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-569"><a href="#cite_note-569">[552]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/British_cuisine" title="British cuisine">British cuisine</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chicken_tikka_masala.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3888" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="225" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Chicken_tikka_masala.jpg/150px-Chicken_tikka_masala.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Chicken_tikka_masala.jpg/225px-Chicken_tikka_masala.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Chicken_tikka_masala.jpg/300px-Chicken_tikka_masala.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Chicken_tikka_masala.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Chicken_tikka_masala" title="Chicken tikka masala">Chicken tikka masala</a>, 1971, adapted from <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">Indian</a> <a href="/wiki/Chicken_tikka" title="Chicken tikka">chicken tikka</a> and called "a true British national dish."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GuardianMasala_570-0"><a href="#cite_note-GuardianMasala-570">[553]</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p><a href="/wiki/British_cuisine" title="British cuisine">British cuisine</a> developed from various influences reflective of its land, settlements, arrivals of new settlers and immigrants, trade and colonialism. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Celtic_fields" title="Celtic fields">Celtic agriculture</a> and animal breeding produced a wide variety of foodstuffs for indigenous <a href="/wiki/Celts" title="Celts">Celts</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Britons_(historic)" title="Britons (historic)">Britons</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_England" title="Anglo-Saxon England">Anglo-Saxon England</a> developed meat and savoury herb stewing techniques before the practice became common in <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norman_conquest" title="Norman conquest">Norman conquest</a> introduced exotic spices into <a href="/wiki/England_in_the_Middle_Ages" title="England in the Middle Ages">England in the Middle Ages</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-571"><a href="#cite_note-571">[554]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a> facilitated a knowledge of <a href="/wiki/Indian_cuisine" title="Indian cuisine">Indian cuisine</a> with its "strong, penetrating spices and herbs". British cuisine has absorbed the cultural influence of those who have <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Immigration_to_the_United_Kingdom_since_1922" title="Immigration to the United Kingdom since 1922">settled in Britain</a>, producing many hybrid dishes, such as the Anglo-Indian <a href="/wiki/Chicken_tikka_masala" title="Chicken tikka masala">chicken tikka masala</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GuardianMasala_570-1"><a href="#cite_note-GuardianMasala-570">[553]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbcenc_572-0"><a href="#cite_note-bbcenc-572">[555]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Media_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Media of the United Kingdom">Media of the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bbc_broadcasting_house_front.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1076" data-file-width="774" decoding="async" height="236" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Bbc_broadcasting_house_front.jpg/170px-Bbc_broadcasting_house_front.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Bbc_broadcasting_house_front.jpg/255px-Bbc_broadcasting_house_front.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Bbc_broadcasting_house_front.jpg/340px-Bbc_broadcasting_house_front.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bbc_broadcasting_house_front.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Broadcasting_House" title="Broadcasting House">Broadcasting House</a> in London, headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a>, the oldest and largest broadcaster in the world<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MediaNewsline_573-0"><a href="#cite_note-MediaNewsline-573">[556]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ProspectMag_574-0"><a href="#cite_note-ProspectMag-574">[557]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AboutBBC_575-0"><a href="#cite_note-AboutBBC-575">[558]</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a>, founded in 1922, is the UK\'s publicly funded radio, television and Internet broadcasting corporation, and is the oldest and largest broadcaster in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MediaNewsline_573-1"><a href="#cite_note-MediaNewsline-573">[556]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ProspectMag_574-1"><a href="#cite_note-ProspectMag-574">[557]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AboutBBC_575-1"><a href="#cite_note-AboutBBC-575">[558]</a></sup> It operates numerous television and radio stations in the UK and abroad and its domestic services are funded by the <a href="/wiki/Television_licensing_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Television licensing in the United Kingdom">television licence</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_576-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-576">[559]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-577"><a href="#cite_note-577">[560]</a></sup> Other major players in the UK media include <a href="/wiki/ITV_plc" title="ITV plc">ITV plc</a>, which operates 11 of the 15 regional television broadcasters that make up the <a href="/wiki/ITV_(TV_network)" title="ITV (TV network)">ITV Network</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-578"><a href="#cite_note-578">[561]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/News_Corporation" title="News Corporation">News Corporation</a>, which owns a number of national newspapers through <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/News_International" title="News International">News International</a> such as the most popular <a href="/wiki/Tabloid_(newspaper_format)" title="Tabloid (newspaper format)">tabloid</a> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Sun_(United_Kingdom)" title="The Sun (United Kingdom)">The Sun</a></i> and the longest-established daily "<a href="/wiki/Broadsheet" title="Broadsheet">broadsheet</a>" <i><a href="/wiki/The_Times" title="The Times">The Times</a></i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-579"><a href="#cite_note-579">[562]</a></sup> as well as holding a large stake in satellite broadcaster <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Sky_Broadcasting" title="British Sky Broadcasting">British Sky Broadcasting</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-580"><a href="#cite_note-580">[563]</a></sup> London dominates the media sector in the UK: national newspapers and television and radio are largely based there, although Manchester is also a significant national media centre. Edinburgh and Glasgow, and Cardiff, are important centres of newspaper and broadcasting production in Scotland and Wales respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-581"><a href="#cite_note-581">[564]</a></sup> The UK publishing sector, including books, directories and databases, journals, magazines and business media, newspapers and news agencies, has a combined turnover of around &#163;20 billion and employs around 167,000 people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-582"><a href="#cite_note-582">[565]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In 2009, it was estimated that individuals viewed a mean of 3.75 hours of television per day and 2.81 hours of radio. In that year the main BBC <a href="/wiki/Public_service_broadcasting_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Public service broadcasting in the United Kingdom">public service broadcasting</a> channels accounted for an estimated 28.4% of all television viewing; the three main independent channels accounted for 29.5% and the increasingly important other satellite and digital channels for the remaining 42.1%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-583"><a href="#cite_note-583">[566]</a></sup> Sales of newspapers have fallen since the 1970s and in 2010 41% of people reported reading a daily national newspaper.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-584"><a href="#cite_note-584">[567]</a></sup> In 2010, 82.5% of the UK population were Internet users, the highest proportion amongst the 20 countries with the largest total number of users in that year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-585"><a href="#cite_note-585">[568]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Philosophy">Philosophy</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/British_philosophy" title="British philosophy">British philosophy</a></div>\n<p>The United Kingdom is famous for the tradition of \'British Empiricism\', a branch of the philosophy of knowledge that states that only knowledge verified by experience is valid, and \'Scottish Philosophy\', sometimes referred to as the \'<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scottish_School_of_Common_Sense" title="Scottish School of Common Sense">Scottish School of Common Sense</a>\'.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-586"><a href="#cite_note-586">[569]</a></sup> The most famous philosophers of British Empiricism are <a href="/wiki/John_Locke" title="John Locke">John Locke</a>, <a href="/wiki/George_Berkeley" title="George Berkeley">George Berkeley</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-587"><a href="#cite_note-587">[note 18]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/David_Hume" title="David Hume">David Hume</a>; while <a href="/wiki/Dugald_Stewart" title="Dugald Stewart">Dugald Stewart</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Reid" title="Thomas Reid">Thomas Reid</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sir_William_Hamilton,_9th_Baronet" title="Sir William Hamilton, 9th Baronet">William Hamilton</a> were major exponents of the Scottish "common sense" school. Two Britons are also notable for a theory of moral philosophy <a href="/wiki/Utilitarianism" title="Utilitarianism">utilitarianism</a>, first used by <a href="/wiki/Jeremy_Bentham" title="Jeremy Bentham">Jeremy Bentham</a> and later by <a href="/wiki/John_Stuart_Mill" title="John Stuart Mill">John Stuart Mill</a> in his short work <i><a href="/wiki/Utilitarianism_(book)" title="Utilitarianism (book)">Utilitarianism</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-588"><a href="#cite_note-588">[570]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-589"><a href="#cite_note-589">[571]</a></sup>\nOther eminent philosophers from the UK and the states and countries that preceded it include <a href="/wiki/Duns_Scotus" title="Duns Scotus">Duns Scotus</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Lilburne" title="John Lilburne">John Lilburne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mary_Wollstonecraft" title="Mary Wollstonecraft">Mary Wollstonecraft</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sir_Francis_Bacon" title="Sir Francis Bacon">Sir Francis Bacon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Adam_Smith" title="Adam Smith">Adam Smith</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Hobbes" title="Thomas Hobbes">Thomas Hobbes</a>, <a href="/wiki/William_of_Ockham" title="William of Ockham">William of Ockham</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bertrand_Russell" title="Bertrand Russell">Bertrand Russell</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alfred_Jules_Ayer" title="Alfred Jules Ayer">A.J. "Freddie" Ayer</a>. Foreign-born philosophers who settled in the UK include <a href="/wiki/Isaiah_Berlin" title="Isaiah Berlin">Isaiah Berlin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Karl_Marx" title="Karl Marx">Karl Marx</a>, <a href="/wiki/Karl_Popper" title="Karl Popper">Karl Popper</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ludwig_Wittgenstein" title="Ludwig Wittgenstein">Ludwig Wittgenstein</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sport">Sport</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Sport in the United Kingdom">Sport in the United Kingdom</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wembley-STadion_2013.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3377" data-file-width="4502" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Wembley-STadion_2013.JPG/220px-Wembley-STadion_2013.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Wembley-STadion_2013.JPG/330px-Wembley-STadion_2013.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Wembley-STadion_2013.JPG/440px-Wembley-STadion_2013.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Wembley-STadion_2013.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Wembley_Stadium" title="Wembley Stadium">Wembley Stadium</a>, London, home of the <a href="/wiki/England_national_football_team" title="England national football team">England national football team</a>, is one of the most expensive stadia ever built<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CNN-NFLStad_590-0"><a href="#cite_note-CNN-NFLStad-590">[572]</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p>Major sports, including association football, <a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">tennis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union" title="Rugby union">rugby union</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rugby_league" title="Rugby league">rugby league</a>, <a href="/wiki/Golf" title="Golf">golf</a>, <a href="/wiki/Boxing" title="Boxing">boxing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Netball" title="Netball">netball</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rowing_(sport)" title="Rowing (sport)">rowing</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cricket" title="Cricket">cricket</a>, originated or were substantially developed in the UK and the states that preceded it. With the rules and codes of many modern sports invented and codified in late 19th century <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Victorian_Britain" title="Victorian Britain">Victorian Britain</a>, in 2012, the President of the IOC, <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Rogge" title="Jacques Rogge">Jacques Rogge</a>, stated; "This great, sports-loving country is widely recognised as the birthplace of modern sport. It was here that the concepts of sportsmanship and fair play were first codified into clear rules and regulations. It was here that sport was included as an educational tool in the school curriculum".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-591"><a href="#cite_note-591">[573]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-592"><a href="#cite_note-592">[574]</a></sup>\n</p><p>In most international competitions, separate teams represent England, Scotland and Wales. Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland usually field a single team representing all of Ireland, with notable exceptions being association football and the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_Games" title="Commonwealth Games">Commonwealth Games</a>. In sporting contexts, the English, Scottish, Welsh and Irish / Northern Irish teams are often referred to collectively as the <a href="/wiki/Home_Nations" title="Home Nations">Home Nations</a>. There are some sports in which a single team represents the whole of United Kingdom, including the Olympics, where the UK is represented by the <a href="/wiki/Great_Britain_at_the_Olympics" title="Great Britain at the Olympics">Great Britain team</a>. The <a href="/wiki/1908_Summer_Olympics" title="1908 Summer Olympics">1908</a>, <a href="/wiki/1948_Summer_Olympics" title="1948 Summer Olympics">1948</a> and <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics" title="2012 Summer Olympics">2012</a> Summer Olympics were held in London, making it the first city to host the games three times. Britain has participated in every modern Olympic Games to date and is third in the <a href="/wiki/All-time_Olympic_Games_medal_table" title="All-time Olympic Games medal table">medal count</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>\n</p><p>A 2003 poll found that football is the most popular <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Sport in the United Kingdom">sport in the United Kingdom</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sports_poll_593-0"><a href="#cite_note-sports_poll-593">[575]</a></sup> England is recognised by <a href="/wiki/FIFA" title="FIFA">FIFA</a> as the birthplace of club football, and <a href="/wiki/The_Football_Association" title="The Football Association">The Football Association</a> is the oldest of its kind, with the <a href="/wiki/Laws_of_the_Game_(association_football)" title="Laws of the Game (association football)">rules of football</a> first drafted in 1863 by <a href="/wiki/Ebenezer_Cobb_Morley" title="Ebenezer Cobb Morley">Ebenezer Cobb Morley</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-594"><a href="#cite_note-594">[576]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-595"><a href="#cite_note-595">[577]</a></sup> Each of the Home Nations has its own football association, national team and <a href="/wiki/League_system" title="League system">league system</a>. The English top division, the <a href="/wiki/Premier_League" title="Premier League">Premier League</a>, is the most watched football league in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-596"><a href="#cite_note-596">[578]</a></sup> The first international football match was contested by <a href="/wiki/England_national_football_team" title="England national football team">England</a> and <a href="/wiki/Scotland_national_football_team" title="Scotland national football team">Scotland</a> on 30 November 1872.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_article_597-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_article-597">[579]</a></sup> England, Scotland, <a href="/wiki/Wales_national_football_team" title="Wales national football team">Wales</a> and <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland_national_football_team" title="Northern Ireland national football team">Northern Ireland</a> usually compete as separate countries in international competitions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-598"><a href="#cite_note-598">[580]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Inside_the_Millennium_Stadium,_Cardiff.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1920" data-file-width="2560" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Inside_the_Millennium_Stadium%2C_Cardiff.jpg/220px-Inside_the_Millennium_Stadium%2C_Cardiff.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Inside_the_Millennium_Stadium%2C_Cardiff.jpg/330px-Inside_the_Millennium_Stadium%2C_Cardiff.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Inside_the_Millennium_Stadium%2C_Cardiff.jpg/440px-Inside_the_Millennium_Stadium%2C_Cardiff.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Inside_the_Millennium_Stadium,_Cardiff.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Millennium_Stadium" title="Millennium Stadium">Millennium Stadium</a> of <a href="/wiki/Cardiff" title="Cardiff">Cardiff</a> opened for the <a href="/wiki/1999_Rugby_World_Cup" title="1999 Rugby World Cup">1999 Rugby World Cup</a></div></div></div>\n<p>In 2003, <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union" title="Rugby union">rugby union</a> was ranked the second most popular sport in the UK.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sports_poll_593-1"><a href="#cite_note-sports_poll-593">[575]</a></sup> The sport was created in <a href="/wiki/Rugby_School" title="Rugby School">Rugby School</a>, Warwickshire, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1871_England_versus_Scotland_rugby_union_match" title="1871 England versus Scotland rugby union match">first rugby international</a> took place on 27 March 1871 between <a href="/wiki/England_national_rugby_union_team" title="England national rugby union team">England</a> and <a href="/wiki/Scotland_national_rugby_union_team" title="Scotland national rugby union team">Scotland</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-599"><a href="#cite_note-599">[581]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-600"><a href="#cite_note-600">[582]</a></sup> England, Scotland, Wales, Ireland, France and Italy compete in the <a href="/wiki/Six_Nations_Championship" title="Six Nations Championship">Six Nations Championship</a>; the premier international tournament in the northern hemisphere. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sport_governing_body" title="Sport governing body">Sport governing bodies</a> in <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union_in_England" title="Rugby union in England">England</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union_in_Scotland" title="Rugby union in Scotland">Scotland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union_in_Wales" title="Rugby union in Wales">Wales</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union_in_Ireland" title="Rugby union in Ireland">Ireland</a> organise and regulate the game separately.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-601"><a href="#cite_note-601">[583]</a></sup>\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Cricket" title="Cricket">Cricket</a> was invented in England, and its <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Laws_of_cricket" title="Laws of cricket">laws</a> were established by <a href="/wiki/Marylebone_Cricket_Club" title="Marylebone Cricket Club">Marylebone Cricket Club</a> in 1788.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-602"><a href="#cite_note-602">[584]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/England_cricket_team" title="England cricket team">England cricket team</a>, controlled by the <a href="/wiki/England_and_Wales_Cricket_Board" title="England and Wales Cricket Board">England and Wales Cricket Board</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-603"><a href="#cite_note-603">[585]</a></sup> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Irish_cricket_team" title="Irish cricket team">Irish cricket team</a>, controlled by <a href="/wiki/Cricket_Ireland" title="Cricket Ireland">Cricket Ireland</a> are the only national teams in the UK with <a href="/wiki/Test_cricket" title="Test cricket">Test status</a>. Team members are drawn from the main county sides, and include both English and Welsh players. Cricket is distinct from football and rugby where Wales and England field separate national teams, although Wales had fielded its own team in the past. <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Ireland" title="Sport in Ireland">Irish</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cricket_in_Scotland" title="Cricket in Scotland">Scottish</a> players have played for England because neither <a href="/wiki/Scotland_national_cricket_team" title="Scotland national cricket team">Scotland</a> nor <a href="/wiki/Ireland_cricket_team" title="Ireland cricket team">Ireland</a> have Test status and have only recently started to play in <a href="/wiki/One_Day_International" title="One Day International">One Day Internationals</a> and Ireland is yet to play their first test match.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-604"><a href="#cite_note-604">[586]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-605"><a href="#cite_note-605">[587]</a></sup> Scotland, England (and Wales), and Ireland (including Northern Ireland) have competed at the <a href="/wiki/Cricket_World_Cup" title="Cricket World Cup">Cricket World Cup</a>, with England reaching the finals on three occasions. There is a professional <a href="/wiki/County_Championship" title="County Championship">league championship</a> in which clubs representing 17 English counties and 1 Welsh county compete.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-606"><a href="#cite_note-606">[588]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Saville_vs_Broady_%E2%80%93_Wimbledon_Boys_Singles_Final_2011.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Saville_vs_Broady_%E2%80%93_Wimbledon_Boys_Singles_Final_2011.jpg/220px-Saville_vs_Broady_%E2%80%93_Wimbledon_Boys_Singles_Final_2011.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Saville_vs_Broady_%E2%80%93_Wimbledon_Boys_Singles_Final_2011.jpg/330px-Saville_vs_Broady_%E2%80%93_Wimbledon_Boys_Singles_Final_2011.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Saville_vs_Broady_%E2%80%93_Wimbledon_Boys_Singles_Final_2011.jpg/440px-Saville_vs_Broady_%E2%80%93_Wimbledon_Boys_Singles_Final_2011.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Saville_vs_Broady_%E2%80%93_Wimbledon_Boys_Singles_Final_2011.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon" title="The Championships, Wimbledon">Wimbledon</a>, the oldest <a href="/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)" title="Grand Slam (tennis)">Grand Slam</a> tennis tournament, is held in <a href="/wiki/Wimbledon,_London" title="Wimbledon, London">Wimbledon</a>, London every June and July</div></div></div>\n<p>The modern game of <a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">tennis</a> originated in Birmingham, England, in the 1860s, before spreading around the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-607"><a href="#cite_note-607">[589]</a></sup> The world\'s oldest tennis tournament, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wimbledon_championships" title="Wimbledon championships">Wimbledon championships</a>, first occurred in 1877, and today the event takes place over two weeks in late June and early July.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-608"><a href="#cite_note-608">[590]</a></sup>\n</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Thoroughbred_horse_race" title="Thoroughbred horse race">Thoroughbred racing</a>, which originated under <a href="/wiki/Charles_II_of_England" title="Charles II of England">Charles II of England</a> as the "sport of kings", is popular throughout the UK with world-famous races including the <a href="/wiki/Grand_National" title="Grand National">Grand National</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Epsom_Derby" title="Epsom Derby">Epsom Derby</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Royal_Ascot" title="Royal Ascot">Royal Ascot</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cheltenham_National_Hunt_Festival" title="Cheltenham National Hunt Festival">Cheltenham National Hunt Festival</a> (including the <a href="/wiki/Cheltenham_Gold_Cup" title="Cheltenham Gold Cup">Cheltenham Gold Cup</a>). The UK has proved successful in the international sporting arena in <a href="/wiki/Rowing_(sport)" title="Rowing (sport)">rowing</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>\n</p><p>The UK is closely associated with <a href="/wiki/Motorsport" title="Motorsport">motorsport</a>. Many teams and drivers in <a href="/wiki/Formula_One" title="Formula One">Formula One</a> (F1) are based in the UK, and the country has won more <a href="/wiki/List_of_Formula_One_World_Drivers%27_Champions" title="List of Formula One World Drivers\' Champions">drivers\'</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Formula_One_World_Constructors%27_Champions" title="List of Formula One World Constructors\' Champions">constructors\'</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Formula_One_World_Championship" title="Formula One World Championship">titles</a> than any other. The UK hosted the first F1 Grand Prix in 1950 at <a href="/wiki/Silverstone_Circuit" title="Silverstone Circuit">Silverstone</a>, the current location of the <a href="/wiki/British_Grand_Prix" title="British Grand Prix">British Grand Prix</a> held each year in July.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-609"><a href="#cite_note-609">[591]</a></sup> The UK hosts legs of the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Prix_motorcycle_racing" title="Grand Prix motorcycle racing">Grand Prix motorcycle racing</a>, <a href="/wiki/World_Rally_Championship" title="World Rally Championship">World Rally Championship</a> and <a href="/wiki/FIA_World_Endurance_Championship" title="FIA World Endurance Championship">FIA World Endurance Championship</a>. The premier national auto racing event is the <a href="/wiki/British_Touring_Car_Championship" title="British Touring Car Championship">British Touring Car Championship</a>. Motorcycle road racing has a long tradition with races such as the <a href="/wiki/Isle_of_Man_TT" title="Isle of Man TT">Isle of Man TT</a> and the <a href="/wiki/North_West_200" title="North West 200">North West 200</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>\n</p>\n<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:R%26A_Clubhouse,_Old_Course,_Swilcan_Burn_bridge.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2709" data-file-width="4059" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/R%26A_Clubhouse%2C_Old_Course%2C_Swilcan_Burn_bridge.jpg/220px-R%26A_Clubhouse%2C_Old_Course%2C_Swilcan_Burn_bridge.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/R%26A_Clubhouse%2C_Old_Course%2C_Swilcan_Burn_bridge.jpg/330px-R%26A_Clubhouse%2C_Old_Course%2C_Swilcan_Burn_bridge.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/R%26A_Clubhouse%2C_Old_Course%2C_Swilcan_Burn_bridge.jpg/440px-R%26A_Clubhouse%2C_Old_Course%2C_Swilcan_Burn_bridge.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:R%26A_Clubhouse,_Old_Course,_Swilcan_Burn_bridge.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/The_Royal_and_Ancient_Golf_Club_of_St_Andrews" title="The Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St Andrews">St Andrews</a>, Scotland, the home of golf. The standard 18 hole golf course was created at St Andrews in 1764.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Forrest_610-0"><a href="#cite_note-Forrest-610">[592]</a></sup></div></div></div>\n<p><a href="/wiki/Golf" title="Golf">Golf</a> is the sixth most popular sport, by participation, in the UK. Although <a href="/wiki/The_Royal_and_Ancient_Golf_Club_of_St_Andrews" title="The Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St Andrews">The Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St Andrews</a> in Scotland is the sport\'s home course,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-611"><a href="#cite_note-611">[593]</a></sup> the world\'s oldest golf course is actually Musselburgh Links\' Old Golf Course.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-612"><a href="#cite_note-612">[594]</a></sup> In 1764, the standard 18-hole golf course was created at St Andrews when members modified the course from 22 to 18 holes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Forrest_610-1"><a href="#cite_note-Forrest-610">[592]</a></sup> The oldest golf tournament in the world, and the first major championship in golf, <a href="/wiki/The_Open_Championship" title="The Open Championship">The Open Championship</a>, is played annually on the weekend of the third Friday in July.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-613"><a href="#cite_note-613">[595]</a></sup>\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Rugby_league" title="Rugby league">Rugby league</a> originated in Huddersfield, West Yorkshire in 1895 and is generally played in <a href="/wiki/Northern_England" title="Northern England">Northern England</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-614"><a href="#cite_note-614">[596]</a></sup> A single \'Great Britain Lions\' team had competed in the <a href="/wiki/Rugby_League_World_Cup" title="Rugby League World Cup">Rugby League World Cup</a> and Test match games, but this changed in 2008 when <a href="/wiki/England_national_rugby_league_team" title="England national rugby league team">England</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scotland_national_rugby_league_team" title="Scotland national rugby league team">Scotland</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ireland_national_rugby_league_team" title="Ireland national rugby league team">Ireland</a> competed as separate nations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-615"><a href="#cite_note-615">[597]</a></sup> Great Britain is still retained as the full national team. <a href="/wiki/Super_League" title="Super League">Super League</a> is the highest level of professional rugby league in the UK and Europe. It consists of 11 teams from Northern England, 1 from London, 1 from Wales and 1 from France.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-616"><a href="#cite_note-616">[598]</a></sup>\n</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marquess_of_Queensberry_rules" title="Marquess of Queensberry rules">\'Queensberry rules\'</a>, the code of general rules in <a href="/wiki/Boxing" title="Boxing">boxing</a>, was named after <a href="/wiki/John_Douglas,_9th_Marquess_of_Queensberry" title="John Douglas, 9th Marquess of Queensberry">John Douglas, 9th Marquess of Queensberry</a> in 1867, and formed the basis of modern boxing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-617"><a href="#cite_note-617">[599]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Snooker" title="Snooker">Snooker</a> is another of the UK\'s popular sporting exports, with the world championships held annually in <a href="/wiki/Sheffield" title="Sheffield">Sheffield</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-618"><a href="#cite_note-618">[600]</a></sup> In Northern Ireland <a href="/wiki/Gaelic_football" title="Gaelic football">Gaelic football</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hurling" title="Hurling">hurling</a> are popular team sports, both in terms of participation and spectating, and Irish expatriates in the UK and the US also play them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CJSHurl_619-0"><a href="#cite_note-CJSHurl-619">[601]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Shinty" title="Shinty">Shinty</a> (or <i>camanachd</i>) is popular in the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Highlands" title="Scottish Highlands">Scottish Highlands</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-620"><a href="#cite_note-620">[602]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Highland_games" title="Highland games">Highland games</a> are held in spring and summer in Scotland, celebrating Scottish and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Celt" title="Celt">celtic</a> culture and heritage, especially that of the Scottish Highlands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-621"><a href="#cite_note-621">[603]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Symbols">Symbols</span></h3>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Symbols_of_the_United_Kingdom,_the_Channel_Islands_and_the_Isle_of_Man" title="Symbols of the United Kingdom, the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man">Symbols of the United Kingdom, the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man</a></div>\n<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Britannia-Statue.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3648" data-file-width="2736" decoding="async" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Britannia-Statue.jpg/170px-Britannia-Statue.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Britannia-Statue.jpg/255px-Britannia-Statue.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Britannia-Statue.jpg/340px-Britannia-Statue.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Britannia-Statue.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Statue of <a href="/wiki/Britannia" title="Britannia">Britannia</a> in <a href="/wiki/Plymouth" title="Plymouth">Plymouth</a>. Britannia is a <a href="/wiki/National_personification" title="National personification">national personification</a> of the UK.</div></div></div>\n<p>The <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Flag of the United Kingdom">flag of the United Kingdom</a> is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Union_Flag" title="Union Flag">Union Flag</a> (also referred to as the Union Jack). It was created in 1606 by the superimposition of the <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_England" title="Flag of England">Flag of England</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_Scotland" title="Flag of Scotland">Flag of Scotland</a> and updated in 1801 with the addition of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saint_Patrick%27s_Flag" title="Saint Patrick\'s Flag">Saint Patrick\'s Flag</a>. Wales is not represented in the Union Flag, as Wales had been conquered and annexed to England prior to the formation of the United Kingdom. The possibility of redesigning the Union Flag to include representation of Wales has not been completely ruled out.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-622"><a href="#cite_note-622">[604]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/National_anthem" title="National anthem">national anthem</a> of the United Kingdom is "<a href="/wiki/God_Save_the_Queen" title="God Save the Queen">God Save the Queen</a>", with "Queen" replaced with "King" in the lyrics whenever the monarch is a man.\n</p><p><a href="/wiki/Britannia" title="Britannia">Britannia</a> is a <a href="/wiki/National_personification" title="National personification">national personification</a> of the United Kingdom, originating from <a href="/wiki/Roman_Britain" title="Roman Britain">Roman Britain</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-623"><a href="#cite_note-623">[605]</a></sup> Britannia is symbolised as a young woman with brown or golden hair, wearing a <a href="/wiki/Corinthian_helmet" title="Corinthian helmet">Corinthian helmet</a> and white robes. She holds <a href="/wiki/Poseidon" title="Poseidon">Poseidon</a>\'s three-pronged trident and a shield, bearing the Union Flag. Sometimes she is depicted as riding on the back of a lion.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Since the height of the British Empire in the late 19th century, Britannia has often been associated with British maritime dominance, as in the patriotic song "<a href="/wiki/Rule,_Britannia!" title="Rule, Britannia!">Rule, Britannia!</a>".<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Up until 2008, the lion symbol was depicted behind Britannia on the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fifty_pence_(British_decimal_coin)" title="Fifty pence (British decimal coin)">British fifty pence coin</a> and on the back of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ten_pence_(British_decimal_coin)" title="Ten pence (British decimal coin)">British ten pence coin</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> It is also used as a symbol on the non-ceremonial flag of the British Army.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>\n</p><p>A second, less used, personification of the nation is the character <a href="/wiki/John_Bull" title="John Bull">John Bull</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Bulldog" title="Bulldog">bulldog</a> is sometimes used as a symbol of the United Kingdom and has been associated with Winston Churchill\'s defiance of <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-624"><a href="#cite_note-624">[606]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Historiography">Historiography</span></h2>\n<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Historiography_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Historiography of the United Kingdom">historiography of the United Kingdom</a> and <a href="/wiki/Historiography_of_the_British_Empire" title="Historiography of the British Empire">historiography of the British Empire</a></div>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>\n<div aria-label="Portals" class="noprint portal plainlist tright" role="navigation" style="margin:0.5em 0 0.5em United Kingdom">Outline of the United Kingdom</a>\n<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Outline_of_England" title="Outline of England">Outline of England</a></li>\n<li><a href="/wiki/Outline_of_Northern_Ireland" rankings of the United Kingdom</a></li></ul>\n<p><img alt="" data-file-height="209" data-file-width="375" decoding="async" height="9" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Open_book_nae_02.svg/16px-Open_book_nae_02.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Open_book_nae_02.svg/24px-Open_book_nae_02.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Open_book_nae_02.svg/32px-Open_book_nae_02.svg.png 2x" width="16"/> <i><a href="/wiki/Book:United_Kingdom" title="Book:United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a></i> &#8211; <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Books" title="Wikipedia:Books">Wikipedia book</a>\n</p>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>\n<div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;">\n<div class="mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns"><ol class="references">\n<li id="cite_note-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-1">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">An alternative variant of the Royal coat of arms is used in Scotland: <a href="/wiki/File:Royal_Coat_of_Arms_of_the_United_Kingdom_(Scotland).svg" title="File:Royal Coat of Arms of the United Kingdom (Scotland).svg">[click to view image]</a>.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">There is no authorised version of the national anthem as the words are a matter of tradition; only the first verse is usually sung.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2"><a href="#cite_note-2">[1]</a></sup> No law was passed making "God Save the Queen" the official anthem. In the English tradition, such laws are not necessary; proclamation and usage are sufficient to make it the national anthem. "God Save the Queen" also serves as the <a href="/wiki/Honors_music" title="Honors music">Royal anthem</a> for certain <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Commonwealth_realms" title="Commonwealth realms">Commonwealth realms</a>. The words <i>Queen, she, her</i>, used at present (in the reign of Elizabeth II), are replaced by <i>King, he, him</i> when the monarch is male. </span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-8"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-8">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Under the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a>\'s <a href="/wiki/European_Charter_for_Regional_or_Minority_Languages" title="European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages">European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages</a>, Scots, Ulster Scots, Welsh, Cornish, Scottish Gaelic and Irish are officially recognised as <a href="/wiki/Regional_language" title="Regional language">regional</a> or <a href="/wiki/Minority_language" title="Minority language">minority</a> languages by the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Government of the United Kingdom">British Government</a> for the purposes of the Charter.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-reglang_4-0"><a href="#cite_note-reglang-4">[2]</a></sup> In addition, the Government provides some services and publishes documents in Welsh.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-5"><a href="#cite_note-5">[3]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-6"><a href="#cite_note-6">[4]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7"><a href="#cite_note-7">[5]</a></sup> See also <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Languages of the United Kingdom">Languages of the United Kingdom</a>. </span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-11"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-11">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> since 1993.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-18"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-18">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Some of the devolved countries, Crown dependencies and British Overseas Territories issue their own sterling banknotes or currencies, or use another nation\'s currency. See <a href="/wiki/List_of_British_currencies" title="List of British currencies">List of British currencies</a> for more information</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-19"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-19">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">This excludes some of the UK\'s dependencies. See <a href="/wiki/Time_in_the_United_Kingdom#British_territories" title="Time in the United Kingdom">Time in the United Kingdom#British territories</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-20"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-20">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Excluding two overseas territories: <a href="/wiki/Gibraltar" title="Gibraltar">Gibraltar</a> and the <a href="/wiki/British_Indian_Ocean_Territory" title="British Indian Ocean Territory">British Indian Ocean Territory</a>.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-21"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-21">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_the_United_Kingdom#Telephone_numbers_in_Overseas_Territories" title="Telephone numbers in the United Kingdom">Excludes most overseas territories</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-22"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-22">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The <a href="/wiki/.eu" title=".eu">.eu</a> domain is also used, as it is shared with other European Union member states. <a href="/wiki/Template:UK_top-level_domains" title="Template:UK top-level domains">Other TLDs are used regionally</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-24"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-24">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Usage is mixed. Some organisations, including the <a class="external text" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/academy/journalism/news-style-guide/article/art20130702112133551" rel="nofollow">BBC</a> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20180326162901/http://www.bbc.co.uk/academy/journalism/news-style-guide/article/art20130702112133551" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> 26 March 2018 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a> and <a class="external text" href="https://www.gov.uk/guidance/style-guide/a-to-z-of-gov-uk-style#B" rel="nofollow">British Government</a>, prefer to use Britain as shorthand for <a href="/wiki/Great_Britain" title="Great Britain">Great Britain</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-35"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-35">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Irish_Treaty" title="Anglo-Irish Treaty">Anglo-Irish Treaty</a> was signed on 6 December 1921 to resolve the <a href="/wiki/Irish_War_of_Independence" title="Irish War of Independence">Irish War of Independence</a>. When it took effect one year later, it established the <a href="/wiki/Irish_Free_State" title="Irish Free State">Irish Free State</a> as a separate <a href="/wiki/Dominion" title="Dominion">dominion</a> within the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">Commonwealth</a>. The UK\'s current name was adopted to reflect the change.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-49"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-49">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Compare to section 1 of both of the 1800 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Acts_of_Union_(1800)" title="Acts of Union (1800)">Acts of Union</a> which reads: the <i>Kingdoms of Great Britain and Ireland shall...be united into one Kingdom, by the Name of "The United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland"</i></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-195"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-195">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Since the early twentieth century the prime minister has held the office of <a href="/wiki/First_Lord_of_the_Treasury" title="First Lord of the Treasury">First Lord of the Treasury</a>, and in recent decades has also held the office of <a href="/wiki/Minister_for_the_Civil_Service" title="Minister for the Civil Service">Minister for the Civil Service</a>.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-202"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-202">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Sinn F&#233;in, an <a href="/wiki/Irish_nationalism" title="Irish nationalism">Irish nationalist</a> party, also contests elections in the Republic of Ireland.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-281"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-281">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In 2007&#8211;2008, this was calculated to be &#163;115 per week for single adults with no dependent children; &#163;199 per week for couples with no dependent children; &#163;195 per week for single adults with two dependent children under 14; and &#163;279 per week for couples with two dependent children under 14.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-388"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-388">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The 2011 Census recorded Gypsies/Travellers as a separate ethnic group for the first time.</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-391"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-391">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In the 2011 Census, for the purpose of harmonising results to make them comparable across the UK, the ONS includes individuals in Scotland who classified themselves in the "African" category (29,638 people), which in the Scottish version of the census is separate from "Caribbean or Black" (6,540 people),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389"><a href="#cite_note-389">[373]</a></sup> in this "Black or Black British" category. The ONS note that "the African categories used in Scotland could potentially capture White/Asian/Other African in addition to Black identities".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-390"><a href="#cite_note-390">[374]</a></sup></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-587"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-587">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Berkeley is in fact Irish but was called a \'British empiricist\' due to the territory of what is now known as the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland" title="Republic of Ireland">Republic of Ireland</a> being in the UK at the time</span>\n</li>\n</ol></div></div>\n<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2>\n<div class="reflist columns references-column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em; list-style-type: decimal;">\n<ol class="references">\n<li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a class="external text" href="https://www.royal.uk/national-anthem" rel="nofollow">"National Anthem"</a>. <i>Official web site of the British Royal Family</i>. 15 January 2016<span class="reference-accessdate">. The abbreviation is UK</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=GOV.UK&amp;rft.atitle=Toponymic+guidelines+for+the+United+Kingdom&amp;rft.pages=13&amp;rft.date=2017-05&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.gov.uk%2Fgovernment%2Fpublications%2Ftoponymic-guidelines&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AUnited+Kingdom"></span><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r879151008" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-25"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-25">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a class="external text" href="http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/Great-Britain?q=Great+Britain" rel="nofollow">"Definition of Great Britain in English"</a>. Oxford University Press<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">29 October</span> 2014</span>. <q>Great Britain is the name for the island that comprises England, Scotland and Wales, although the term is also used loosely to refer to the United Kingdom.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Definition+of+Great+Britain+in+English&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.oxforddictionaries.com%2Fdefinition%2Fenglish%2FGreat-Britain%3Fq%3DGreat%2BBritain&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AUnited+Kingdom"></span><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r879151008" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-26"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-26">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="http://www.royal.gov.uk/MonarchUK/HowtheMonarchyworks/Whatisconstitutionalmonarchy.aspx" rel="nofollow">The British Monarchy, <i>What is constitutional monarchy?</i></a>. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">6 March</span> 2015</span>. <q><blockquote style="padding-top:0; margin-top:0; padding-left:0; padding-right:0;"><p>The full title of this country is \'the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland\'. Great Britain is made up of England, Scotland and Wales. The United Kingdom (UK) is made up of England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. \'Britain\' is used informally, usually meaning the United Kingdom.<br/> The Channel Islands and the Isle of Man are not part of the UK.</p></blockquote></q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Key+facts+about+the+United+Kingdom&amp;rft.pub=Directgov&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.direct.gov.uk%2Fen%2FGovernmentcitizensandrights%2FLivingintheUK%2FDG_10012517&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AUnited+Kingdom"></span><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r879151008" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-overseasterrirories-36"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-overseasterrirories_36-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-overseasterrirories_36-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-overseasterrirories_36-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a class="external text" href="https://www.gov.uk/government/policies/protecting-and-developing-the-overseas-territories" rel="nofollow">"Supporting the Overseas Territories"</a>. <a href="/wiki/Foreign_and_Commonwealth_Office" title="Foreign and Commonwealth Office">Foreign and Commonwealth Office</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. State University of New York Press. pp.&#160;59, 282. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7914-6401-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-7914-6401-4">978-0-7914-6401-4</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Balance+of+Power&amp;rft.pages=59%2C+282&amp;rft.pub=State+University+of+New+York+Press&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-7914-6401-4&amp;rft.au=T.V.+Paul&amp;rft.au=James+J.+Wirtz&amp;rft.au=Michel+Fortmann&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D9jy28vBqscQC%26pg%3DPA59%26dq%3D%22Great%2Bpower%22&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AUnited+Kingdom"></span><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r879151008" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/> <i>Accordingly, the great powers after the Cold War are Britain, China, France, Germany, Japan, Russia and the United States</i> p. 59</span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-David_M._McCourt-45"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-David_M._McCourt_45-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">McCourt, David (2014). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/?id=lwpOnwEACAAJ&amp;dq=Britain+and+World+Power+Since+1945:+Constructing+a+Nation%27s+Role+in+International+Politics" rel="nofollow"><i>Britain and World Power Since 1945: Constructing a Nation\'s Role in International Politics</i></a>. The United States and the UK designed a set of institutions&#8212;whether it was the United Nations, or the Bretton Woods structure, IMF, World Bank, NATO, across the board.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=whitehouse.gov&amp;rft.atitle=Remarks+by+the+President+Obama+and+Prime+Minister+Cameron+in+Joint+Press+Conference&amp;rft.date=2016-04-22&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fobamawhitehouse.archives.gov%2Fthe-press-office%2F2016%2F04%2F22%2Fremarks-president-obama-and-prime-minister-cameron-joint-press&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AUnited+Kingdom"></span><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r879151008" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></span>\n</li>\n<li id="cite_note-130"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-130">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news"><a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/28/business/worldbusiness/28iht-nazi.4042453.html" rel="nofollow">"Britain to make its final payment on World War II loan from U.S."</a> <i>The New York Times</i>. 28 December 2006<span class="reference-accessdate">.
